Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated and cited as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Madison, Alabama." Such Code may also be cited as the "Madison City Code." 
(Code 1979, § 1-1; Code 1992, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to provide for the revision and codification of its ordinances and for the adoption of a code, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-7. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, provided that these rules of construction shall not be applied to any section of this Code or any ordinance which contains any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject matter or content of such section may be repugnant thereto: 
    General rule. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
    Acts. References to acts are to acts of the Alabama Legislature, as published in the Acts of Alabama. Acts passed after 1978 are referenced to the act number, which number includes the last two digits of the year of enactment. All other acts are referenced to act number and year of enactment. All references to acts are followed by a parenthetical reference to the page number in the Acts of Alabama upon which the act begins. The page number reference is for information purposes only. All references to acts are to such acts as amended. 
    City. The term "city" means the City of Madison in the County of Madison, in the State of Alabama, incorporated under the laws of the State of Alabama. 
    City officials, officers and employees. Whenever reference is made to officials, boards, commissions, departments, officers or employees by title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the City of Madison" and shall be taken to mean the official, board, commission, department, officer or employee of this city having the title mentioned or performing the duties indicated; and powers and authority granted to them shall be deemed to be grants of such powers and authority to their respective duly designated subordinates. 
    Code of Alabama. Whenever reference is made to the "Code of Ala. 1975" it shall mean the Code of Ala. 1975, as amended, or any subsequent code of this state. 
    Computation of time. In computing any period of time, the day of the act, event or default from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so computed shall be included, unless it is a Saturday, a Sunday or a legal holiday, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day which is not a Saturday, a Sunday or a legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 1-1-4; legal holidays, Code of Ala. 1975, § 1-3-8. 
    Council, city council, governing body. The terms "council," "city council" and "governing body" mean the city council of the City of Madison, Alabama. 
    County. The terms "county," "the county" or "this county" means the County of Madison, State of Alabama. 
    Gender. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing one gender, the other genders shall be deemed to be included. 
    In the city or within the city. The terms "in the city" or "within the city" mean within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Joint authority. All words giving joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall give such authority to a majority of such persons or officers, unless it is otherwise declared. 
    Jurisdiction. All provisions of this Code and other laws and ordinances of the city prescribing police or sanitary regulations and prescribing penalties for violations thereof shall have force and effect in the corporate limits of the city and on any property or rights-of-way belonging to the city. 
    May. The term "may" is permissive. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month, unless otherwise expressed. 
    Number. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the singular number, the plural and separate matters and persons and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes affirmation. 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," where the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner" includes not only the owner of the whole, but the owner of any part of the property, any tenant in common or joint tenant of the whole or a part of property. 
    Person. The term "person" includes a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization, body politic and any other group acting as a unit as well an individual. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The term "property" shall include real, tangible and intangible personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements, and hereditaments. 
    Shall. The term "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when a person cannot write. 
    State. The terms "the state" or "this state" mean the State of Alabama. 
    Street. The term "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public ways in the city, and shall embrace all parts thereof within the designated right-of-way. In those instances where the context requires, the term "street" shall embrace only the area between the opposite curbs or curblines designated for vehicular traffic. 
    Tense. Words used in the present, future or past tense shall include each of the other tenses. 
    Wholesaler, wholesale dealer. In all cases where the term "wholesaler" or "wholesale dealer" is used in this Code or any ordinance, unless otherwise specifically defined, it shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale, as distinguished from a retail dealer who sells directly to the consumer. 
    Writing or in writing. The term "writing" or "in writing" may be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1979, § 1-2; Code 1992, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Definitions and construction of words, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 1-1-1, 1-1-2. 
Sec. 1-3. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same in substance as those of ordinances of the city existing at the time of the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1979, § 1-3; Code 1992, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines of sections. 
(a)  The catchlines of the sections of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of any section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any section, including its catchline, is amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the references and editor's notes scattered throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect. 
(Code 1979, § 1-4; Code 1992, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Interpretation of Code. 
    In all interpretations of this Code, and ordinances, the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the city council, keeping in view, at all times, the old law, the evil, and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate, and a transposition of words and clauses may be resorted to when the sentence or clause is without meaning as it stands. 
Sec. 1-6. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1979, § 1-5; Code 1992, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-7. - Effect of repeal of ordinance. 
(a)  No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance, whether or not such former ordinance is expressly repealed, as to any offense committed under such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment is mitigated by any provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(c)  This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provision upon the same subject or in any other ordinance. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this Code shall be construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the city herein repealed; or as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, or as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of adoption of this Code. 
(Code 1992, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-8. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contractor or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete; and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them in a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing sections or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1992, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-9. - General penalty. 
(a)  In this section, the term "violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation, or order" means any of the following: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code, or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(b)  Unless a higher penalty is otherwise specified, wherever in this Code, or in any ordinance or resolution of the city, or rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agent of the city under authority duly vested in such officer or agent, any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor and no specific penalty is provided for the violation thereof, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation, or order shall be punished by a fine not less than $1.00 and not exceeding $500.00 or by imprisonment at hard labor not exceeding six months, or both; provided, however, that any person found to be in violation of Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191, shall, upon conviction, be punished in accordance with the provisions set out in such Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191. Each day any violation of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Any person who is convicted under subsection (a) of this section shall be punished by fine, not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment at hard labor upon the streets or public works or in the workhouse or house of correction in the city, not exceeding six months, one or both; and in the event any fine or cost is not presently paid, the municipal judge shall sentence the offender, or person, thus in default to work out the fine and costs at hard labor upon the streets or public works or in the workhouse or house of correction of the city, and persons so sentenced to hard labor shall be allowed not less than $10.00 for each day's service so performed. 
(d)  Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city which is declared by a law of the state, now existing or hereafter enacted, to be an offense as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-1-2, which is not declared by a law of the state to be a felony, misdemeanor or violation, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 nor more than $500.00, and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to labor for the city for a period of not exceeding six months, at the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(e)  Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city which is declared by a law of the state, now existing or hereafter enacted, to be a violation shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 nor more than $200.00, and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to labor for the city for a period of not exceeding 30 days, or double the pecuniary gain to the defendant or loss to the victim as authorized in Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-5-12, at the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(f)  Any corporation found to be in violation shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00, nor more than $500.00, at the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(g)  In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this Code or of an ordinance, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense, provided that the revocation of a license or permit, or the abatement of a nuisance and the assessment of the cost thereof shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar the enforcement of any other penalty. 
(h)  No penalty shall consist of a fine or sentence of imprisonment exceeding the maximum fine and sentence established under state law for the commission of a substantially similar offense. 
(i)  Whenever a minimum, but not a maximum, fine or penalty is imposed, the court may in its discretion fine the offender the minimum or any sum exceeding the minimum fine or penalty so imposed, but not exceeding the maximum provided in this section. 
(j)  No provision of this Code or any ordinance designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. 
(Code 1979, §§ 1-6, 14-1; Code 1992, § 1-8; Ord. No. 83-21, §§ 1, 2, 8-16-1983; Ord. No. 2005-148, § 2, 7-11-2005) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to enforce obedience to ordinances by fine not exceeding $500.00 and by imprisonment or hard labor not exceeding six months, or both, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-45-1, 11-45-9; punishment for DUI up to $5,000.00 and one year in jail, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9; authority to abate nuisances, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-117, 11-47-118; municipal courts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1 et seq.; punishment, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 1-10. - Violation of orders, rules and regulations adopted. 
    Any person who shall violate, fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any lawful order of any lawful officer of the city made in pursuance of and under such officer's authority as such officer; or who shall violate, fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any of the codes, rules, regulations or laws adopted in this Code shall be guilty of an offense; provided, however, the provisions of this section shall not apply to violations of official duty imposed by this Code upon officers or employees of the city as such, unless the provision imposing the duty also expressly makes the violation thereof unlawful or punishable. 
(Code 1992, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-11. - Imprisonment in default of payment of fine. 
    If a fine is assessed against any party by a judge having jurisdiction over the matter, upon conviction under this Code or any of the ordinances of the city, and in the event the fines and costs are not then paid, the judge shall sentence the party so in default to work out the fines and costs under the direction of the city authorities, allowing not less than $15.00 for each day's service. 
(Code 1992, § 1-10) 
State Law reference- Authority, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-12; required credit, Ala. Rules of Criminal Procedure, Rule 26.11(i), found in Code of Ala. 1975, Vol. 23A. 
Sec. 1-12. - Payment of costs by city. 
    No part of the costs, or any of the fees due any officer in any case or proceeding for a violation of the city laws shall be taxed against or be paid by the city. 
(Code 1992, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-13. - Conflicts with technical codes. 
    In case of conflict between this Code of Ordinances and any technical code adopted herein by reference, the more restrictive provision shall apply. 
(Code 1992, § 1-12) 
Sec. 1-14. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful to change or amend by deletion any part of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with this Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1992, § 1-13) 
Sec. 1-15. - Substantive compliance with Code. 
    A substantial compliance with any requirement of the Code, or ordinances, especially on the part of public officers, shall be deemed and held sufficient, and no proceeding shall be declared void for want of such compliance, unless expressly so provided by the enactment. 
Sec. 1-16. - Prior offenses, penalties and rights not affected by adoption of Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty of forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as abating any action pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the city repealed in this chapter, and all general ordinances contained in this Code shall be deemed to be continuing and not a new enactment of the same ordinance. This chapter shall not be deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue or as affecting the liability of any person or as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or section thereof in force at the time of the adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-17. - Rates, charges and fees established. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided for, all rates, charges, or fees necessary for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this Code shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by motion, resolution or ordinance of the city council, from time to time. Any rates, charges, or fees established by the city pursuant to the regulations or requirements established herein may be changed from time to time by the city council, and such changes shall both be considered an amendment to this Code. 
(b)  Whenever any provision of this Code provides that a rate, charge, or fee shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and the amount of such rate, charge, or fee is not expressed in this Code in any dollar amount, then the amount of such rate, charge, or fee shall be the most recent and latest amount established, set or fixed by the city council by ordinance, resolution or motion. 
Sec. 1-18. - Ordinances, resolutions and activities not affected by Code. 
(a)  The adoption of this Code shall not repeal or otherwise affect any of the following: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty of forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; 
(3)  Any resolution not mentioned in the Code and not inconsistent with it; 
(4)  Any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(5)  Any ordinance prescribing zoning or subdivision regulations, or zoning particular property, or accepting any plat or subdivision; 
(6)  Any right or franchise granted by the city; 
(7)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(8)  Any appropriation or budget ordinance; 
(9)  Any administrative ordinance not mentioned in the Code and not inconsistent with it; 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat; 
(11)  Any ordinance levying any tax; 
(12)  Any ordinance establishing any board, commission or authority, not inconsistent with the Code; 
(13)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city or removing territory from the city; 
(14)  Any ordinance or resolution establishing metes and bounds descriptions for elections districts; 
(15)  Any ordinance or resolution of agreement with another political subdivision; 
(16)  Any ordinance or resolution establishing and/or prescribing employment, benefits, and/or personnel policies and procedures; 
(17)  Any ordinance or resolution establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; 
(18)  Adopting and incorporating by reference any maps, plans, diagrams and illustrations which are not published in this Code; 
(19)  Any ordinance or resolution establishing any traffic device, signal or marking, parking regulation, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones, speed limit or other limitation placed upon the use of any specific street for vehicles or pedestrians; and 
(20)  Any other ordinance or resolution, or part thereof, which is not of a general and permanent nature; or which is referred to elsewhere in this Code as continuing in effect. 
(b)  Nor shall the repeal of any such ordinance or resolution be construed to revive any ordinance, resolution or part thereof that has been repealed or superseded by a subsequent ordinance or resolution which is repealed or superseded by this chapter. All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1992, § 1-14) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- According to the U.S. Census Bureau, the 1970 census of population for the City of Madison, Alabama, was 3,086. Therefore, the city would have been classified as a Class 8 municipality at the time of enactment of Acts 1979, No. 79-263, p. 402, §§ 1, 3 (Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-40-12). 
State Law reference- Municipalities generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-40-1 et seq.; mayor and council form of government generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-1 et seq. 

Article VI. - Disability Board 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Governing body. 
    The city governing body shall consist of a mayor and seven councilmembers. 
(Code 1992, § 2-1; Ord. No. 88-10, § 1, 3-29-1988; Ord. No. 91-126, §§ 1, 2, 12-17-1991) 
Sec. 2-2. - District designation of council candidates. 
(a)  There are hereby established within the city seven districts, hereafter described, for the purpose of electing one member to the city council from each such district. 
(b)  The seven districts are described, by reference to census blocks, metes and bounds or other appropriate references. A copy of the metes and bounds descriptions of the election districts is on file in the city clerk's office, and available for public examination. 
(c)  Any person seeking election to the city council to represent any district described in subsection (b) of this section must reside within the boundaries of the district for a period of 90 days immediately preceding the date of the election, must be a qualified elector of the city, and must continue to reside in the district so long as such person remains a member of the council. 
(d)  Only electors residing within a district shall be entitled to vote for a candidate seeking election to represent that district; and in each district, election to the council shall require a majority of votes cast. If no candidate receives a majority in the general election in any particular district for a seat on the council, a run-off election between the two candidates who receive the most votes for the council seat will be held in that district, consistent with state law. 
(e)  Properly qualified candidates for mayor of the city shall be included on ballots in each of the seven districts and shall run at large. Election as mayor shall require a majority of all votes cast in the city. If no candidate for mayor receives a majority of the votes cast in the general election, a runoff election between the two candidates who receive the most votes for mayor will be held in the city at large, consistent with state law. 
(f)  Newly annexed areas annexed subsequent to the date of the 1990 Census shall be assigned to districts to which they are contiguous. 
(Code 1992, § 2-2; Ord. No. 88-10, §§ 2, 3, 3-29-1988; Ord. No. 91-126, §§ 1-6, 12-17-1991; Ord. No. 98-101, §§ 1-3, 3-26-1998; Ord. No. 2003-166, 8-25-2003) 
State Law reference- Election of mayor and councilmembers, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-43-2, 11-43-40; requirement that governing body designate certain municipal offices by number and that candidates run for a specific numbered office, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-46-22. 
Sec. 2-3. - Candidate qualification fee. 
    There is hereby fixed and established a qualification fee for all qualified candidates seeking office in a general municipal election, the same to be paid to the city clerk-treasurer at the time such candidate qualifies for the place, position or office to be filled. Such fee shall be paid into the general fund of the city and shall be used to defray the costs of holding such election; provided, however, that for any persons who are indigent, such qualifying fee shall be waived by the city clerk-treasurer upon the candidate completing an affidavit, under oath, of hardship, such form to be furnished by the city clerk-treasurer. The amount of the qualification fee shall be as established by the city council, from time to time. 
(Code 1992, § 2-3; Ord. No. 88-12, § 1, 4-26-1988) 
State Law reference- Authority of governing body of city to establish qualification fee for candidates for city office, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-46-2. 
Sec. 2-4. - Compensation and other benefits for elected officials-Mayor. 
(a)  The mayor shall receive as compensation for services as mayor such salary as the council may prescribe by ordinance not less than six months prior to the election of such mayor. 
(b)  The mayor shall be entitled to claim reimbursement for expenses up to that certain amount included in the annual budget adopted by the council, the same to be paid in accordance with actual expenses incurred. 
(c)  In addition to the compensation and expense allowance provided for as set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the mayor shall be entitled to all benefits which are available to other fulltime department heads of the city as provided by law, including, but not limited to, state retirement, social security and insurance. 
(Code 1992, § 2-4; Ord. No. 88-2, § 2, 2-16-1988) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipality to provide for compensation of elected officials, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-43-2, 11-43-6, 11-43-7, and 11-46-1. 
Sec. 2-5. - Same-Councilmembers. 
(a)  All members of the city council shall each receive such salary as the council may prescribe by ordinance not less than six months prior to the election of such members as compensation for their services on the city council. 
(b)  Each member of the city council shall be entitled to claim reimbursement for expenses up to that certain amount included in the annual budget adopted by the council, the same to be paid in accordance with actual expenses incurred. 
(Code 1992, § 2-5; Ord. No. 88-2, § 3, 2-16-1988) 
State Law reference- Fixing of salaries, etc., of councilmembers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-6. 
Sec. 2-6. - Conflicts of interests. 
    No councilmember or other officer, or any employee, elected or appointed by the council, shall be interested, directly or indirectly, in any contract, or the profits thereof, for work, material or service to be furnished or performed for the city; and no councilmember or regular employee holding employment under civil service regulations shall be interested in or an employee of any corporation operating any public service utility or common carrier within the city; provided, that this shall not apply to any employment or interest existing at the time of selection or election of such employee or councilmember. Any person violating any provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor, and any elective officer violating this section shall be guilty of malfeasance in office, and shall be punished as provided by the laws of the state. Any elective officer of the city shall be punished as provided by the laws of the state. Any elective officer of the city shall be subject to all the pains and penalties and enjoy all the privileges and immunities as provided by the constitution and general laws of the state applicable to such elected officers. 
(Code 1979, § 2-9; Code 1992, § 2-7; Ord. No. 92-127, 9-22-1992) 
Secs. 2-7-2-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- City council proceedings, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-43-48, 11-43-49, 11-43-50, 11-43-51, and 11-43-52. 

Sec. 2-35. - Reorganizational meetings. 
    At any regular meeting of the city council, the council may call for a special reorganizational meeting by a vote of two-thirds of the councilmembership. A special reorganizational meeting may then be conducted on at least 24 hours' notice. A majority vote of the councilmembership will prevail at that meeting. The procedures for a reorganizational meeting will be the same as the procedures for the election of officers and annual organization provided in this article. 
(Code 1992, § 2-20; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 1, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 1, 11-3-2008; Ord. No. 2012-82, § 1, 4-26-2012) 
Sec. 2-36. - Council president. 
    The council president will be elected by a majority vote of the council at the first council meeting in November and shall serve a one-year term unless earlier removed at a reorganizational meeting held in accordance with section 2-35. The president may be elected to successive terms as council president. 
(Code 1992, § 2-21; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 2, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 2, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-37. - Duties and responsibilities of council president. 
(a)  The president will serve as the presiding officer at meetings of the council, rule on points of order during meetings, call special meetings, sign ordinances or resolutions adopted by the council, and exercise such other powers and responsibilities assigned by law or ordinance to the president. 
(b)  The president will appoint all council committee positions and department liaisons, the appointment of which is not otherwise provided by law or ordinance, for one-year terms coinciding with the term of the president. 
(c)  The president of the council will coordinate the council office staff and the administrative operations of the council. 
(d)  The president of the council will represent the council at official and civic functions as requested. If the president is unable to attend, the president pro tempore shall attend in the president's place as representative of the council. If both the president and president pro tempore are unable to attend, then other councilmembers shall be contacted, in order of seniority if possible, until a replacement representative is available. 
(e)  The president of the council shall sign and approve all documents and have responsibility and authority over council staff as exercised by other department heads. In the case of purchase requisitions and expenditures by councilmembers, a simple majority vote of the council may override approval or disapproval of the council president. 
(f)  The president shall serve as acting mayor as necessary in the absence of the mayor and shall succeed to the office of mayor for the unexpired term in the event of any vacancy in that office. See Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-42. 
(g)  Should the council vote to go into executive session pursuant to the Alabama Open Meetings Act, § 36-25A-1 et seq., as last amended, the council president shall state for the record and the public the approximate time at which the council will reconvene. 
(Code 1992, § 2-22; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 3, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 3, 11-3-2008; Ord. No. 2012-82, § 2, 4-26-2012) 
Sec. 2-38. - Council president pro tempore. 
    The president pro tempore of the council, elected by a majority vote of the council, shall serve a one-year term unless earlier removed from that office at a reorganizational meeting held in accordance with section 2-35. The president pro tempore may be elected to successive terms as president pro tempore. 
(Code 1992, § 2-23; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 4, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 4, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-39. - Duties and responsibilities of president pro tempore. 
    The president pro tempore shall perform all duties of the president of the council in the absence of the council president and shall exercise such other powers and responsibilities assigned by law or ordinance to the office. In the event of any vacancy in the office of president, the president pro tempore shall succeed to the office of president for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1992, § 2-24; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 5, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 5, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-40. - Number of meetings. 
(a)  Required. As soon as the president and president pro tempore have been elected, the city council will then be considered as organized for the transaction of business as the city council. After the organizational meeting, the council will meet at least twice in each month for the transaction of the business of the city and will meet more often if required by the president of the council. Special meetings shall be called as provided in Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-50. 
(b)  Special and emergency meetings. Special meetings may be held at the call of the council president whenever in his opinion the public interest may require it or by any two councilmembers or the mayor in writing, pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-50. Notice of all special meetings shall be posted on a bulletin board accessible to the public at least 24 hours prior to such meeting. Exceptions shall be made only in the following circumstances and in these cases notice shall be posted at least one hour prior to the meeting: 
(1)  Notice cannot be given due to an emergency requiring immediate action to avoid physical injury to persons or damage to property; or 
(2)  The meeting is held solely to accept the resignation of a public official or employee. 
(Code 1992, § 2-25; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 6, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, §§ 6, 7, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-41. - Time of meetings. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the city council will meet for business on the second and fourth Monday in each month and may continue from day to day until the business is finished. The meetings will commence at 6:00 p.m. in the official chambers of the city council or at any other place designated by the council. The council will meet in informal work sessions at 5:30 p.m. prior to its regular council meetings, as deemed necessary, and at such other times and places as it may direct after posting notice. All such work sessions will be open to the public. 
(Code 1992, § 2-26; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 7, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 7, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-42. - Rules governing city council procedure. 
    For the orderly transaction of the public business, the following rules are adopted for the government of the city council: 
(1)  The president of the council will establish and make public an agenda prior to any meeting thereof. The president of the council will establish a deadline for submission of items for inclusion on the agenda. Once that deadline has passed, no item will be added to the official agenda unless said addition is approved by the council president. Items not on the official agenda established by the president may be added for consideration upon the consent of a majority of the council. Items can be offered for introduction at any time during a regular council meeting. If so requested, items proposed to be added will be approved by a majority vote of the council. A change in the order of agenda items may be made by the president or by request of a simple majority of the councilmembers present. 
(2)  At the appointed hour, the presiding officer of the city council shall take the chair and call the council to order if a quorum is present. A majority of the councilmembership shall constitute a quorum. 
(3)  If the president is absent, the president pro tempore will act as the president and if both the president and the president pro tempore are absent, the chairperson of the finance committee will preside. If all three are absent, the councilmembers present will select one of the members present to preside at the meeting, with the clerk presiding over the selection of the presiding officer of the meeting. 
(4)  At all meetings, business shall be taken up and disposed of generally in the following order. The council president may adjust the format from time to time, as deemed necessary, to provide for the orderly conduct of council business. 
a.  Call to order. 
b.  Invocation and Pledge of Allegiance. 
c.  Roll call of elected governing officials. 
d.  Approval of minutes. 
e.  Presentations and awards. 
f.  Public comments. 
g.  Consent agenda and finance committee report (regular and periodic bills to be paid). 
h.  Presentation of reports of mayor, councilmembers, committees, etc. 
i.  Departmental reports. 
j.  Other business and announcements. 
k.  Adjournment. 
(5)  Except as provided herein, the council will adhere to the procedural rules contained in the latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order. 
(6)  The council president will preserve order and decorum in the transaction of business during each sitting of the council, and on points of order may speak in preference to any councilmember. The president of the council will decide all questions of order, but an appeal may be made from his decision and such appeal shall be decided without debate by majority vote. 
(7)  If a councilmember violates any rule, in speaking or otherwise, the president of the council or any councilmember may call him to order. 
(8)  When two or more councilmembers speak at the same time, the president of the council will decide who is entitled to speak. 
(9)  No member will speak more than twice on the same subject without the permission of the council president. 
(10)  The council will not hear public comment on formally filed claims or lawsuits. Whenever the city attorney advises the council that a matter presented to the council or to any councilmember, whether verbally or in writing, should, in the opinion of the city attorney, remain confidential, the council shall abide by the request of the city attorney and shall refrain from any public comment, discussion, or dissemination of information with regard thereto. 
(11)  When a verbal motion is made, the president of the council will state it. If the motion is in writing, the clerk will read it. Motions will be reduced to writing when requested by any member of the council. When a motion is stated or read, the president of the council will submit the motion to the vote of the council. 
(12)  When an amendment is offered and seconded, the vote on the amendment will be taken. If the vote on the amendment is successful, then a vote will be taken on the motion, as amended. If the amendment fails, then the original motion will be put to a vote. 
(13)  A motion to adjourn is always in order and will be decided without second or any debate. 
(14)  The previous question will have precedence over all motions (except a motion to adjourn and a motion to lay on the table) and, if sustained by a two-thirds vote of the council, will preclude all debate and all amendments. 
(15)  Any ordinance or resolution presented to the council for consideration or action must be in writing. 
(16)  Discussion or debate on any matter may be limited to a prescribed time upon majority vote of the council. Discussion or debate of matters under consideration by the council will generally be limited to members of the council, city staff, and consultants. Members of the public may request permission, however, to speak to an issue then under consideration and may speak to the issue if permitted to do so by the council president or a majority vote of the council. Public discussion or debate permitted under this rule will be limited to three minutes per speaker unless otherwise directed by the council president or a majority of the council. Rebuttal to public comment by members of the public, with a three-minute limit, may be permitted at the discretion of the council president or a majority vote of the council. The foregoing rule will not apply to public comment permitted under subsection (17) of this section. 
(17)  Members of the public may request that the city clerk include them on the public comment portion of the official agenda by the established deadline. The deadline for inclusion on the agenda for public comments is hereby set as close of business on the Tuesday prior to the council meeting. Those making a timely request may be allowed to address the council for up to five minutes or for such longer time as allowed by the council president or a majority of the council. Comment from members of the public who have not been listed on the official agenda may be permitted and shall be limited to three minutes each or for such longer time as allowed by the council president or a majority of the council. 
(18)  Any councilmember, having voted with the majority on any question, may move for a reconsideration of the question at that meeting or at the next meeting of the council. 
(19)  No ordinance or resolution intended to be of permanent operation shall be adopted by the council at the same meeting at which it is introduced unless unanimous consent of those present is given for a suspension of the rules to allow for the immediate consideration of such ordinance or resolution. No ordinance or resolution intended to be of permanent operation shall become law unless, on its final passage, a majority of the members elected to the council vote in its favor. 
(20)  A councilmember may or may not vote on any item at his option, except as prohibited by law. See Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-54. Any councilmember may request that another member state publicly the reason for his vote on any matter. 
(21)  For all votes of the council, the clerk shall record the "yeas" and "nays." 
(22)  Any member of the council has the right to have his protest to the passage of any measure entered on the minutes, provided that it is made in respectful language, of which the council president will be the judge. 
(23)  Nothing will be introduced as a rider or as a condition or qualification to any ordinance unless the same shall be pertinent to the subject of the ordinance. 
(24)  A majority of any committee of the council shall be sufficient to make a recommendation to the council. 
(25)  The president of the council may, at his discretion, call any member to take the chair temporarily to allow the president to address the council, make a motion, or discuss any other matter at issue. 
(26)  If any councilmember willfully violates any of these rules, he shall suffer such censure as the council may direct. Any censure must be approved by a two-thirds vote of the remaining councilmembers. Censure may include a fine, public criticism, and/or admonition. 
(27)  If any vacancy should occur in the office of mayor, then such vacancy will be filled in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-42. Vacancies in the office of councilmember will be filled in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-4. 
(28)  The clerk-treasurer, city attorney, city engineer, chief of police, fire chief, and such other officers or employees of the city, when requested by the mayor or council president, shall attend meetings of the council and shall remain in attendance for such length of time as the council may direct. 
(29)  Every officer whose duty it is to report at the regular meetings of the council, and who is in default thereof, may be fined at the discretion of the council. 
(30)  All meetings of the council shall be open to the public, except when the council meets in executive session as authorized by state law. When a councilmember makes a motion to go into executive session for a stated purpose and the motion is seconded, the council president shall put the motion to a vote. If the majority of the council votes in favor of the motion, the body will then move into executive session to discuss the matter for which the executive session was called. No action or any vote shall be taken in an executive session. Discussion in the executive session shall be limited to the purpose for which it was called. When the discussion of such matters has been completed, the council shall return from the executive session and upon a majority vote shall resume its public session. The council may then resume or conclude deliberations or take such action as appropriate. 
(31)  The rules of the council may be temporarily suspended by a vote of two-thirds of the members present. 
(Code 1992, § 2-27; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 8, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 8, 11-3-2008; Ord. No. 2012-82, § 3, 4-26-2012) 
Sec. 2-43. - Transmittal or recall of ordinances or resolutions to mayor; publication by clerk. 
(a)  All resolutions or ordinances intended to be of permanent operation, after having been passed by the council, shall be transmitted by the clerk within 48 hours after passage to the mayor for consideration. To approve said resolutions or ordinances, the mayor shall sign them and return them to the clerk, who shall publish them. Unless otherwise stated, resolutions or ordinances shall be effective upon approval by the mayor, except that ordinances requiring publication shall be effective when published. The council, however, may provide in a resolution or ordinance that it shall be effective at some other time if permitted by law. 
(b)  The council may recall an ordinance or resolution from the mayor at any time before it has become a law or has been acted on by the mayor. To recall an ordinance or resolution, the council must adopt a recall resolution by a majority of all members of the council. 
(Code 1992, § 2-28; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 9, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 9, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-44. - Veto on ordinances and resolutions; passage over veto. 
    If the mayor disapproves of any resolution or ordinance transmitted to him, the mayor shall, within ten calendar days of the time of its passage by the council, return it to the clerk with written objections. The clerk shall report the mayor's veto at the next regular meeting of the city council. At that time, if two-thirds of the members of the council shall adhere to said resolution or ordinance, notwithstanding the mayor's veto, then such resolution or ordinance shall have the force of law after publication, unless by its term it was to take effect on its approval, in which event it shall take effect upon its passage over the mayor's veto. The failure of the mayor to return to the clerk a resolution or ordinance with the mayor's veto within ten calendar days of its passage by the council shall operate and have the same effect as an approval of the same, and the clerk shall then publish the same, if publication is required by law. 
(Code 1992, § 2-29; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 10, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 10, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-45. - Passage over veto on ordinances and resolutions fixing salaries of officers and employees. 
    Ordinances or resolutions fixing salaries of employees and officers of the city shall be submitted to the mayor as other ordinances and resolutions are to be submitted, but may be approved in part and vetoed as to specific items, as stated in the mayor's veto message. In the case of the veto of specific items and approval of the remainder of said ordinance or resolution by the mayor, the clerk, at the next regular meeting of the council, shall present the mayor's veto to the council with the question, "Shall the ordinance (or resolution) pass, the veto of the mayor notwithstanding?" If two-thirds of the members of the council do not vote for the passage of said ordinance or resolution, the veto notwithstanding, then the clerk shall submit to the council the following question: "Shall the ordinance stand as approved by the mayor?" If a majority of the members of the council vote in the affirmative to that question, the law as amended and approved by the mayor shall have the force and effect of law; otherwise such salary resolution or ordinance shall be defeated. 
(Code 1992, § 2-30; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 11, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 11, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-46. - Organization and appointment of finance committee. 
(a)  At the November organizational meeting of the council, the council will appoint three members of the council to serve as the finance committee. The president of the council will then designate one member of the committee to serve as chairperson and one member of the committee to serve as vice chairperson. The president of the council shall not serve on the finance committee. 
(b)  Each member of the finance committee shall provide a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $25,000.00 executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the state. The city shall pay the premium for the bond. The bond shall be payable to and for the use and benefit of the city and conditioned upon the faithful discharge of duties by members of the finance committee. The bonds shall be deposited with the city clerk. 
(Code 1992, § 2-31; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 12, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 12, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-47. - Composition and duties of finance committee. 
    The chairperson of the committee will appoint such other city employees to the committee that he deems necessary to fulfill the responsibilities of the committee, provided the committee will not have more than five members. The finance committee shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Supervision of revenues and income. The finance committee shall have in their charge and under their supervision all revenues and income of the city arising from any and all sources whatsoever. 
(2)  Examination of accounts and transactions. The finance committee shall examine all the accounts and transactions of every officer of the city who has the power and whose duty it is to collect or receive any money coming from any and all sources of revenue. 
(3)  Duties of committee on examination of accounts and transactions; report to council. The finance committee, upon investigation of the accounts and transactions of any officer, shall examine all the receipts and vouchers for the payment of the money received by the officer, show how much he has paid, to whom paid, and when paid, the purpose of the payment, and thus show if such officer has faithfully paid over all the money received, and make a report to the next council meeting showing these facts. They shall ascertain from all sources of information whether or not there is any money still due to the city and uncollected, and from whom and on what account due. 
(4)  Questions regarding finances. Any question regarding finances may be directed by the council to the finance committee for a recommendation or a report to the council. 
(Code 1992, § 2-32; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 13, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 13, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-48. - Amendment to organizational ordinance. 
    The rules of the council contained herein may be amended in the same manner as any other ordinance of general and permanent operation. 
(Code 1992, § 2-33; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 14, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 14, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-49. - Statutory precedence. 
    Anything not specifically provided herein shall be governed by Chapter 43, Title 11, Code of Ala. 1975, or other applicable Class 8 or general legislation. 
(Code 1992, § 2-34; Ord. No. 2005-242, § 15, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 2008-283, § 15, 11-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-50. - Approval of city council for bylaws or operating rules of ad hoc committees. 
(a)  The provisions of this section shall apply to all existing ad hoc committees and other certain boards and committees not set up by state statute, to wit: 
(1)  Education committee. 
(2)  Recreation advisory committee. 
(3)  Senior citizens center committee. 
(4)  Archives and records. 
(5)  Cemetery committee. 
(6)  Committee on animal issues. 
(7)  Beautification board. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall apply to ad hoc committees created or appointed by the city hereafter. 
(c)  No bylaws or similar operating policies or rules, or amendment thereto, of any board or committee, as to which this resolution is applicable, shall be effective until the same are submitted to and approved by city council. 
(Code 1992, § 2-36; Res. No. 93-68-R, §§ 1-3, 5-25-1993; Ord. No. 2005-242, 10-10-2005) 
Secs. 2-51-2-73. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY CLERK-TREASURER; TAX COLLECTOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to establish the salary of officers and employees of the city, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-43-7, 11-43-8. 

Sec. 2-74. - City clerk-treasurer-Establishment of office. 
    The offices of city clerk and city treasurer, as created under state law, are hereby combined into one office to be known as the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1992, § 2-40; Ord. No. 92-153, § 1, 10-27-1992) 
State Law reference- Authority of mayor and city council to consolidate two or more city offices, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-3. 
Sec. 2-75. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall be appointed and shall serve in accordance with duties imposed on the office of the city clerk and city treasurer by state law and by other ordinances and resolutions of the city, and in accordance with the job description approved by council resolution for this position. 
(Code 1992, § 2-41; Ord. No. 92-153, § 2, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 94-92, § 1, 7-1-1994; Ord. No. 94-137, § 1, 10-18-1994; Ord. No. 2005-56, § 2, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 2008-373, § 2, 12-22-2008) 
Sec. 2-76. - Same-Term. 
    The person appointed to the city clerk-treasurer position shall be appointed for a term that runs concurrent with the term of the mayor, provided, however, that the city clerk-treasurer may be subject to removal for cause pursuant to the city's personnel ordinances, and otherwise, the city clerk-treasurer may continue to serve at the end of the term until a successor is elected and qualified. 
(Code 1992, § 2-42; Ord. No. 92-153, § 3, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 94-92, § 2, 7-1-1994; Ord. No. 94-137, § 2, 10-18-1994; Ord. No. 2005-56, § 3, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 2008-373, § 3, 12-22-2008) 
Sec. 2-77. - Same-Salary. 
    The annual salary of the city clerk-treasurer is established at $75,000.00; provided, however, that the occupant of said office shall receive such general or across-the-board increases as provided by the city council to all other employees of the city. Merit increases given by the mayor must be specifically approved by the city council and subject to the maximum salary limitations established for said position by council resolution. 
(Code 1992, § 2-43; Ord. No. 92-153, § 4, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 94-92, § 3, 7-1-1994; Ord. No. 94-136, § 3, 10-11-1994; Ord. No. 94-137, § 3, 10-18-1994; Ord. No. 2005-56, § 1, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 2008-373, § 1, 12-22-2008) 
Sec. 2-78. - Same-Bond. 
    For the faithful performance of official duties, the city clerk-treasurer shall make bond with surety to be approved by the mayor in the sum of $100,000.00, the premiums of which are to be paid from the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 2-44; Ord. No. 92-153, § 5, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 94-92, § 4, 7-1-1994) 
Sec. 2-79. - Same-Indemnification. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall be indemnified and held harmless as to personal liability by the city for actions taken in an official capacity when such actions are in accord with the policies and procedures established by law and by this council. 
(Code 1992, § 2-45; Ord. No. 92-153, § 6, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 94-92, § 5, 7-1-1994; Ord. No. 94-137, § 4, 10-18-1994) 
Sec. 2-80. - Same-Election. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall be elected by a majority vote of the council. 
(Code 1992, § 2-46; Ord. No. 92-153, § 7, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 94-92, § 6, 7-1-1994; Ord. No. 94-137, § 5, 10-18-1994; Ord. No. 2008-373, § 4, 12-22-2008) 
Sec. 2-81. - Tax collector-Establishment of office. 
    The office of tax collector is hereby established as provided for under Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-5. 
(Code 1992, § 2-49; Code 1979, § 2-20; Ord. No. 89-51, § II, 10-18-1989) 
Sec. 2-82. - Same-Election; setting salary and term. 
    The tax collector shall be elected by a majority vote of the council. The council shall fix the salary and term of office of the tax collector, who shall serve until a successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1992, § 2-50; Code 1979, § 2-21; Ord. No. 89-51, § II, 10-18-1989) 
Sec. 2-83. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The tax collector shall have powers and duties imposed upon the office of the tax collector by state law, the provisions of this Code and other ordinances and resolutions of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 2-22; Code 1992, § 2-51; Ord. No. 89-51, § II, 10-18-1989) 
Sec. 2-84. - Same-Bond. 
    For the faithful performance of official duties, the tax collector shall make bond with surety to be approved by the mayor in such penalty as council may prescribe, the premiums of which are to be paid from the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 2-23; Code 1992, § 2-52; Ord. No. 89-51, § II, 10-18-1989) 
Secs. 2-85-2-127. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS 

Sec. 2-128. - General powers. 
    Such persons as may be designated by the mayor and sworn to service by the municipal judge of the city hereby are empowered to enforce by issuance of citations, notices of violations and other lawful means, all ordinances and codes of the city in accordance with municipal and state laws related to the issuance of such legal process. 
(Code 1992, § 2-60; Ord. No. 90-62, § I, 8-14-1990) 
Sec. 2-129. - Specific powers. 
    The authority of the code enforcement officers shall specifically include, but not be limited to, enforcement of planning and zoning ordinances, ordinances concerning maintenance of property and buildings, ordinances related to lawful licensure and operation of businesses or occupations, ordinances related to the health, safety and welfare of the public, and ordinances related to implementation, operation, protection or preservation of public utilities, property or recreational facilities. 
(Code 1992, § 2-61; Ord. No. 90-62, § I, 8-14-1990) 
Sec. 2-130. - Restrictions on powers. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 2-128 and 2-129, however, it is not the intent of this council to empower the code enforcement officer to engage in the issuance of motor vehicle or traffic citations, except to the extent as to enforce laws related to abandoned vehicles or illegal parking and storage of vehicles as may be governed by the zoning ordinance, as amended; nor to make any custodial arrests or to engage in enforcement of penal or criminal laws of this city or state, the violation of which constitutes a misdemeanor or felony. 
(Code 1992, § 2-62; Ord. No. 90-62, § I, 8-14-1990) 
Secs. 2-131-2-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-161-2-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BEAUTIFICATION BOARD 

Sec. 2-186. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established in the city a board to be known as the beautification/tree board of the city ("the board"), to be composed of not less than five nor more than 15 members, and for the purpose of this division, to be known as the "board". 
(Code 1992, § 16-10; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 2, 10-28-2002) 
Sec. 2-187. - Terms of members. 
    Two members of the board shall be appointed by majority vote of the city council and shall serve for two years. The remaining members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor to serve for a term of one year, two years, or three years, as the mayor shall designate. After the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives, the members then serving on the beautification board authorized by Ordinance No. 2000-219 shall be permitted to complete the terms to which they are then appointed, and shall be eligible for reappointment pursuant to the terms of this division. 
(Code 1992, § 16-11; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 3, 10-28-2002) 
Sec. 2-188. - Qualification of members. 
    No person shall be eligible to serve on the board who is not a bona fide resident citizen of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 16-12; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 4, 10-28-2002) 
Sec. 2-189. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the board shall be filled by appointment as defined in section 2-187. Appointments to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired term. An appointee shall cease to be a member upon resignation to the mayor, upon ceasing to be a resident of the city, upon removal by the member's appointing authority for failure to attend at least three consecutive regularly scheduled meetings, or upon expiration of the term to which they are appointed. 
(Code 1992, § 16-13; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 5, 10-28-2002) 
Sec. 2-190. - Organization and meetings. 
    The board shall hold regular meetings at such time and place within the city as it may from time to time determine; provided, however, that the board shall hold at least one regular or one special meeting every 90 days. The board shall adopt bylaws providing for its own administration, quorum requirements, officers, and other matters not inconsistent with this division. 
(Code 1992, § 16-14; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 6, 10-28-2002) 
Sec. 2-191. - Subcommittees. 
    The board may, by simple majority vote, establish such subcommittees and advisory bodies as it sees fit. Such bodies may be advisory only, and shall have no power to act in the place of the board, nor shall they expend board funds without a vote of the board. Such bodies shall report their work to the full board, which shall take any official action on such work as they deem appropriate. The board may, however, delegate the administration of one or more of its programs (e.g., Adopt-A-Mile) to such a subcommittee, and authorize the expenditure of funds by the subcommittee for that purpose. 
(Code 1992, § 16-15; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 7, 10-28-2002) 
Sec. 2-192. - Reimbursements. 
    The members of the board shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the performance of their duty; provided, however, such expenses do not exceed $50.00, except as authorized by a vote of the board. 
(Code 1992, § 16-16; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 8, 10-28-2002) 
Sec. 2-193. - Funding. 
    Funding for the board and its projects may be derived from the general fund of the city. The board is also authorized to hold plant sales and conduct other similar fundraising events with the proceeds accruing to the board. Members are encouraged to procure funding through volunteer projects and fundraisers and the solicitations of donations and grants made specifically to the board. The city council shall make an annual appropriation to the board in the amount that they deem fit. 
(Code 1992, § 16-17; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 9, 10-28-2002) 
Sec. 2-194. - Powers and duties. 
    The board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To study and make recommendations to the mayor and city council in matters concerning the landscaping and beautification of public places and around public buildings within the city. 
(2)  To study, report and make recommendations regarding such matters and projects as may be referred to them by the mayor, the city council, or any other board or agency of the city, and to oversee such projects when authorized by the mayor. 
(3)  To encourage through mass media the various civic and governmental organizations of the city, including city schools, the initiation and execution by civic clubs and associations, merchants, and property owners associations, programs to enhance the cleanliness and beautification of the city and its environs. 
(4)  To counsel with governmental agencies and private individuals when requested to do so on matters and things concerning the cleanliness and beautification of the city and its environs. 
(5)  To counsel with nurseries, garden shops, landscaping establishments, garden clubs, and private developers on a voluntary basis, for the purpose of encouraging a comprehensive, coordinated, program for the beautification of private and public premises within the city. 
(6)  To encourage litter control and cleanliness projects within the city through a "Pride of Madison" program, including, but not limited to "Adopt-A-Mile", "Adopt-A-Park" and "Adopt-A-Spot", and to recognize those efforts on an annual basis. 
(7)  To encourage the landscaping and maintenance of public and private properties within the city and to recognize those efforts on an annual basis through a beautification awards program. 
(8)  To function in its capacity as the city tree board, charged with the implementation and enforcement of any and all provisions of this division and any ordinances relating to the preservation and maintenance of trees within the city and its environs as may from time to time be adopted by the council. 
(9)  To perform such other and additional duties as the council may from time to time require. 
(10)  No power or duty listed herein shall be interpreted as granting this board supervisory powers over any department or agency of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 16-18; Ord. No. 2002-193, § 10, 10-28-2002) 
Secs. 2-195-2-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TREE BOARD 

Sec. 2-216. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Park trees means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
    Street trees means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
(Code 1992, § 16-52; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 1, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-217. - City tree board. 
(a)  Creation and establishment. The Madison Beautification Board is hereby designated as the city tree board ("the board") and shall in that capacity be charged with the implementation and enforcement of this division. The board may be assisted by city staff as directed by the mayor. 
(b)  Term of office. The terms of the members of the beautification board shall be determined by operation of section 2-186 through and including section 2-189. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities. It shall be the responsibility of the board to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be consistent with and further the purposes of the comprehensive plan of the city. The plan shall be presented annually to the city council and upon their acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. The board, when requested by the city council, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Code 1992, § 16-53; Ord. No. 2000-103, §§ 2-4, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-218. - Street tree species to be planted. 
    The following list constitutes the official street tree species for the city. No species other than those included in this list may be planted as street trees without written permission of the city tree board.

(Code 1992, § 16-54; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 5, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-219. - Spacing. 
    The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the species size classes listed in section 2-218 and no trees may be planted closer together than the following: small trees, 30 feet; large trees, 50 feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. 
(Code 1992, § 16-55; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 6, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-220. - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
    The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the species size classes listed in section 2-218, and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following: small trees, two feet; large trees, four feet. 
(Code 1992, § 16-56; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 7, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-221. - Distance from street corners and fireplugs. 
    No street tree shall be planted within 35 feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No street tree shall be planted within ten feet of any fireplug. 
(Code 1992, § 16-57; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 8, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-222. - Utilities. 
    No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 2-218 may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Code 1992, § 16-58; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 9, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-223. - Public tree care. 
(a)  The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
(b)  The city tree board may remove or cause or order to be removed from public property any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and locations of said trees is in accordance with sections 2-218 through 2-222. 
(Code 1992, § 16-59; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 10, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-224. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this provision at the determination of the city tree board. 
(Code 1992, § 16-59.1; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 11, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-225. - Pruning. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection or traffic control sign or signal, and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs that constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with the visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(Code 1992, § 16-59.2; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 12, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-226. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
    The presence of a dead tree or trees on private property shall constitute a nuisance under section 2-227. Enforcement action shall be taken in accordance with sections 2-228 through 2-230. 
(Code 1992, § 16-59.3; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 13, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-227. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Code 1992, § 16-59.4; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 14, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-228. - Interference with city tree board. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this division. 
(Code 1992, § 16-59.5; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 15, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-229. - Arborists license and bond. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street or park trees within the city without first applying for and procuring a license. However, no license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work within the normal scope of their duties. 
(Code 1992, § 16-59.6; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 16, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-230. - Review by city council. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the city tree board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree board to the city council, who may hear the matter and make a final decision. 
(Code 1992, § 16-59.7; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 17, 6-26-2000) 
Secs. 2-231-2-255. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-256. - Creation. 
    The recreation advisory board for the city was created and established on October 15, 1992. 
(Code 1992, § 16-90; Res. No. 92-141-R, § 1, 10-14-1992; Res. No. 2005-14-R, § 1, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 2010-51-R, § 1, 3-8-2010) 
Sec. 2-257. - Composition. 
(a)  Membership on the board shall consist of the following: 
(1)  The president, or program-member designee of the president, of each of the following recognized sports programs in the city shall sit as a voting ex officio member: 
a.  Madison Baseball Association. 
b.  Madison Softball League. 
c.  Madison Dolphin Swim Team.
