d.  Basketball Association of Madison. 
e.  AYSO Soccer Region 498. 
f.  Madison Youth Football and Cheer. 
g.  Madison Greenways and Trails. 
h.  Madison City Volleyball. 
Each of the board members serving hereunder shall be a legal resident of the city for the entire term of his membership on the board. 
(2)  Two additional at-large voting members appointed by the city council, at least one of whom shall be a senior citizen and each of whom shall be a legal resident of the city for the entire term of his membership on the board. 
(3)  One at-large voting member appointed by the mayor who shall be a legal resident of the city for the entire term of his membership on the board. 
(4)  The following non-voting ex officio members or their respective designees: 
a.  Director of Madison Parks and Recreation. 
b.  Member of Madison City Council. 
c.  Member of Madison City School Board. 
d.  Director of Madison Senior Center. 
e.  Chairperson of the Madison City Disability Advocacy Board. 
(b)  The city council may amend the membership of the board from time to time as it finds appropriate and in the best interests of the city. When an amendment to the membership is made, the council will designate if the new member is to be a voting or non-voting member and what the term of the position will be. 
(Code 1992, § 16-91; Res. No. 92-141-R, § 2, 10-14-1992; Res. No. 2005-14-R, § 2, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 2010-51-R, §§ 2, 3, 3-8-2010; Ord. No. 2014-76, § 1, 5-12-2014) 
Sec. 2-258. - Term. 
(a)  The member (or his designee) serving under section 2-257(a)(1) shall serve for his term of office as president of the recognized sports program which he represents unless he (or the designee, as applicable) ceases to be a legal resident of the city. 
(b)  Members appointed under section 2-257(a)(2) shall serve staggered three-year terms, the first three appointees having been appointed initially for a one-year term, a two-year term, and a three-year term, respectively. All appointments made thereafter shall be for three-year terms or, in the event the terms of office for these positions become unevenly spaced, the council may adjust new appointments accordingly until the originally intended schedule of appointment is restored. At-large members appointed under section 2-257(a)(2) may be reappointed at the will of the city council. 
(c)  The member appointed under section 2-257(a)(3) shall serve a three-year term and may be reappointed at the will of the mayor. 
(d)  A member serving under section 2-257(a)(4) shall serve for his term of appointment or employment in his particular position. 
(e)  Those members designated in section 2-257 as non-voting shall be entitled to engage in discussion and debate with other members of the board but are not authorized to cast votes in favor of or in opposition to any motion presented for consideration by the board. 
(Code 1992, § 16-92; Res. No. 92-141-R, § 3, 10-14-1992; Res. No. 2005-14-R, § 3, 2-14-2005; Res. No. 2010-51-R, § 4, 3-8-2010; Ord. No. 2014-76, § 2, 5-12-2014) 
Sec. 2-259. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The recreation advisory board shall have the duty and responsibility to meet periodically to review and evaluate available sports programs of the city and to make recommendations to the city council for funding, improvements, changes, enhancements, expansion, or other modifications or additions to available sports programs in the city. The role of the board shall be advisory in nature only. Full responsibility for the direction, control, management and supervision of the parks and recreation department shall remain with the parks and recreation director under the supervision of the mayor. 
(Code 1992, § 16-93; Res. No. 92-141-R, § 4, 10-14-1992; Res. No. 2005-14-R, § 4, 2-15-2005; Ord. No. 2010-51-R, § 5, 3-8-2010) 
Secs. 2-260-2-275. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DISABILITY BOARD 

Sec. 2-276. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the establishment of an advisory board which strives to affect positive change in persons with physical or mental impairments that substantially limit one or more major life activities. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 1, 3-9-2009) 
Sec. 2-277. - Name. 
    There is hereby created and established in the city, a board to be known as the Madison City Disability Advocacy Board (hereinafter referred to as "the board"). 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 2, 3-9-2009) 
Sec. 2-278. - Membership. 
(a)  The board shall be composed of nine voting members. As set forth in Table 2-278, three members of the board shall be appointed by majority vote of the city council and six members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(b)  Except for those serving an interim term according to Table 2-278, members shall serve two-year terms. 
(c)  All members serving as of May 1, 2014, shall be deemed to have been appointed to an interim term which shall expire according to the dates set forth in Table 2-278. 
(d)  For any place requiring an appointment between May 1, 2014, and that place's expiration date set forth in Table 2-278, such appointment shall be made for an interim term which shall expire according to the dates set forth in Table 2-278, even if adherence thereto results in an appointment of more than two years. 
Table 2-278 
Place Number Residency Required Appointing 
Authority Interim Term 
Expiration 1 Yes Mayor 12-31-14 2 Yes Mayor 12-31-14 3 Yes Mayor 12-31-14 4 Yes Mayor 12-31-15 5 No Council 12-31-15 6 Yes Mayor 12-31-15 7 Yes Council 12-31-16 8 No Mayor 12-31-16 9 No Council 12-31-16  
(e)  Upon the expiration of each of the interim terms, every appointment thereafter shall be according to the individual requirements of each place and for a term which carries an expiration date two years from the date of that place's last expiration. This shall be the appointment schedule even if adherence thereto results in an appointment for less than a full two years. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 3, 3-9-2009; Ord. No. 2014-65, § 1, 4-30-2014) 
Sec. 2-279. - Qualification of members. 
(a)  The membership of the board shall be as follows: 
Place 1 : An adult with a disability. 
Place 2 : A parent/caregiver of a person with a disability. 
Place 3 : A parent/caregiver of a person with a disability. 
Place 4 : A parent/caregiver of a person with a disability. 
Place 5 : An employee of the Madison City School Special Education Department. 
Place 6 : A Madison resident with an interest in promoting issues that affect persons with disabilities. 
Place 7 : A Madison resident with an interest in promoting issues that affect persons with disabilities. 
Place 8 : A person associated with a business not affiliated with disability services. 
Place 9 : A person associated with a business affiliated with disability services. 
(b)  In addition to the voting membership defined above, there shall be one ex officio non-voting member from the parks and recreation department and one ex officio non-voting liaison to the city council. 
(c)  Places 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 7 must be bona fide resident citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 4, 3-9-2009; Ord. No. 2014-65, § 2, 4-30-2014) 
Sec. 2-280. - Vacancies. 
(a)  Vacancies on the board shall be filled by appointment as defined in section 2-278. Appointments to fill vacancies, including those to fill interim terms as provided in section 2-278, shall be for the unexpired term. An appointee shall cease to be a member upon resignation to the mayor; upon ceasing to qualify under section 2-279; or upon removal by the member's appointing authority for failure to attend at least three consecutive regularly scheduled meetings without acceptable reasons as determined by the board chairperson. 
(b)  In the event a member's term expires and the appointing authority has not taken action to fill the expired place, the member will continue to serve beyond the expiration of his or her term until the place is filled by appointment or reappointment. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 5, 3-9-2009; Ord. No. 2014-65, § 3, 4-30-2014) 
Sec. 2-281. - Organization and meetings. 
    The board shall hold regular meetings at such time and place within the city, as it may from time to time determine; provided, however, that the board shall hold at least one regular or one special meeting every 90 days. The board shall adopt by-laws providing for its own administration, quorum requirements, officers, and other matters not inconsistent with this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 6, 3-9-2009) 
Sec. 2-282. - Subcommittees. 
    The board may, by simple majority vote, establish such subcommittees and advisory bodies as it sees fit. Such bodies may be advisory only, and shall have no power to act in the place of the board, nor shall they expend board funds without a vote of the board. Such bodies shall report their work to the full board, which shall take any official action on such work as they deem appropriate. The board may, however, delegate the administration of one or more of its programs to such a subcommittee, and authorize the expenditure of funds by the subcommittee for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 7, 3-9-2009) 
Sec. 2-283. - Reimbursements. 
    The members of the board shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the performance of their duty as authorized by a vote of the board. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 8, 3-9-2009) 
Sec. 2-284. - Funding. 
    Members are encouraged to procure funding through fundraisers and the solicitations of donations and grants made to the city, which the city will disburse specifically for their projects. The city council may make an annual appropriation to the board in the amount that they deem fit. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 9, 3-9-2009) 
Sec. 2-285. - Powers and duties. 
    The board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Advise the mayor and city council on matters affecting the disability community. 
(2)  Advise and assist other city boards, commissions, committees and city staff on matters affecting persons with disabilities. 
(3)  Review city policies, programs, and activities that affect persons with disabilities, including efforts to remove physical and programmatic barriers to access. 
(4)  Educate city employees on how to effectively interact with persons with disabilities. 
(5)  Serve as a coordinating body for the purpose of disseminating information to people with disabilities. 
(6)  Receive input from citizens on the needs and concerns of the disability community, formulate and recommend solutions to those concerns, and to convey such recommendations to appropriate governmental bodies. 
(7)  Comment on current and pending legislative and/or regulatory issues affecting persons with disabilities. 
(8)  Organize and maintain working committees, when appropriate. These working committees will consist of a minimum of one board member, and may address areas of concerns such as, but not limited to: 
a.  Accessibility; 
b.  Day program; 
c.  Housing; 
d.  Emergency services; 
e.  Employment; 
f.  Transportation; 
g.  Recreation. 
(9)  Provide and support activities that raise public awareness regarding persons with disabilities. 
(10)  Create task forces, as needed, to address specific issues. These task forces will be made up of at least one board member. 
(11)  Actively seek state, federal and private funding to assist the city and surrounding community in improving environmental and community accessibility, transportation, employment and economic development, and other services. 
(12)  Operate under the guidelines of the Legal Handbook for City of Madison Boards, Commissions, Committee and Similar Bodies. 
(13)  Establish communications and liaisons with organizations at the local, state and federal levels that have like-minded goals and objectives. 
(Ord. No. 2009-61, § 10, 3-9-2009) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Intoxicating liquor, malt beverages and wine, generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-1-1 et seq.; municipal authority to fix and levy local license taxes on alcoholic beverages, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3A-21(c); power of municipalities to adopt ordinances to promote temperance and to suppress intemperance, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-112. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The definitions set forth in Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3-1 ("Regulation and Control of Alcoholic Beverages in Wet Counties-General Provisions, Definitions"), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3-1, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3-1. 
(Code 1979, § 4-1; Code 1992, § 4-1) 
Sec. 4-2. - Interpretation and construction of chapter; purpose. 
(a)  This chapter shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the city for the protection of the public welfare, health, peace and morals of the people of the city. All of the provisions of this chapter shall be liberally construed for the accomplishment of this purpose. 
(b)  Except as herein otherwise expressly provided, the purpose of this chapter is to regulate transactions in alcoholic beverages which take place within the city, as herein specifically provided, and every section and provision of this chapter shall be construed accordingly. 
(Code 1979, § 4-2; Code 1992, § 4-2) 
Sec. 4-3. - Powers and duties of the revenue director. 
    The revenue director shall administer and enforce the licenses imposed by this chapter. The revenue director shall have the power to enter upon the premises of any taxpayer, examine or cause to be examined by any agent or representative designated by the revenue director for that purpose any books, papers, records, or memoranda, and other records bearing upon the amount of licenses or taxes payable and to secure other information directly concerned in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 4-4; Code 1992, § 4-3; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-4. - Purchase or sale from unauthorized or unlicensed persons. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to purchase any alcoholic beverages from any person, except those duly authorized and licensed under the provisions of this chapter or from a state liquor store. 
(b)  It shall unlawful within the city limits for any person to sell or offer for sale any liquor, malt or brewed beverages, or wine, except a state liquor store operated by the state pursuant to laws of the state, or a licensed distributor or retailer duly licensed by the city, and in accordance with ordinances, rules, regulations and standards adopted by the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person who has not been licensed to do so under laws or ordinances of this city to sell, offer for sale, or have in such person's possession for the purpose of sale any liquor, wine, malt or brewed beverages. Any such liquor, wine, or malt or brewed beverages held in violation of this section shall be confiscated, and upon conviction of any person found to be in violation of this section, any such liquor, wine, malt or brewed beverages confiscated hereunder shall be destroyed as contraband. 
(Code 1979, § 4-5; Code 1992, § 4-4; Ord. No. 91-93, §§ 1, 3, 9-24-1991) 
Sec. 4-5. - Drinking, exhibiting or displaying in public places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any public place, or the owner's agent or employee within the city to allow any person to drink or consume alcoholic beverages in such place operated by such person, agent or employee, except on premises licensed to sell such beverages for on-premises consumption. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume any liquor, wine or malt or brewed beverages in any public place within the city, except on premises licensed to sell such beverages pursuant to laws and ordinances of the city. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the consumption of spirituous or vinous liquors or malt or brewed beverages by persons lawfully upon premises which are not opened to the public at the time of such consumption. 
(Code 1979, § 4-10; Code 1992, § 4-45; Ord. No. 91-93, § 2, 9-24-1991) 
Sec. 4-6. - Public drunkenness. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be found on any street, highway or other public place within the city in a state of drunkenness. 
(Code 1979, § 4-11; Code 1992, § 4-6) 
State Law reference- Intoxication in public, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-10. 
Sec. 4-7. - Minors-Purchasing, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful: 
(1)  For any minor, directly or indirectly, to purchase or attempt to purchase any alcoholic beverage. 
(2)  For any minor to possess or to consume any alcoholic beverages in any public place or business establishment or club. 
(3)  For any person to sell, furnish, give to or purchase for any minor any alcoholic beverages, or to attempt to sell, furnish, give to or purchase for any minor any such beverages. 
(4)  For any minor, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent that such person is not a minor or is not under 21 years of age, and by means of such false representation buy, receive or otherwise obtain any alcoholic beverages. 
(5)  For any person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent that a minor is not a minor or is not under 21 years of age, and by means of such false representation, aid or abet or attempt to aid or abet such minor to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any alcoholic beverage. It shall be considered a false representation that a person is not a minor or is not under 21 years of age if the purchaser fails to disclose that the person making the purchase, obtaining or securing such alcoholic beverage is a minor person or has not reached the age of 21 years. 
(Code 1979, § 4-12; Code 1992, § 4-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-1-5; sale to minors, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3A-25(a)(3). 
Sec. 4-8. - Employment of minors. 
    It shall be unlawful to employ any person under the age of 19 years to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages of any kind. 
(Code 1979, § 4-21; Code 1992, § 4-8; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-9. - Sale of alcohol within entire corporate limits of city. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted to the city by Ala. Act No. 2003-277 of the Legislature of Alabama, all of the area located within the corporate limits of the city, including annexed portions located in a legally dry county, is hereby determined to be legally wet, and all of the provisions of Title 28, Code of Alabama, 1975, relating to alcoholic beverages in wet counties, including chapters 3, 3A, 6 and 7 shall be effective throughout the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 4-8.1; Ord. No. 2003-155, § 1, 7-14-2003) 
Sec. 4-10. - Hours of operation. 
    In addition to the hours of operation made unlawful by the provisions of the Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3A-25(a)(19) and (20), it shall be unlawful for any manufacturer, wholesaler, or lounge, club, or restaurant, or any establishment selling alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption, to sell, offer to sell, trade, or barter any alcoholic beverages, or to allow the consumption of same on the licensed premises between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. each secular day. 
(Code 1979, § 4-13; Code 1992, § 4-9; Ord. No. 94-134, § 1, 10-25-1994) 
Sec. 4-11. - Prohibited locations-Generally. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the sale of alcoholic beverages of any kind is prohibited within the city limits. 
(Code 1979, § 4-14; Code 1992, § 4-10; Ord. No. 2000-249, 12-18-2000; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-12. - On-premises beer and wine. 
    Retail beer or table wine licenses for on-premises consumption may be granted to establishments such as restaurants, bars, taprooms, salon-spas, barber shops, art studios, cigar stores, and vaping stores located in the following use districts as defined by the zoning ordinance of the City of Madison, Alabama: 
(a)  B-1 Neighborhood Business District. 
(b)  B-2 Community Commercial District. 
(c)  B-3 General Business District. 
(d)  MC Medical Center District. 
(e)  MU Mixed Use District. 
(f)  TND Traditional Neighborhood Development. 
(Code 1979, § 4-30; Code 1992, § 4-11; Ord. No. 94-22, § 1, 3-8-1994; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 1, 1-12-2011; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-13. - Off-premises beer and wine. 
    Licenses for the sale of table wine and beer for off-premises consumption may only be granted to establishments located in the following use districts as defined by the zoning ordinance of the City of Madison, Alabama: 
(a)  B-1 Neighborhood Business District. 
(b)  B-2 Community Commercial District. 
(c)  B-3 General Business District. 
(d)  MC Medical Center District. 
(e)  MU Mixed Use District. 
(f)  TND Traditional Neighborhood Development. 
(g)  M-1 Restricted Industrial District. 
(Code 1979, § 4-34; Code 1992, § 4-12; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 1-12-2011; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-14. - On-premises liquor. 
    Licenses for the sale of liquor for on-premises consumption may only be granted to establishments and restaurants located in the following use districts as established by the zoning ordinance of the City of Madison, Alabama: 
(a)  B-1 Neighborhood Business District. 
(b)  B-2 Community Commercial District. 
(c)  B-3 General Business District. 
(d)  MC Medical Center District. 
(e)  MU Mixed Use District. 
(f)  TND Traditional Neighborhood Development. 
(g)  M-1 Restricted Industrial District. 
(Code 1979, § 4-27; Code 1992, § 4-13; Ord. No. 94-22, § 2, 3-8-1994; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 3, 1-12-2011; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-15. - Off-premises liquor. 
    Licenses for the sale of liquor for off-premises consumption may only be granted to establishments located in the following use districts, as defined and conditioned by the zoning ordinance of the City of Madison, Alabama: 
(a)  B-2 Community Commercial District. 
(b)  B-3 General Business District. 
(c)  MC Medical Center District. 
(d)  MU Mixed Use District. 
(e)  TND Traditional Neighborhood Development. 
(Code 1992, § 4-13.1; Ord. No. 94-159, § 1, 1-10-1995; Ord. No. 2011-357, 1-9-2012; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-16. - Sales to be in original containers; receipt from unlicensed distributor; consumption on premises of licensee. 
(a)  Importer, wholesaler or warehouser. No importer, wholesaler or warehouser shall purchase or receive for sale any alcoholic beverages except in the original containers as prepared for the market by the manufacturer. No alcoholic beverages sold or delivered shall be consumed upon the premises of the licensee in any place provided for such purpose by such licensee, unless such licensee shall have first procured the applicable retail license from the board and the city. 
(b)  Off-premises retailers. No off-premises retailer shall purchase or receive any alcoholic beverages except from wholesalers licensed under the board and this chapter. All such alcoholic beverages must be received in original containers as prepared for the market by the manufacturer. All alcoholic beverages must be sold or dispensed in the original containers, and sold for off-premises consumption. 
(Code 1979, § 4-15; Code 1992, § 4-14) 
Sec. 4-17. - Records. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to keep, for a period of at least three years, complete and truthful records covering the operation under the license and particularly showing the date of all purchases of alcoholic beverages, the actual price paid therefor and the name of the vendor, or to refuse an authorized employee of the city access thereto or the opportunity to make copies of such records when the request is made during business hours. 
(Code 1979, § 4-16; Code 1992, § 4-15) 
Sec. 4-18. - Advertising. 
(a)  No licensee selling alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption shall construct, install or permit the construction of any advertising matter, electric sign, painted sign or signs of any kind advertising alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises outside any business outlet, provided that this section shall not prohibit any licensee hereunder from placing upon the licensed premises a sign not to exceed 32 square feet in dimension advertising alcoholic beverages for sale by use of the words "Beverages for Sale." 
(b)  No licensee selling alcoholic beverages for on-premises or off-premises consumption shall construct, install or permit the construction and installation of any advertising matter, electric sign, painted sign or signs of any kind advertising malt or brewed beverages on the licensed premises outside any business outlet; provided, that this section shall not prohibit any licensee hereunder from placing upon the licensed premises a sign not to exceed 32 square feet in dimension advertising alcoholic beverages for sale by use of the words "Beverages Served-On-Premises/Off-Premises." 
(Code 1979, § 4-18; Code 1992, § 4-16) 
State Law reference- Advertising of alcoholic beverages, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3-16. 
Sec. 4-19. - Inspections. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to refuse any authorized employee of the city the right to completely inspect the entire licensed premises at any time during which the premises are open for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1979, § 4-19; Code 1992, § 4-17) 
Sec. 4-20. - Employment of licensee by other licensee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to be directly or indirectly employed by any other licensee engaged in the manufacture, storage, transportation or sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1979, § 4-20; Code 1992, § 4-18) 
Sec. 4-21. - Transportation-In original containers; permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee or transporter for hire to transport any alcoholic beverages except in the original containers. It shall be unlawful for any transporter for hire to transport any alcoholic beverages within the city unless such transporter shall hold a permit issued by the board. 
(Code 1979, § 4-23; Code 1992, § 4-19) 
Sec. 4-22. - Same-Vehicles to bear name and address of distributor. 
    It shall be unlawful for a manufacturer, wholesaler or distributor to deliver any alcoholic beverages except in vehicles bearing the name, address and license number of such distributor, wholesaler or manufacturer on each side of such vehicle printed or affixed in letters not smaller than four inches in height. 
(Code 1979, § 4-24; Code 1992, § 4-20) 
Sec. 4-23. - Sale of contraband beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any contraband alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1979, § 4-17; Code 1992, § 4-21) 
Sec. 4-24. - Manufacture, transportation, etc., in accordance with rules. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, transport or import any alcoholic beverages into the city except in accordance with the rules and regulations of the board, or for any person to transport alcoholic beverages into or within the city unless there shall be affixed to the original container in which such alcoholic beverages are transported stamps, crowns or lids evidencing the payment of the alcoholic beverage tax to the state; provided, that this section shall not be construed to prohibit transportation of alcoholic beverages through the city and not for the delivery therein if such transportation is done in accordance with the rules and regulations of the board. 
(Code 1979, § 4-22; Code 1992, § 4-22) 
Sec. 4-25. - Beverages on which tax has not been paid-Possession. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display, exhibit, possess or have in possession on the premises of such person any alcoholic beverage on which the license tax has not been paid, provided that this section shall not apply to alcoholic beverages in the possession of distributors or wholesalers which have not been withdrawn from storage for sale. 
(Code 1979, § 4-8; Code 1992, § 4-23) 
State Law reference- Failure to pay tax, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 28-3-192, 28-3-193; disposal, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3A-25(a)(17). 
Sec. 4-26. - Same-Display, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display, exhibit, possess or have in possession on the premises of such person any alcoholic beverage on which the license tax has not been paid to the city as required by this chapter, provided that this section shall not apply to alcoholic beverages in the possession of distributors or wholesalers which have not been withdrawn from storage for sale. 
(Code 1979, § 4-9; Code 1992, § 4-24) 
Sec. 4-27. - Unstamped intoxicating beverages-Possession, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful anywhere within the city for any person to accept delivery of, receive, have in such person's possession or possess any alcoholic beverage, unless such beverage is stamped or endorsed in such a manner as to clearly indicate that such beverage has been dispensed by a state liquor store or a licensee of the alcoholic beverage control board, or unless there is affixed to the original container in which such liquor or beverage is contained stamps, crowns or lids evidencing the payment of the tax on such beverage to the state; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the possession of wine or cordials made from grapes or other fruits when the grapes or other fruits are grown by the person making such beverages for such person's own domestic use on such person's own premises in the state and when such person keeps such wine or cordials for such person's own domestic use on such person's own premises in any quantity not exceeding five gallons for one family in ten months, nor to the receipt or possession of wine for sacramental purposes, when received and possessed by an authorized person in accordance with the rules and regulations prescribed by the laws of the state, when not exceeding the quantity so prescribed. 
(Code 1979, § 4-6; Code 1992, § 4-25) 
Sec. 4-28. - Same-Seizure. 
    Any alcoholic beverages enumerated and defined in section 4-1 found at any point within the city, which shall have been within the city for a period of two hours or longer in the possession of any off-premises retailer, or for a period of 36 hours or longer in the possession of any wholesaler or distributor, not having affixed to the package the stamps, crowns or lids as provided by the board, are hereby declared to be contraband goods which may be seized by the city agents or by any peace officer of the city without a warrant. Such goods shall be delivered to the board or its agents; provided, that any of the goods, wares or merchandise herein enumerated and all such goods, wares or merchandise when offered for sale, either at wholesale or retail, without the stamps, crowns or lids having been affixed, shall be subject to seizure as hereinabove provided; and provided, that any vehicle not a common carrier which may be used for the transportation for the purpose of sale of unstamped articles, as hereinabove enumerated, shall likewise be subject to seizure in the manner as above provided for goods, wares or merchandise without stamps, crowns or lids; and provided, that should any alcoholic beverages without stamps, crowns or lids enumerated and defined herein be found in any vehicle which is engaged in the sale, distribution or delivery of taxable alcoholic beverages, it shall be prima facie evidence that such beverages were there for sale. 
(Code 1979, § 4-7; Code 1992, § 4-26) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3-240. 
Sec. 4-29. - Applicability of license schedule. 
    Any reference in this chapter to license fees, amounts or charges shall be governed, controlled and determined by the license schedules of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 4-45; Code 1992, § 4-27) 
Sec. 4-30. - Maintenance of order; exclusion of disorderly, etc., persons; reports to police. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each owner, and of each manager or supervisor at any time charged with the management and supervision, of any retail liquor or wine or retail malt or brewed beverage licensed premises, while the same is open to the public to maintain order upon the premises and to exclude from the premises any person who is drunk and disorderly or who commits any breach of the peace, or who uses offensive, disorderly, threatening, abusive or insulting language, conduct or behavior with the intent to provoke a breach of the peace, or whereby a breach of the peace might be occasioned. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each officer, owner, manager or person in charge of any retail or liquor or wine or retail malt or brewed beverage premises within the city to immediately make an appropriate report by telephone to the police department of each assault, assault and battery or affray occurring on the licensed premises while such premises are open for business. 
(c)  It shall further be the duty of such person to make a written report of such incidents to the police department within 36 hours thereof. Failure to make either of such reports shall be grounds for revocation or suspension of the license for the operation of such establishment. 
(Code 1992, § 4-28; Ord. No. 91-93, § 4, 9-24-1991) 
Sec. 4-31. - Habitual breaches of peace, etc. 
    Habitual breaches of the peace, affrays, assaults, assaults and batteries and the continued and habitual presence of disorderly persons upon the premises of a licensee shall be grounds for revocation or suspension of the license for the operation of such establishment. In addition, repeated and habitual incidents of vandalism, breaches of the peace, disorderly conduct or other violations of state or local laws which unreasonably interfere with the peace, quiet, comfort and repose of persons of ordinary sensibilities in the neighborhood where such incidents may be attributable to the presence in the neighborhood of the licensed establishment shall also be grounds for revocation or suspension of the license of such establishment. 
(Code 1992, § 4-29; Ord. No. 91-93, § 5, 9-24-1991) 
Sec. 4-32. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, adopted February 8, 2016, repealed § 4-32, which pertained to hours for selling or serving of alcoholic beverages on Sunday specified and derived from Code 1992, § 4-29.1; Ord. No. 94-146, § 1, 1-10-1995. 
Sec. 4-33. - Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sunday. 
    Alcoholic beverages are hereby authorized and permitted to be sold within the corporate limits of the city on Sunday in the same manner as permitted on other days of the week. 
(Code 1992, § 4-29.2; Ord. No. 2003-252, 10-13-2003) 
Secs. 4-34-4-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 28-3-194, 28-3A-21. 

Sec. 4-55. - License and food service requirements. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who has not been licensed to do so under the appropriate provisions of the laws of the state and of this chapter to sell, offer for sale, or have possession for sale of any alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person holding a license for on-premises consumption of any alcoholic beverages pursuant to this chapter to offer such beverages for sale at any time without offering food or snack items. 
(Code 1979, § 4-25; Code 1992, § 4-30; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-56. - Manufacturers, importers, wholesalers and warehousers; application procedure; issuance. 
(a)  Upon the applicant filing an application with the board for a manufacturer, importer, liquor wholesaler, wholesaler, or warehouser license, or within five business days thereafter, the applicant must file a duplicate, verified copy of such application with the revenue director, along with a nonrefundable filing fee and the privilege license fee as required by chapter 10, such privilege license fee being conditioned on the board granting the requested license. The amount of the filing fee shall be as established by the council, from time to time. 
(b)  All applicants shall, upon the filing of the application with the revenue director, submit copies of the plans and specifications for any building located or planned to be located upon the proposed premises to the building department and the planning department. The premises shall comply with all planning and zoning requirements and ordinances, fire codes, and public health laws as required by the ordinances of the city, county, and state. If the premises complies with said planning and zoning codes and regulations, the head of the city's planning department will submit a signed certification of such compliance to the revenue director. If the premises complies with city and state fire prevention, electrical, and building codes, the head of the city's building department will submit a certificate of occupancy to the revenue department. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the requested license from the board, and upon the applicant's compliance with section 4-56(b), including the required certifications from city departments, the revenue director is authorized to issue the following licenses to the applicant: 
(1)  A manufacturer's license, which shall authorize the licensee to manufacture or otherwise distill, produce, ferment, brew, bottle, rectify, or compound alcoholic beverages within the city or for sale or distribution within the city, under the terms and conditions as permitted by the laws of the state. 
(2)  An importer's license, which shall authorize the licensee to import alcoholic beverages manufactured outside the United States of America into the city under the terms and conditions as permitted by the laws of the state. 
(3)  A liquor wholesaler's license, which shall authorize the licensee to import and receive shipments of liquor or wine from outside the city from licensed manufacturers and to sell at wholesale or distribute liquor or wine to the board or as authorized by the board; except, that a liquor wholesale licensee may not sell liquor or fortified wine to retail licensees of the board, under the terms and conditions as permitted by the laws of the state. 
(4)  A wholesaler's license, which shall authorize the licensee to import and receive shipments of beer and table wine from outside the state from licensed manufacturers, to purchase beer and table wine from licensed manufacturers or other licensed wholesalers within the state, and to sell at wholesale or distribute beer and table wine to all licensees or others within the state lawfully authorized to sell beer and wine within the state, and to export beer and wine from the state, under the terms and conditions as permitted by the laws of the state. 
(5)  A warehouser's license, which will authorize the licensee to receive, store, or warehouse alcoholic beverages within the state for transshipment inside and outside the state, under the terms and conditions as permitted by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1979, § 4-26; Code 1992, § 4-31; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-57. - Lounges, clubs, restaurants, on-premises table wine and off-premises table wine and liquor licenses; application procedures; issuance; operation requirements. 
(a)  Upon the applicant's filing for a state lounge, club, or restaurant retail liquor license, off-premises retail liquor license, or on-premises or off-premises table wine license, or special retail license, or within five business days thereafter, the applicant shall file a duplicate verified copy of that license application with the revenue director, along with a nonrefundable filing fee, and the license fee as specified in chapter 10, which license fee shall be conditioned upon the board's granting of the requested license. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the license application and the fees referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the revenue director shall inform the chief of police of the city of the application for such license, along with the name of the individual, partnership, or corporation applying for such license and, in the event that the proposed licensee is to be a partnership or corporation, the names of the partners or stockholders of the partnership or corporation, and the name of the proposed manager of the proposed licensee. The chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant, including, if the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the partners or stockholders and the proposed manager of the proposed licensee. The chief of police shall, at the earliest practicable time, report to the governing body the results of the investigation, along with a recommendation to the governing body as to the granting of consent by the governing body to the proposed licensee; but in no case shall the report be made later than the time set for public hearing of the proposed licensee's request for consent of the governing body. 
(c)  A public hearing shall be held on the granting or withholding of consent to the issuance of the license by the board, which hearing shall be held at a regular meeting of the governing body; provided, however, that no public hearing on the application shall be held less than 14 days from the date of the filing of the application with the revenue director. In all cases, notice of such public hearing shall be given by at least one insertion in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least ten days prior to the time set for such public hearing; any such advertisement shall be of a size of not less than four inches by four inches, carrying a distinctive surrounding border, stating the address and location of the proposed premises, the name of the applicant, and the date and time of the public hearing. Such notice shall be published at the applicant's expense, and proof of publication must be mailed or delivered to the revenue director's office prior to the time for the public hearing. At such public hearing, the applicant and all persons interested in securing the approval or disapproval of such application may be heard. 
(d)  In considering an application for a license, the city council shall consider the following, including, but not necessarily limited to: character of the applicant; the applicant's record; location of the place of business; applicant's compliance with the present laws of the state and of the city; the period of residence in the limits of the city; and the applicant's general attitude toward the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(e)  No consent shall be given by the city council under this chapter to any person or any partnership to whom a partner belongs, or to any corporation to whom a stockholder belongs, that has, during the preceding 12 months, forfeited a cash bond for violation of liquor laws in any court or has been convicted of violating the liquor laws in any court, or to any applicant who has misstated any material fact on the application for a license. 
(f)  All applicants shall, upon the filing of the application with the revenue director, submit copies of the plans and specifications for any building located or planned to be located upon the proposed premises to the building department and the planning department. The premises shall comply with all planning and zoning requirements and ordinances, fire codes, and public health laws as required by the ordinances of the city, county, and state. If the premises complies with said planning and zoning codes and regulations, the head of the city's planning department will submit a signed certification of such compliance to the revenue director. If the premises complies with city and state fire prevention, electrical, and building codes, the head of the city's building department will submit a certificate of occupancy to the revenue department. 
(g)  Upon both the grant of any retail or special retail license and the certification of City departments required in section 4-57(f), the revenue director shall be authorized to issue to the applicant a lounge, club, restaurant, or special retail license, which will allow the applicant to purchase liquor and wine from the board or as authorized by the board, and beer, and to sell the same at retail, under the terms and conditions set forth in this chapter, the state code, and the regulations of the board; provided, however, that: 
(1)  A license under this chapter for a restaurant may be issued only to an eating establishment licensed by the city which has obtained all required food handling permits from the department of public health of either Madison County or Limestone County. 
(2)  A special retail license may be issued for a state park, racing commission, fair authority, airport authority, or civic center authority, or the franchises or concessionaire of such park, commission, or authority, and to any other valid responsible organization of good reputation for such period of time not to exceed one year and upon such terms and conditions as the council may prescribe, subject to restrictions and limitations imposed by the board or its regulations. 
(h)  Upon the board's grant of an off-premises retail liquor license, or an on-premises or off-premises table wine license, and upon applicant's compliance with this chapter and the certification of city departments as specified in section 4-57(f), the revenue director is authorized to issue the following appropriate licenses to the applicant: 
(1)  A retail liquor license for off-premises consumption, which authorizes the licensee to purchase liquor from the board or from a licensed wholesaler and to sell such liquor in original unopened containers at retail for off-premises consumption, as permitted by the Code of Alabama and the regulations of the board. 
(2)  A retail table wine license for off-premises consumption, which authorizes the licensee to purchase table wine in package form from the board or from a licensed wholesaler and to sell such table wines in original unopened containers at retail for off-premises consumption, as permitted by the Code of Alabama and the regulations of the board. 
(3)  A retail table wine license for on-premises consumption, which authorizes the licensee to purchase table wine from the board or from a licensed wholesaler and to sell table wine at retail for on-premises consumption, as permitted by the Code of Alabama and the regulations of the board. 
(Code 1979, § 4-28; Code 1992, § 4-32; Ord. No. 91-106, § 1, 10-22-1991; Ord. No. 94-147, § 1, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 99-187, §§ 1-3, 12-13-1999; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-58. - Beer license for on-premises consumption. 
    Upon the applicant's filing with the board for a retail beer license for on-premises consumption, or within five business days thereafter, the applicant shall file a duplicate, verified copy of such application with the revenue director, along with a nonrefundable filing fee and the privilege license fee as required by chapter 10, such privilege license fee being conditioned on the board's granting the requested license. The amount of the filing fee shall be as established by the city council, from time to time. Upon granting the requested license from the board, and upon applicant's compliance with this chapter and the certification of city departments as specified in section 4-57(f), the revenue director is authorized to issue a retail beer license for on-premises consumption, which authorizes the licensee to purchase beer from a licensed wholesaler and to sell the same at retail for on-premises consumption and in original unopened containers for off-premises consumption, to the extent permitted in the Code of Alabama and the regulations of the board." 
(Code 1979, § 4-29; Code 1992, § 4-33; Ord. No. 94-147, § 2, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-59. - Beer license for off-premises consumption. 
    Upon the applicant's filing an application with the board for a retail beer license for off-premises consumption, or within five business days thereafter, the applicant must file a duplicate, verified copy of such application with the revenue director, along with a nonrefundable filing fee and the privilege license fee as required by chapter 10, such privilege license fee being conditioned on the board granting the requested license. The amount of the filing fee shall be as established by the city council, from time to time. Upon granting the requested license from the board, and upon the applicant's compliance with this chapter and the certification of city departments as specified in section 4-57(f), the revenue director is authorized to issue a retail beer license for off-premises consumption, which license will authorize the licensee to purchase beer in original unopened containers from licensed wholesalers and to sell such beer in package form at retail for off-premises consumption, to the extent permitted in the Code of Alabama and the regulations of the board. 
(Code 1979, § 4-33; Code 1992, § 4-34; Ord. No. 94-147, § 3, 12-27-1994; Ord. No. 2016-21, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-60. - Restrictions as to licensees. 
    No such license shall be issued to any person or to any partnership or to any corporation to whom a partner, in the case of a partnership or a stockholder, in the case of a corporation has, during the preceding 12 months, been convicted of violating the liquor laws in any court or who has, during the preceding 12 months, forfeited a cash bond on the charge of violating the liquor laws in any court. 
(Code 1979, §§ 4-31, 4-35; Code 1992, § 4-35) 
Sec. 4-61. - Applicants to comply with relevant public health laws, fire prevention, electrical and building codes. 
    No applicant under this article shall be deemed eligible for a license hereunder until such applicant has obtained and is the holder of all required food handling permits from the county department of public health. No business outlet or licensee hereunder shall be eligible for a license until inspected by the building official of the city and found to be in compliance with the minimum requirements of the fire prevention, electrical and building codes of the state and the city. 
(Code 1979, §§ 4-32, 4-36; Code 1992, § 4-36) 
Sec. 4-62. - Special retail license or a special events retail license. 
(a)  An applicant for a special retail license or a special events retail license for the sale of alcoholic beverages from the board must file a duplicate application with the city clerk, along with a non-refundable filing fee and a privilege license fee. The amounts of the filing fee and the privilege license fee shall be as established by the council, from time to time. Upon review of the application and a determination that the applicant is in compliance with this article and all planning, zoning, fire, electrical, building, and health codes, if the request for the license is limited to the sale of beer only, the city clerk is authorized to issue a special retail license or a special events retail license, subject only to terms and conditions as the council may prescribe and to the granting of the license from the board. 
(b)  If the request is for a special retail license or a special events retail license for the sale of wine or liquor in addition to, or instead of, beer, the city council shall hear the request for the license and shall determine whether and under what conditions it will consent to the issuance of the license from the board. If approved by the city council, the appropriate license will be issued by the city clerk, subject only to the granting of the license by the board. 
(Code 1992, § 4-37; Ord. No. 95-92, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 98-33, §§ 1, 2, 2-23-1998) 
Secs. 4-63-4-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOND AND REPORTS 

Sec. 4-71. - Bond of wholesalers. 
(a)  Before any license may be issued to any wholesale distributor or jobber of any alcoholic beverages pursuant to chapter 10, such wholesale distributor or jobber shall deliver to, and maintain with, the city clerk or license collector a bond, payable in a penal sum not to exceed twice the amount of the average monthly tax due by the licensee to the city as estimated by the city clerk or tax collector, such bond to be executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the state and the city and conditioned to promptly pay to the city all amounts which may become due to the city from such wholesale distributor or jobber under the terms of this section after the date of such bond. 
(b)  Such wholesale distributor or jobber may deposit with the clerk or license collector cash or readily marketable securities, satisfactory to the clerk or license collector, of a value equivalent to the amount of security hereinabove required to be provided by the suretyship of surety upon bond. 
(c)  If any such collateral securities are impaired in value by existing liabilities there against, or otherwise, such wholesale distributor or jobber shall furnish additional securities or bond, so that at all times revenues to become due shall be secured to the extent of twice the amount of average tax collection due to the city. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any wholesale distributor or jobber to do any business within the city while in default in the provision of security as hereinabove required, regardless of any amount of license which may have heretofore been paid. 
(Code 1979, § 10-31; Code 1992, § 4-40) 
State Law reference- Authority, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3-190(b). 
Sec. 4-72. - Liquor sales reports. 
(a)  On or before the 20th day of each month, every person, whether public or private, who is engaged in the business of selling liquor shall render to the city, on a form prescribed by the city, a true and correct verified statement showing the gross receipts of liquor sold during the next preceding month, which report shall accompany payment of the tax. 
(b)  Any person subject to the provisions hereof who shall sell out such person's business or stock of goods, or shall quit business, shall be required to make out the return provided for under this section within 30 days after the date such person sold out the business or stock of goods, or quit business; and a successor in business shall be required to withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase money to cover the amount of such taxes due and unpaid until such time as the former owner shall produce a receipt from the department showing that the taxes have been paid, and the successor shall be personally liable for the payment of the taxes accrued and unpaid on account of the operation of the business of the former owner. If in such cases the department deems it necessary in order to collect the taxes due the city, it may make a jeopardy assessment as herein provided. 
(Code 1979, § 4-39; Code 1992, § 4-41) 
Sec. 4-73. - Beer sales reports-Wholesale. 
(a)  Each wholesale distributor or jobber selling malt or brewed beverages to any retailer, on-premises/off-premises licensee, off-premises retailer or private club within the city shall, on or before the 15th day of each calendar month, file with the city clerk an itemized, verified statement showing the number of each 12 ounces of malt or brewed beverages delivered by such wholesale distributor or jobber to each retailer, on-premises/off-premises licensee, off-premises retailer or private club during the calendar month next preceding. Such report shall show the name and address of each retailer, on-premises/off-premises licensee, off-premises retailer or private club to whom such beverages were delivered and the number of each 12 ounces of malt or brewed beverages delivered to each such retailer, on-premises/off-premises licensee, off-premises retailer or private club. 
(b)  Any wholesale distributor or jobber of malt or brewed beverages doing business within the city failing to make such a report shall be subject to a penalty of $10.00 per day for each day after the 15th day such report is delinquent, and if such report has not been filed and all penalties paid to the city clerk by the first day of the following calendar month, such wholesale distributor or jobber shall thereby forfeit such person's privilege of continuing to engage in the business of selling such malt or brewed beverages at retail, wholesale or otherwise within the city. 
(Code 1979, § 10-32; Code 1992, § 4-42) 
State Law reference- Excise tax on beer (preemption), Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3-190(e). 
Sec. 4-74. - Same-Retail. 
(a)  Each person selling at retail any malt or brewed beverages within the city shall, on or before the 15th day of each calendar month, file with the city clerk an itemized, verified statement showing the amount of malt or brewed beverages sold during the next preceding calendar month. Such report shall show the name and address of each wholesale distributor or jobber source and the amount so delivered or so obtained. 
(b)  Each person selling at retail malt or brewed beverages within the city failing to make such a report shall be subject to a penalty per day for each day after the 15th day such report is delinquent, and if such report has not been filed and all penalties paid to the city clerk by the first day of the following calendar month, such person shall thereby forfeit the privilege of continuing to engage in the business of selling malt or brewed beverages at retail within the city. 
(Code 1979, § 10-34; Code 1992, § 4-43) 
Sec. 4-75. - Wine sales reports-Wholesale. 
(a)  Each wholesale distributor or jobber selling wine to any retailer, on-premises/off-premises licensee, off-premises retailer or private club within the city shall file with the city clerk the monthly return required to be filed with the state alcoholic beverage control board under Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-7-16(b), which return shall be filed with the city clerk not later than the tenth day following the date such return is due to be filed with the state alcoholic beverage control board. 
(b)  Any wholesale distributor or jobber of wine doing business within the city failing to make such a report shall be subject to a penalty per day for each day after the 15th day such report is delinquent, and if such report has not been filed and all penalties paid to the city clerk by the first day of the following calendar month, such wholesale distributor or jobber shall thereby forfeit such person's privilege of continuing to engage in the business of selling wine at retail, wholesale or otherwise within the city. 
(Code 1979, § 4-42; Code 1992, § 4-44) 
Sec. 4-76. - Same-Retail. 
(a)  Each retail licensee of table wine, or licensee holding any other license for on-premises or off-premises consumption, shall file a monthly report with the city clerk, showing the total amount of inventory received from each wine wholesaler, the total sales during the month, and such other information as the clerk may require. The reports, when filed, are to be verified, and shall substantially comply with the forms supplied by the clerk. 
(b)  Each person selling at retail wine within the city failing to make such a report shall be subject to a penalty per day for each day after the 15th day such report is delinquent, and if such report has not been filed and all penalties paid to the city clerk by the first day of the following calendar month, such persons shall thereby forfeit the privilege of continuing to engage in the business of selling wine at retail within the city. The penalty imposed for failure to file such a report shall be as described under section 1-8. 
(Code 1979, § 4-43; Code 1992, § 4-45) 
Sec. 4-77. - Authority of clerk to examine books and records. 
    The city clerk or the city clerk's designee shall have the authority to examine the books and records of any licensee to determine the accuracy of any report required to be filed with such clerk. 
(Code 1979, § 4-44; Code 1992, § 4-46) 
Sec. 4-78. - Records to be kept confidential. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person connected with the administration of this article to divulge any information obtained by such person in the course of inspection and examination of the books of account, invoices, bank statements, sales tax records, state and federal income tax records or other reports and memoranda of the taxpayers made pursuant to the provisions hereof, except to the mayor, the city council, the city clerk, the city attorney or the agents or representatives thereof, connected with the administration of this article, or to like officers of other municipalities within the county or to duly authorized officers of the state and federal governments in connection with their official duties and upon written request. 
(Code 1979, § 10-36; Code 1992, § 4-47) 
Secs. 4-79-4-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIQUOR EXCISE TAX 

Sec. 4-100. - Privilege and license tax levied. 
    There is hereby levied and imposed, in addition to all other taxes of every kind now imposed by law, and shall be collected as herein provided, a privilege or license tax against the person on account of the business activities as follows: Upon every person, whether public or private, who is engaged in the business of selling liquor a twelve percent gross receipts tax, which privilege or license tax is hereby expressly levied against such sales for either on-premises or off-premises consumption. 
(Code 1979, § 4-37; Code 1992, § 4-50; Ord. No. 95-37, § 1, 3-28-1995; Ord. No. 2016-22, § 1, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 4-101. - Payment; penalty. 
(a)  The tax levied under provisions of this article shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the 20th day of the month next succeeding the month in which the sales are made. 
(b)  Any person who fails to pay the tax herein levied within the time required hereunder shall pay, in addition to the tax, a penalty of ten percent of the amount of tax due, together with interest thereon at the rate of one-half of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date at which the tax herein levied became due and payable. Such penalty and interest shall be assessed and collected as part of the tax, provided that the revenue officer may, upon the approval of the city council, if a good and sufficient reason is shown, waive the penalty of ten percent and/or the interest or a portion thereof. 
(Code 1979, § 4-39; Code 1992, § 4-51) 
Sec. 4-102. - Collection from purchasers. 
    All persons subject to the provisions of this tax shall add the same to the sales price of the liquor sold and collect it from the purchasers. 
(Code 1979, § 4-38; Code 1992, § 4-52) 
Sec. 4-103. - Records to be kept. 
    All persons subject to provisions of this tax shall keep and preserve for a period of three years all records of such sales and purchase invoices of alcoholic beverages sold. 
(Code 1979, § 4-40; Code 1992, § 4-53) 
Sec. 4-104. - Effect on certain existing provisions. 
    This tax shall not be construed to repeal any of the provisions of the general license code of the city or of any other ordinance or code provision of the city imposing a license tax; and this tax shall be held to be cumulative to all other ordinances and code provisions of the city. In particular, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, this tax shall not be deemed to amend, repeal, modify or affect any of the provisions of other articles of this chapter, or any of the provisions of this article, and this tax is and shall be deemed to be in addition to, and cumulative thereof. 
(Code 1979, § 4-41; Code 1992, § 4-54) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMAL CONTROL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Animals generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-1-1 et seq.; general authority relative to animals, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 3-5-14, 11-47-110; municipal authority to establish and fix reasonable fees for animal control program, Code of Ala. 1975, § 45-8-170. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal control officer means such person as may be so designated or employed by the city for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and any other ordinances of the city concerning animals as defined herein, and all other persons designated by the chief of police as assistant animal control officers or enforcement officers to assist the animal control officer in the performance of such officer's duties. The chief of police shall be the department head responsible for the general supervision and control of the animal control officer and of the employees of the city assigned to the animal control officer. 
    At large means when an animal is off the property of its owner or person in charge and not under effective control or restraint of a person physically capable of restraining the animal. 
    Cat means any member of the domestic feline family which is three months old or more. 
    City animal shelter means the place designated or used as such by the city for the maintenance and operation of a pound, located on the premises of the city police department. 
    Cruelty means any act or omission whereby unjustifiable physical pain, suffering or death of an animal is caused or permitted, including failure to provide proper food, drink, air, space, shelter or protection from the elements, a safe and sanitary living environment, and veterinary care. 
    Dog means any member of the domestic canine family which is three months old or more. 
    Domestic animal includes dogs, cats, domesticated sheep, horses, cattle, goats, swine, fowl, ducks, geese, turkeys, confined domestic hares and rabbits, pheasants, and other birds and animals raised and/or maintained in confinement. 
    Exotic animal means any monkey, alligator, crocodile, raccoon, skunk, fox, bear, sea mammal, venomous snake, member of the feline species other than domestic cat, member of the canine species other than the domestic dog, or any other animal that would require a standard of care greater than that required for customary household pets sold by commercial pet shops or domestic farm animals. 
    Feral cat means any member of the feline family existing in a wild or untamed state, or a cat which has been separated from domestication through abandonment, loss, or running away. 
    Kennel, commercial, means any premises wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, letting for hire, training for a fee, or selling dogs or cats. 
    Kennel, private, means any premises wherein five or more dogs or cats are kept and are provided a minimum of a ten-foot by 25-foot area for each animal and which is not principally operated as a commercial enterprise. The occasional purchase and sale of animals will not affect private kennels otherwise fitting this definition. 
    Owner or person in charge means the actual owner or person in whose charge said animal is being kept, and all the responsible adult members of the household where an animal is regularly kept or allowed or suffered to remain. 
    Restraint means an animal is controlled by a leash; with a competent person, and responds to the commands of that person; on or within a vehicle being driven or parked on a public street; or securely enclosed within the property limits of its owner or keeper. 
    Shelter means a dwelling with a roof, enclosed sides, a doorway, and a solid floor that provides protection from the elements. 
    Stray animal means any animal running at large, the owner or person in charge of which is unknown. 
(Code 1992, § 5-1; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-2. - Fines and penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-8; provided, however, that where any person is found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter for which a fine is provided and imposed, in addition to such other punishment as may be provided by the court, the minimum fines shall apply as follows: 
Charge 1st Offense 2nd Offense 3rd Offense Habitual Keeping dangerous animals $100.00 $200.00 $500.00 Cruelty to animals  250.00  500.00 10-day confinement Abandoning animals  100.00  200.00 $500.00 Sanitation   25.00   50.00  100.00 Allowing an animal to run at large   25.00   50.00  100.00 Not properly confining a female dog or cat in heat   25.00   50.00  100.00 Noisy animals   25.00   50.00  100.00 Allowing a dog or cat to be at large without proper license tag affixed   25.00   50.00  100.00 Vicious dogs  100.00  200.00  500.00  
(Code 1992, § 5-2; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 2010-59, § 1, 5-24-2010) 
Sec. 6-3. - Citations. 
    When any animal is found by the animal control officer to be in violation of any provision of this chapter, and the person or persons responsible become known to the animal control officer, he may issue a citation to that person directing him to appear in the municipal court at a time and date stated therein to answer to charges of violations of this chapter. Any violations shall be stated in said citation. It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person to fail to appear in the municipal court at the time stated in a citation issued by an animal control officer. 
(Code 1992, § 5-3; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-4. - Animal control officer's authority on unenclosed premises. 
    For the purpose of discharging the duties imposed by this article and to enforce its provisions, the animal control officer and the animal control officer's assistants are each empowered to enter upon any unenclosed premises upon which a dog is running at large in violation of this article and in the presence of such animal control officer or animal control officer's assistants for the purpose of obtaining information for the issuance of a citation or of impounding such dog. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-5. - Humane animal traps. 
(a)  Any animal control officer, in order to apprehend animals in violation of this chapter, and which are otherwise difficult to apprehend, is hereby authorized to humanely capture said animals by placing a humane animal trap upon city property, or upon private property with owner's permission in writing. 
(b)  If placed on private property, it shall be the duty of the citizen to check the trap daily and immediately contact animal control to report trapped animals. 
(c)  No humane animal traps shall be set on any Friday or any day before an observed holiday. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to molest or tamper with any humane animal trap or to interfere with the animal control officer in setting or servicing any such trap. 
(e)  The city will provide a humane animal trap for wildlife if the wildlife is causing destruction to the residence or presents an immediate health hazard. The trap will be placed in or around the homeowner's residence or inside of the garage, not including crawl space and attic space. It shall be the resident's responsibility to check the trap daily and call animal control for removal of any trapped animal. 
(f)  If any dog or cat is captured in a humane trap that is not on their owner's property, it shall be presumed that the owner has allowed, suffered, or permitted such animal to run at large, at which time the animal control officer will issue a citation or summons as provided in section 6-12. 
(Code 1992, § 5-5; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-6. - Interference. 
    No person shall interfere with, hinder or molest any animal control officer or animal control officer's assistant in the performance of any duty of such animal control officer or animal control officer's assistant or seek to release any dog or puppy in the custody of the animal control officer, animal control officer's assistants, the poundmaster or the poundmaster's assistants, except as provided in this article. 
(Code 1992, § 5-7; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-7. - Keeping of dangerous animals. 
    The following animals have been determined by the United States Animal Health Association to be inherently dangerous to humans. It shall be unlawful for anyone to keep any of these animals in the city. The owner or keeper shall also be responsible for removing such animal at his expense. 
(1)  Mammals. 
a.  African buffalo. 
b.  Hippopotamus. 
c.  Wolves, dingos, jackals, all species except foxes. 
d.  Hyenas, all species. 
e.  Wolverine. 
f.  Honey badgers or ratels. 
g.  Bears. 
h.  Lions, jaguars, leopards, tigers. 
i.  Clouded leopards. 
j.  Cheetahs. 
k.  Cougars, mountain lions, pumas. 
l.  Elephants. 
m.  Rhinoceros. 
n.  Gibbons, siamangs. 
o.  Orangutans, chimpanzees, gorillas. 
p.  Baboons, drills, mandrills. 
q.  Macaques. 
r.  Gelada baboons. 
s.  Wild boars. 
(2)  Reptiles. 
a.  Gavials. 
b.  Crocodiles. 
c.  Alligators, caimans. 
d.  Cobras, coral snakes. 
e.  Sea snakes. 
f.  Adders, vipers. 
g.  Pit vipers. 
h.  All venomous rear-fanged species. 
i.  The following species of snakes over eight feet in length: 
1.  Boa constrictors, all subspecies. 
2.  Anacondas. 
3.  Indian pythons. 
4.  Reticulated pythons. 
5.  Rock pythons. 
6.  Gila monsters and beaded lizards. 
7.  Komodo dragons. 
(Code 1992, § 5-8; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-8. - Caring for animals/animal cruelty. 
(a)  All animals, including fowl, which are kept in pens must be housed in a pen of sufficient size that it does not subject the animal or fowl to conditions that constitute cruel mistreatment or cruel neglect. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal to: 
(1)  Fail to provide adequate wholesome, nutritious food and potable water for any animal. 
(2)  Override, overwork, overload, or overdrive any animal, causing physical pain or suffering. 
(3)  Beat, torture, injure, torment, poison, deprive of necessary sustenance, or mutilate any animal causing physical pain, suffering, or death. 
(4)  Fail to provide adequate veterinary medical treatment for any sick, diseased or injured animal. 
(5)  Keep any animal under unsanitary or inhumane conditions which are detrimental to the animal's health and general welfare, and increasing the probability of transmission of disease. 
(6)  Tease, molest, bait, or harass any animal. 
(7)  Release any rabbit, raccoon, fox, or other such animal for the purpose of chasing, hunting, or racing the animal. 
(8)  Promote, permit, stage, hold, manage, conduct, or attend any game, exhibition, contest, fight or combat involving any animal, or animal and human. 
(9)  Fail to provide adequate shelter for any animal depriving them of protection from weather extremes, e.g., heat, cold, rain, wind, and sun. 
(10)  Transport or carry an animal in a motor vehicle unless the animal is safely enclosed within the vehicle or protected by a cab, container, tether, or other device to prevent the animal from falling out or being thrown from the vehicle. 
(11)  Place or confine an animal, or allow an animal to be placed or confined, in a motor vehicle under such conditions or for such a period of time as to endanger the health or welfare of the animal because of temperature, lack of food or water, or such other conditions as may reasonably be expected to cause suffering, disability, or death. 
(12)  Restrain an animal with a leash or humane restraining device that is less than eight feet long, unless walking or training the animal. 
(c)  Any person who unlawfully or maliciously kills, disables, disfigures or injures any animal, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor (Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-241). 
(Code 1992, § 5-9; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals prohibited, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-14. 
Sec. 6-9. - Abandoning animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to transport any domestic animal into the city and subsequently abandon or set loose said animal with the intent to avoid responsibility for its custody and care. 
(Code 1992, § 5-10; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-10. - Tethering near property line. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog to tie, chain or tether such dog so that it has access to public property or the property of another without the consent of the owner or person in charge of such property. 
(Code 1992, § 5-11; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-11. - Sanitation. 
(a)  No owner or custodian of any animal shall cause or allow such animal to soil, defile or defecate on any public property or upon any street, sidewalk, public way, play area or common grounds owned jointly by the members of a homeowners' or condominium association, or upon private property other than that of the owner, unless such owner immediately removes and disposes of all feces deposited by such animal by the following methods: 
(1)  Collection of the feces by appropriate implement and placement in a paper or plastic bag or other container; and 
(2)  Removal of such bag or container to the property of the animal owner or custodian and disposition thereafter in a manner as otherwise may be permitted by law. 
(b)  No person owning, harboring, or keeping an animal within the city shall permit any waste matter from the animal to collect and remain on the property of the owner or custodian, or on the property of others so as to cause or create an unhealthy, unsanitary, dangerous or offensive living condition on the owner's or custodian's property, or to abutting property of others. 
(c)  No person owning, harboring, keeping or in charge of any animal shall cause unsanitary, dangerous or offensive conditions by virtue of the size or number of animals maintained at a single location or due to the inadequacy of the facilities. 
(d)  Removal of dead animals by the city. Whenever a request is made to remove a small or large dead animal, the animal control officer or public works department will dispose of the animal's body in the most efficient method as they see fit. The fee for removal and disposal of a large dead animal shall be as established by the council, from time to time. 
(Code 1992, § 5-12; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 2010-59, § 2, 5-24-2010) 
Sec. 6-12. - Restraint and confinement; generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal to fail to keep such animal under restraint or to permit such animal to run at large upon the streets and public ways of the city. 
(b)  Any dog, while on a street, sidewalk, public way or in any park, public square or other public space, shall be secured by a leash of sufficient strength to restrain the particular dog. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any cat known to such person to habitually cause destruction or damage to the property of another to allow such cat to be at large. 
(d)  Every female dog or cat in heat shall be confined in a building or other enclosure in such a manner that such female dog or cat cannot come into contact with another animal except for planned breeding. 
(Code 1992, § 5-13; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-13. - Noisy animals.
