    It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to confine, harbor, or keep on a residential lot or premises within the city any animal known to such person to habitually, continuously, or intermittently make or emit sounds or noises of such volume and nature as to reasonably interfere with or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort, and repose of persons of ordinary sensibilities within the neighborhood in the reasonable use and enjoyment of their property. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of maintaining a nuisance; provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest made pursuant to this section except upon affidavit made before and warrant issued by a magistrate of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 5-14; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-14. - Keeping of livestock. 
(a)  Minimum lot size. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep livestock in the city limits on any lot smaller than three acres in size. 
(b)  Minimum corral area. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any livestock in any corral in the city, unless such corral shall have a minimum area of 10,000 square feet for one such animal and 1,000 square feet for each additional animal there kept to which every such animal shall have unrestricted access. 
(c)  Distance of stables or corrals from dwellings. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any animal in any corral or stable in the city, any part of which is within 75 feet of a dwelling occupied by a person other than the person keeping such animal, or if such dwelling is not occupied, owned by a person other than the person keeping such animal, provided, that this subsection shall not apply to pastures established prior to May 7, 1974, if continuously so used to the present time. 
(Code 1992, § 5-15; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-15. - Rabies control. 
    The city specifically adopts by reference and incorporates herein as if fully set out Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-7A-2, and any revisions or amendments thereto, which is the law of the state which governs the immunization of dogs and cats for rabies. 
(Code 1992, § 5-16; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-16. - Vicious or dangerous dogs. 
(a)  Defined. As used in this section, the phrase "vicious or dangerous dog" means and includes: 
(1)  Any dog with a propensity, tendency or disposition to attack, cause injury or otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or other domestic animals as evidenced by its habitual or repeated chasing, snapping or barking; 
(2)  Any dog which attacks a human being or another domestic animal without provocation; or 
(3)  Any dog owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting or any dog trained for dog fighting. 
(b)  Running at large prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any vicious or dangerous dog to allow such dog to be at large or unrestrained within the city. 
(c)  Conditions permitting dangerous dogs to be taken off premises. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any vicious or dangerous dog to allow such dog to be at large or off the owner's property unless such dog is securely muzzled so as to effectively prevent such dog from biting another animal or person and unless such dog is secured on a leash or chain of not more than five feet in length that is held or controlled by a person of not less than 16 years of age. 
(d)  Owning/training dogs for fighting or attacking. No person shall own or harbor any dog for the purpose of dog fighting or train, torment, badger, bait or use any dog for the purpose of causing or encouraging such dog to engage in unprovoked attacks upon human beings or domestic animals. 
(e)  Destruction. Any vicious or dangerous dog which attacks a human being or domestic animal may be ordered destroyed when in the judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction the dog represents a continuing threat of serious harm to human beings or domestic animals. 
(f)  Penalty for violations. Violations of the provisions of this section, unless otherwise enumerated, are punishable under section 6-2. 
(g)  Violators liable for expenses. Any person found guilty of violating this section shall pay all expenses, including shelter, food, veterinary expenses for identification or certification of the breed of the animal, or boarding and veterinary expenses necessitated by the seizure of any dog for the protection of the public, and such other expenses as may be required for the destruction of any such dog. 
(h)  Application to police dogs. The provisions of this section shall not have applicability to dogs while engaged in police service training at a recognized and duly licensed facility and under supervision of professional instructors. 
(Code 1992, § 5-17; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
State Law reference- Liability for injury by dog, Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-6-1 et seq. 
Sec. 6-17. - Quarantine, veterinary care and euthanasia. 
(a)  Any dog which is known by the city's animal control officer to have attacked or bitten another domestic animal or human being will be examined by a licensed veterinarian to check for infectious disease, and if it is the opinion of the veterinarian it would be in the best interest of the public to quarantine such animal, such animal may be quarantined. 
(b)  The cost of the veterinary examination and any resulting quarantine shall be payable by the owner of the animal. 
(c)  In addition, the cost of veterinary care for a domestic animal injured or killed by a vicious dog may be charged to the owner of the vicious animal if deemed appropriate by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  Any domestic animal that is injured or diseased will, as an act of mercy, be humanely euthanized immediately after inspection by a veterinarian who determines that euthanasia is necessary to prevent unnecessary suffering or to prevent the spread of disease. 
(Code 1992, § 5-18; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Secs. 6-18-6-37. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING 

Sec. 6-38. - License required for dogs and cats over three months of age. 
(a)  The owner or person in charge of every dog and cat in the city more than three months of age shall register each animal as to sex, breed, description, owner's name and address, and the animal's name, if any. Registration may be done annually or tri-annually. At the time of such registration, such owner or person in charge shall, only after providing proof of valid rabies vaccination of either one year or three years, obtain a license for such dog or cat and shall pay a license fee. The amount of the license fee shall be as established by the mayor and city council, from time to time. Any owner claiming that his dog or cat has been spayed or neutered must show to the satisfaction of the licensing authority that such operation has been performed. 
(b)  Upon the written recommendation of a licensed veterinarian, a waiver may be granted to the rabies vaccination requirement when it is determined that age or health reasons may prevent an animal from safely receiving the same. 
(c)  Each owner or person in charge of every dog or cat in the city who is required by the terms of this section to register said animal shall have 90 days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived to register said animal as required by this section. For any dog or cat acquired after the effective date, the owner or person in charge thereof shall register said animal within 30 days of the animal entering the city. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, owners and operators of private kennels may license all animals housed within any such kennel for an annual registration fee. The amount of the registration fee shall be as established by the council, from time to time. Owners will be required to list and provide proof of rabies vaccination for each animal. Upon payment of the annual license fee, the city will issue a metal tag for each individual animal for no additional fee. The owner of each private kennel will be responsible for timely informing the city of the addition or removal of any animals from the kennel during each registration year. Failure to so inform the city of the addition of animals to any private kennel within 30 days will subject the owner of the kennel to an individual licensing requirement for each animal in the kennel as provided in this section. If timely reported, however, a license tag will be issued by the city for each new animal added to the kennel during the registration year at no additional cost. This provision will not apply to owners of commercial kennels. 
(e)  Each license issued hereunder must be renewed within 30 days of the date of expiration or be subject to a late fee. The amount of the late fee shall be as established by the council, from time to time. 
(Code 1992, § 5-19; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 2010-59, § 3, 5-24-2010) 
Sec. 6-39. - Evidence of license. 
    Evidence of the licensure as issued by the city shall be attached to the animal on a collar and shall be maintained on the licensed animal at all times. 
(Code 1992, § 5-20; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 2010-59, § 4, 5-24-2010) 
Sec. 6-40. - Exemption from license fee. 
    License fees shall not be required for seeing-eye dogs, government police dogs, or dogs belonging to a nonresident of the city and kept within boundaries of the city for not longer than 30 days, provided that all dogs of nonresidents shall at the time of entry into the city be properly vaccinated against rabies, and while kept within the city, meet all the other requirements of this chapter. Any owner claiming any of these exemptions has the burden of proving to the satisfaction of the animal control officer that the dog or cat in question is entitled to such exemption. 
(Code 1992, § 5-21; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009) 
Secs. 6-41-6-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 6-61. - Required care; disposal procedure; citations; notices; animals known to have bitten. 
(a)  Dogs, puppies, cats and kittens with no tag or other identification found at large within the city shall be taken up by the animal control officer who will impound, make arrangements for housing, and provide necessary care for each animal in a humane manner for a period of not less than seven days. 
(b)  Immediately upon impounding dogs, puppies, cats or kittens, the animal control officer shall make a reasonable effort to ascertain the identity of and notify the owners of such animals of the impoundment and of the conditions under which they may regain possession of such animals. 
(c)  Dogs, puppies, cats and kittens not claimed by their owner during confinement by the animal control officer, and before disposition thereof as herein provided, shall become the property of the city and may be disposed of by the animal control officer. 
(d)  When dogs or puppies are found at large and their ownership is known to the animal control officer, such dogs or puppies need not be impounded, but the animal control officer or such officer's duly authorized assistants may, at such officer's discretion, return such animal to the owner and issue a citation to the owner to appear in the municipal court to answer to charges for violations of this article. 
(e)  Feral cats and kittens attained by use of a humane animal trap shall not be housed with any other animals impounded by the animal control officer. Said animals will be taken to a licensed veterinarian to be humanely euthanized for the welfare of personnel and to prevent the spread of disease. 
(Code 1992, § 5-22; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 2010-59, § 5, 5-24-2010) 
Sec. 6-62. - Redemption. 
(a)  The owner of any animal impounded under the provisions of this article may at any time within seven days after the impounding of such animal recover the animal upon the payment to the city for the care and feeding of the animal during its impoundment. 
(b)  The city shall charge for the humane care of all dogs, puppies, cats and kittens housed by the city. The amount charged per day for the care of impounded animals shall be as established by the council, from time to time. 
(c)  When redemption is sought for an animal in the custody of the animal control officer, the owner shall produce a certificate or other satisfactory evidence that such animal has been inoculated for rabies within 12 months prior to being impounded. If such evidence cannot be provided, then before the animal control officer shall release the animal, such animal shall be duly inoculated for rabies at the expense of the owner. 
(d)  The owner of any impounded animal who has not complied with the licensing requirements of this chapter must purchase a license before the animal will be released. 
(Code 1992, § 5-23; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 2010-59, § 6, 5-24-2010) 
Sec. 6-63. - Adoption and fostering. 
    Seven days after the impoundment of any animal, the animal control officer may give custody of such animal to the Madison Animal Rescue Foundation or other similarly situated and responsible organization which shall have been established and equipped to provide fostering and adoption services for impounded, abandoned and surrendered animals. The receiving organization shall not be required to pay any fees or to reimburse the city for any other expenses associated with the impoundment of the animal, but shall agree to provide for the sterilization and inoculation of the animal as soon as the health and age of the animal allow. 
(Code 1992, § 5-24; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 2010-59, § 7, 5-24-2010) 
Sec. 6-64. - Collection and disposition of fees. 
    All monies collected as provided for in this article shall be collected by the city police department and, to the extent allowed, shall be allocated and used for the operation of the animal control division. 
(Code 1992, § 5-25; Ord. No. 2009-77, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 2010-59, § 8, 5-24-2010) 
Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS, CONSTRUCTION AND RELATED ACTIVITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt codes by reference, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-8; state building construction standards, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-9-160 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Compliance with codes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, business, corporation or partnership, who constructs, erects, alters, enlarges, improves, or changes any structure or building within the city to fail to comply with the requirements set forth in the International Codes and National Electrical Code, herein adopted as modified, altered, deleted and amended. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-1, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-2. - Unlawful occupation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, firm, business, corporation or partnership to occupy any structure or building or cause same to be occupied, whether owned, leased or rented, without a certificate of occupancy issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-2, 4-11-2011) 
Secs. 8-3-8-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 8-23. - Licensing and permits. 
    No permit required by this chapter shall be issued to any individual, firm, organization, corporation or partnership, association, or other entity that is not properly licensed as a contractor by the city nor shall any permit required by this chapter be issued without express written authority of the building owner or landowner. It shall be unlawful for any individual, firm, organization, corporation or partnership or other entity to engage in the construction of any structure or building including erection, alteration, enlargement, improvement or changes to any building or structure or any portion thereof within the city without first obtaining a business license issued by the revenue department of the city and a state contractor's license unless specifically exempted by state statute, rules or regulations. This section does not preclude or prevent an owner from obtaining permits and performing work on their own property except that any person, firm or corporation hired or contracted by the owner must possess a valid city business license and state license as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-3, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-24. - More stringent or restrictive provision prevails. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be cumulative and shall not be construed to repeal or to supersede any rule or regulation setting forth standards more stringent or restrictive than those adopted herein. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-4, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-25. - Violations; punishment, stop work order. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or the codes as modified and amended and adopted hereunder shall be guilty of violation of a city ordinance and shall upon conviction thereof be punished as provided in section 1-8. The exaction of one penalty violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; provided, however, that any building inspector or code enforcement officer may issue a stop work order at any time such inspector or officer has reason to believe that any provision of this chapter has been violated. Upon issuance of a stop work order, all construction personnel will leave the site, except those necessary to correct the violation that prompted the order or to ensure the protection of the structure and occupants, if occupied, to ensure the health, welfare and safety of the occupants. No further work will be done until the violation is corrected, and the stop work order rescinded by either the director of building, deputy building official, code enforcement officer or as otherwise provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-5, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-26. - Appeals. 
    Whenever under this chapter, or any of the various codes adopted herein, it is alleged that there is an error in any decision, order, grant of permit, refusal to grant permit, or any other requirement or determination made by any official, building official, department head, agency or other authority charged with enforcement of or decision-making power under this chapter, any person aggrieved including any official, building official, department head, agency or other authority of the municipality shall have the right to administrative review before the construction board of appeals, in accordance with procedures prescribed in the International Codes as adopted herein. Application for review or appeal shall be in made in writing within 20 days after the code official's determination, notice, order or alleged error in any decision on forms provided for such purpose and obtained from the building department. In authorizing appeals and administrative review in accordance with this section, it is deemed to be the intent of the city that this chapter be uniformly applied to all persons who come under its regulations and that any aggrieved person, as well as the city officials involved, are provided with a vehicle for administrative review. The construction board of appeals shall have no authority to waive requirements of the codes or any sections therein. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-6, 4-11-2011) 
Secs. 8-27-8-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION BOARD OF APPEALS 

Sec. 8-47. - Terms. 
    The construction board of appeals shall consist of seven members appointed by the chief appointing authority, two of which shall be appointed as alternates, to serve as follows: 
Place Number Number of Years in Initial Term of Appointment Place 1 5 years Place 2 4 years Place 3 3 years Place 4 2 years Place 5 1 year Alternate 1 5 years Alternate 2 5 years  
Thereafter, each new member shall serve for five years or until a successor has been appointed. The two appointed alternates shall serve for five years. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-7, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-48. - Qualifications. 
    The seven members of the construction board of appeals shall each possess one of the following qualifications: 
(1)  Registered design professional who is a registered architect or a builder or superintendent of building construction with at least ten years' experience, five years of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(2)  Registered design professional with structural engineering or architectural experience. 
(3)  Registered design professional with mechanical and plumbing engineering experience or a mechanical and plumbing contractor with at least ten years' experience, five years of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(4)  Registered design professional with electrical engineering experience; or an electrical contractor with at least ten years' experience, five years of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(5)  Registered design professional with fire protection engineering experience; or a fire protection contractor with at least ten years' experience, five years of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-7-1, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-49. - Members. 
    The board members shall annually select one of its members to serve as chairperson. A board secretary shall be designated by the director of building. The board secretary shall record and maintain a detailed file of all proceedings. A member shall not hear an appeal in which that member has any personal, professional or financial interest. Alternate members shall attend all organizational and educational meetings. Other than organizational and educational meetings, Alternate members shall attend meetings to hear appeals whenever required and called by the board chair. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-7-2, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-50. - Meetings. 
    The board shall meet upon notice from the secretary or chairperson, within 20 days of the filing of an appeal or at stated periodic meetings, whichever is sooner. All hearings before the board shall be open to the public. The appellant, the appellant's representative, the code official and any other person whose interests are affected shall be given an opportunity to be heard and present to the board documentation, facts or suggestions for alternative methods to meet or exceed minimum code requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-7-3, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-51. - Procedures. 
    The board shall adopt and make available to the public, procedures under which a hearing will be conducted. Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall apply. The procedures shall not require compliance with strict rules of evidence, but shall mandate that only relevant information be received. When two of the five members are not present to hear an appeal, either the appellant or the appellant's representative shall have the right to request a postponement of the hearing. The board shall modify or reverse the decision of the code official by a concurring vote of three members. The decision of the board shall be by resolution. Certified copies of decisions shall be furnished to the appellant and to the code official. The code official shall take immediate action, if any, in accordance with the decision of the board. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-7-4, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-52. - Contractors; payment of license tax; registration of name liability insurance. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every contractor, subcontractor, builder, electrical contractor, plumbing contractor, gas contractor, and mechanical contractor, who shall make contracts for the erection or construction or alteration or repair of buildings, or builder making such contracts and subletting the same, or any part thereof, to pay a city license tax as provided in the general license code and to register such person's name in a book or database provided for that purpose with the revenue department of the city, giving full name, residence, and place of business, and in case of removal from one place to another in the city, to have made corresponding changes in such register accordingly. 
(b)  Any person engaged as a contractor, subcontractor, builder, electrical contractor, plumbing contractor, gas contractor or mechanical contractor shall be covered by a public liability insurance policy to include the coverage known as manufacturers and contractors liability and products and completed operations, issued by a solvent insurance company, licensed to do business in the state. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-8, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-53. - Contractor identification. 
    No contractor, subcontractor or licensee as regulated in this chapter shall operate in connection with the prosecution of its work or business within the city any truck or automobile without displaying on each door panel thereof the name, address and telephone number of such contractor, subcontractor or licensee in letters of not less than two inches in height. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-9, 4-11-2011) 
Secs. 8-54-8-73. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REGULATIONS AND STANDARDS 

Sec. 8-74. - Disposal of solid waste. 
    All construction sites in the city are to be supplied with a receptacle for trash, garbage and construction debris. All trash, garbage and construction debris or waste shall be disposed of in such receptacles. In no case may any trash, garbage or construction debris or waste be allowed to be dumped, blown, thrown or otherwise conveyed beyond the lot lines of the lot or parcel under construction. No pits are to be excavated on any construction site for the purpose of disposal and burying of trash, garbage or construction debris or waste. All trash, garbage and construction debris or waste are to be disposed of at approved construction or sanitary landfills. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-10, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-75. - Landscaping bonds. 
(a)  In the event that inclement weather makes the site work on or landscaping of a parcel undergoing improvement or construction impossible or impractical, the director of building may cause a certificate of occupancy for the structure under construction to be issued upon making the following findings: 
(1)  That all required inspections of the structure have been completed and approved by the department; 
(2)  A list of all subcontractors who participated in the construction of the structure has been submitted to the department, and all of said subcontractors have been determined to have a valid city business privilege license; 
(3)  All required fees have been paid; 
(4)  The engineering inspector under purview of the director of building has made a written recommendation to the director of building as to the cost of completing the site work and landscaping; and 
(5)  A landscape guarantee, in the amount of 150 percent of the projected completion cost, as approved by the planning department, has been posted. 
(b)  The landscape guarantee required by subsection (a)(5) of this section shall consist of a landscape bond executed by the principal in favor of the city, secured by cash, a certified check, bank check, letter of credit, or other acceptable form of security, unless alternative forms of the guarantee or security are approved by the city attorney. 
(c)  In the event that the engineering inspector approves the site work and landscaping that has been guaranteed pursuant to this section within 180 days, the instrument of guarantee shall be returned to the person or corporation posting it, and the letter of agreement shall be marked "satisfied," signed and dated by the director of building. A copy of the letter marked "satisfied" shall be retained in the records of the building department. 
(d)  In the event that the engineering inspector approves the site work and landscaping that has been guaranteed pursuant to this section within 180 days, the city shall convert the instrument of guarantee to cash, and shall contract for the completion of the guaranteed work. In contracting for said work, the city shall follow normal purchasing guidelines, as though the work were being done for the city. Any excess proceeds from the instrument of guarantee not needed to complete the minimum site work and landscaping required to cause the subject parcel to pass engineering inspection shall be returned to the person or corporation posting the guarantee by the building department. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-11, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-76. - Proper disposal of roofing shingles and felt or tar paper. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this section to dispose of roofing shingles, roofing felt, or tar paper anywhere in the city other than in a landfill approved by the state department of environmental management. 
(b)  All general contractors, residential homebuilders, and roofing subcontractors shall at the time of application for a building permit to remove an old roof and install a new roof, declare such on the permit application and indicate an estimated completion date for the job permitted. 
(c)  Upon the issuance of a permit to perform work that includes the removal and/or discarding of roofing material, the director of building shall establish a file recording the date, building permit number, contractor's name and business privilege license number and other pertinent information. 
(d)  The contractor shall retain, for one year after completion of the work permitted, business records reasonably sufficient to establish the method of disposal of the discarded roofing material resulting from the work permitted. Reasonable verification shall include a receipt or other written statement from an ADEM approved landfill, contractor's business records, disposer's business records, business records of the entity receiving the materials, or other written document acceptable to the revenue director of the city. 
(e)  The contractor shall report completion of all roofing jobs to the building department within two business days after completion. The director of building shall, at his discretion, cause an inspection of the work to be made within two business days after notification. The date of notification of completion shall be noted in the file established pursuant to the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. 
(f)  The director of revenue of the city is hereby authorized and directed to include, in any and all business taxation audits of general contractors, residential homebuilders, and roofing subcontractors, a review of documentation that establishes compliance with subsection (a) of this section. Such documentation shall include, but not be limited to, those forms of documentation enumerated in subsection (d) of this section. It shall be a violation of this section to fail to provide such information to the revenue director within two business days after the request. 
(g)  Violation of this section shall be punishable by a minimum fine of $500.00 per occurrence. An occurrence is defined as the improper disposal of roofing materials as defined in subsection (a) of this section or the inability or unwillingness to provide documentation of proper disposal of roofing material when required by the revenue director pursuant to this section. Failure to provide documentation of proper disposal for each roofing permit for which the request is made shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-12, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-77. - Grading of land. 
(a)  Violation declared. It shall be a violation of this section to: 
(1)  Excavate, fill dredge, alter the topography of, or grade any land in the city except: 
a.  Pursuant to a site plan approved by the planning commission. 
b.  Pursuant to a preliminary subdivision plat approved by the planning commission. 
c.  Pursuant to a building permit issued by the building department of the city and this section. 
d.  Pursuant to and in conformity with a grading permit approved and issued by the engineering department for any approved subdivision of the city and this section. 
e.  In the conduct of any agricultural activity. 
f.  For the purpose of burial within approved human and animal cemeteries. 
g.  For an excavation or fill that satisfies all of the following criteria: 
1.  Will not result in a total area of land disturbance of less than one acre; 
2.  Will not, in the opinion of the director of engineering or his designee, impair existing surface drainage, constitute a potential erosion hazard, or act as a source of sedimentation to adjacent land, watercourses, roads, the municipal storm sewer system, or other features or facilities; 
3.  Will have no fill placed on any slope greater than three feet horizontal to one foot vertical; and 
4.  Will have no final slopes steeper than three feet horizontal to one foot vertical. 
h.  For grading performed for the purpose of repair or maintenance, when such grading is performed: 
1.  In connection with the construction, improvement, or repair of any structure within a development for which an approved grading, drainage and erosion control plan exists; or 
2.  As a maintenance measure, or for home gardens, or for landscaping on developed lots or parcels with an existing principal structure, provided all of the following criteria are met: 
(i)  The aggregate area affected or stripped at any one time does not exceed one acre and is not within a natural drainageway; 
(ii)  The grade change does not exceed 18 inches at any point and does not alter the direction of drainage flow; 
(iii)  Proper vegetative cover is reestablished as soon as possible on all disturbed areas; and 
i.  For the installation of any water, sewer, telephone, electric, gas, or other utility lines or other public utility facility. 
j.  For any project performed by the city or other governmental entity, or performed by any individual, firm, corporation or other entity pursuant to a contract with any governmental entity. 
k.  For lawful commercial mineral extraction activities that have been licensed by the city, including filling, grading, excavation or other alteration of the land in conjunction with closure of or removal of detritus from any formerly licensed site from which mineral matter has been lawfully extracted at any point in the past. 
l.  For rough grading of any lot not in excess of one acre in a recorded subdivision. 
(2)  Excavate, fill, dredge, alter the topography of, or grade any land in the city in violation of this section, or regulations promulgated by the state or federal authorities pursuant to the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System Program, or any permit, including any municipal permit, issued in connection therewith. 
(b)  Permit required. 
(1)  When required. Any individual, firm, corporation, partnership or other legal entity must obtain approval for a grading permit from the director of engineering of the city prior to commencing any excavation, filling, dredging, alteration of topography, or grading of any land in the city, unless exempted by this section; provided, however, that when such exemption is based on the provisions of subsection (a)(1)a.-c. of this section, then if the approval on which the exemption is based expires before the grading or other operation has been completed, the expired approval must be extended or otherwise reinstated, or the landowner must apply for and receive a grading permit for the work. 
(2)  Standards for issuance. A grading permit will be approved by the engineering department of the city upon demonstration by the applicant that: 
a.  No organic or decaying matter of any type whatsoever will be used in any fill operation, and that precautions to prevent the illicit dumping thereof will be taken by the applicant. 
b.  The grading, dredging, excavations, filling or other plan conforms in all respects to all applicable provisions of the city's adopted comprehensive plan, as well as the city's drainage master plan, zoning appendix, flood insurance rate maps and flood hazard district regulations, construction standards specifications manual, this section, and all other applicable regulations. 
c.  The area to be graded, dredged, filled, excavated or otherwise altered will be stabilized with silt fences, hay bales and other erosion control methods during and after the operation, until vegetation has matured sufficiently to control erosion to the satisfaction of the director of engineering or his designee. 
d.  The director of engineering is hereby authorized to require the submittal of the following documents that demonstrate compliance with this subsection: 
1.  Vicinity map. 
2.  Topographical map at a scale of no less than one inch equals 100 feet, or at such other scale so as to indicate clearly the work proposed. Contour intervals must be no greater than two feet. 
3.  A tree plat, if required by city ordinance or this Code. 
4.  Location of existing structures, watercourses, and other major physical features. 
5.  Topographical map with proposed grades and contours upon completion at two-foot intervals. 
6.  Proposed drainage plan, including structural improvements, drainage arrows, and, if deemed necessary by the director of engineering, drainage calculations based on the ten-year type II rainfall event. 
7.  Plan for the temporary and permanent control of erosion and sediment. 
8.  Schedule of work that indicates a time sequence for the installation of temporary erosion control measures, the grading work itself, and the installation of permanent erosion control measures. This schedule must indicate the sequence of work only, and not the actual completion date. 
9.  Certification of plans submitted under this section by a registered engineer, landscape architect, or land surveyor. 
(3)  Fees, time limits. The engineering department of the city shall accept, process and review all applications and plans for grading permits and, upon approval, refer payment of permits to the building department, which shall collect a fee for each grading permit issued. Grading permits shall remain valid for six months from the date of issuance and may be renewed once at no cost for an additional six months. However, any expired permit may be reapplied for by resubmitting all required documents and paying a new permit fee. The amount of the grading permit fee shall be as established by the mayor and city council, from time to time. 
(c)  Enforcement. The city shall rely on representations made in the grading permit application and all supporting documents, and it shall be a violation of this section to grade, fill dredge, excavate or otherwise alter any land in any way that is inconsistent with representations made in the approved permit application. If the director of engineering determines that the work being performed is in any way inconsistent with said representations, he shall, after giving 24 hours written notice to the landowner, have the authority to seek revocation of the permit and order all workers to leave the site. Failure of the landowner to stop work upon the order of the director of engineering, or the commission of any other act prohibited by this section shall be punished as a misdemeanor under section 1-9. 
(d)  Appeals. Any applicant for a grading permit may appeal any decision of the director of engineering with respect to that application. The appeal will fall to the construction board of appeals and must be presented in writing to the director of building within 20 days after the action for which the appeal is based. The ordinances and rules governing the authority and procedures of the construction board of appeals shall govern the appeal process. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-13, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 8-78. - Key lock box system. 
(a)  The following structures/facilities shall be equipped with a key lock box at or near the main entrance or such other location required by the fire marshal: 
(1)  Multifamily residential structures that have restricted access through locked doors and have a common corridor for access to the living units. 
(2)  Government structures and nursing facilities. 
(b)  Residential communities or developments approved by the planning commission for gate-restricted access must have key lock box access to all entrances and the entrances with electronic access must open automatically in the event of power loss. 
(c)  All newly constructed structures/facilities subject to this section shall have the key lock box installed and operational prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(d)  All structures in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived and subject to this section shall have 60 days from the effective date to have a key lock box installed and operational. 
(e)  Residential communities or developments already gated on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall have 60 days from the effective date to have a key lock box installed and operational. 
(f)  Industrial and commercial occupancies protected by an automatic alarm system or automatic suppression system may participate in the lock box program on a voluntary basis. 
(g)  The fire marshal shall designate the type of key lock box system to implement within the city and shall have the authority to require all structures/facilities described above to use the designated system. 
(h)  The owner or operator of the structure/facility required to have a key lock box shall, at all times, keep a key in the lock box that will allow for access to the structure. 
(i)  The fire marshal shall be authorized to implement rules and regulations for the use of the lock box system, subject to notification and approval of the mayor. 
(j)  Any person who owns or operates a structure subject to this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in this section for any violation of this section, provided that the minimum fine for the conviction for a violation of this section shall be $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-14, 4-11-2011) 
Secs. 8-79-8-98. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 8-99. - Codes adopted. 
    That certain documents, three copies of which are on file in the office of the director of building of the city being marked and designated as the: 
(1)  International Building Code, 2009 Edition, including Appendices A, B, C, F, and H (as amended herein); 
(2)  Accessible and Usable Buildings and Facilities, ICC A117.1-2009 (American National Standard); 
(3)  International Residential Code, 2006 Edition, including Appendices A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, J, K, M, N, O, and Q (as amended herein); 
(4)  International Fuel Gas Code, 2009 Edition including Appendices A, B, C, and D; 
(5)  International Fire Code, 2009 Edition, including Appendices; 
(6)  International Plumbing Code, 2009 Edition, including Appendices B, C, D, E, F, and G; 
(7)  International Mechanical Code, 2009 Edition, including Appendix A; 
(8)  National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition; 
(9)  International Property Maintenance Code, 2009 Edition; 
(10)  International Energy Conservation Code, 2009 Edition, including Appendices, as that edition pertains to commercial structures, as well as the International Energy Conservation Code, 2015 Edition, as it pertains to residential structures and has been codified in §305-2-4-.10 of the Alabama Administrative Code; and 
(11)  National Green Building Standard, ICC 700-2008; 
as such are modified and amended herein, are hereby adopted as the building code of the city for regulating and governing the construction, conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the demolition of such structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said building code on file in the office of the director of building of the city are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part thereof, if fully set out in this Code, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 8-100. 
(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-15, 4-11-2011; Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 8-100. - Amendments. 
    The following sections of the codes adopted in section 8-99 are amended as follows: 
(1)  International Building Code, 2009 Edition. The International Building Code is hereby amended as follows: 
a.  Section 103, entitled "Department of Building Safety," is changed to read: 
"Section 103 Department of Building." 
b.  Section 103.1, entitled "Creation of Enforcement Agency," is changed to read: 
"The Department of Building is hereby created and the official in charge thereof shall be known as the Director of Building and Chief Building Official of the City. Wherever used in the adopted codes, the titles of Director of Building and Building Official shall have meaning as one and the same person." 
c.  Section 103.2, entitled "Appointment," is deleted. 
d.  Section 103.3, entitled "Deputies," is changed to read: 
"In accordance with the policies and procedures of the city and with the concurrence of the appointing authority, the Director of Building and Chief Building Official shall have the authority to designate specific responsibilities and delegate certain tasks to the Deputy Building Official, Code Enforcement Officers, technical inspectors, building inspectors, plan reviewers and other department employees as deemed necessary and relating to building code administration, permitting, inspections, code enforcement and property maintenance. Such employees shall have powers as delegated by the Director of Building." 
e.  Section 104.12 is added, to read as follows: 
"Notwithstanding any other provision to the contrary, the Fire Chief or authorized designee shall consult with the Director of Building on all matters of fire and life safety, and shall make the determination and with respect to any matter covered by the International Fire Code. No building permit, except for one and two family dwellings, shall be issued until approved in writing by the fire chief or his designee." 
f.  Section 105.1.1, entitled "Annual Permit," is deleted. 
g.  Section 105.1.2, entitled "Annual permit records," is deleted. 
h.  Section 105.2, entitled 'Work exempt from permit' under the subheading entitled 'Building,' paragraphs 2 and 4 are deleted in their entireties. 
i.  Section 105.2, entitled "Work exempt from permit" under the subsection entitled "Building," paragraph 14, is added to read: 
"14. Any other fixed or nonfixed interior partitions, premanufactured cubicles or similar furnishings not over 5 feet 9 inches in height and installed or situated in a manner not to interfere with or block required egress access, egress pathways, or otherwise violate any other fire or life safety mandatory requirements. Plans or details may be required to verify exemption from permit requirements." 
j.  Section 105.2, entitled "Work exempt from permit" under the subsections entitled "Electrical" and "Repairs and maintenance," has the following wording added: 
"The minor replacement of defective light switches or light fixtures and ceiling fan fixtures where no special knowledge or no additional wiring or branch circuits are required is exempt from permitting." 
k.  Section 109.4, entitled "Work commencing before permit issuance," is changed to read: 
"Any person, contractor, firm or corporation who commences any work on a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system before obtaining the necessary permits shall be subject to a fee equal to twice the calculated permit fee, such fee to be paid in addition to the required permit fee. Failure to pay required fees shall be deemed a violation of the City Code of Ordinances and subject to penalties and fines as permitted by law." 
l.  Section 111.1, entitled "Use and occupancy," Section 111.1.1, is added to read: 
"Section 111.1.1 Certificates of Completion. In shell structures where interior tenant spaces are unfinished or where spaces are finished in anticipation of a future tenant and the use or occupancy of the building or tenant space or spaces therein have not been established, a Certificate of Completion may be issued subject to completion of the exterior of the building and an approved final inspection, including compliance with regard to accessibility, landscaping, parking, drainage and any other provisions as required by the jurisdiction shall be obtained. " 
m.  Section 113, entitled "Board of Appeals," is changed to read: 
"Section 113 Construction Board of Appeals." 
n.  Section 113.4, entitled "Code Appeals," is inserted following Section 113.3 to read as follows: 
"Section 113.4 Code Appeals. The Construction Board of Appeals shall have the authority to hear and decide appeals from orders, decisions, or determinations made by the Building Official or Fire Marshal relative to any of the following codes: 
International Building Code, 2009 Edition, including appendices adopted and amended herein; 
Accessible and Usable Buildings and Facilities, ICC A117.1-2009 (American National Standard) as adopted and amended herein; 
International Residential Code, 2006 Edition, including appendices as adopted and amended herein; 
International Fuel Gas Code, 2009 Edition as adopted and amended herein; 
International Fire Code, 2009 Edition, including appendices as adopted and amended herein; 
International Plumbing Code, 2009 Edition, including appendices as adopted and amended herein; 
International Mechanical Code, 2009 Edition, including appendices as adopted and amended herein; 
International Property Maintenance Code, 2009 Edition as adopted and amended herein; 
International Energy Conservation Code, 2009 Edition as adopted and amended herein; 
National Green Building Standard, ICC 700-2008 as adopted and amended herein;" 
o.  Section 117, entitled "Construction Site Conditions," is inserted with subsections to read as follows: 
"Section 117.1 Sanitary conditions. Every construction site shall be provided with portable restroom facilities during construction and until a Certificate of Occupancy has been issued. 
Section 117.2 Rubbish and debris. Every construction site shall be maintained free of trash, rubbish and construction debris at all times. Trash, rubbish and construction debris shall be placed in waste containers approved for such use. Waste containers shall not be placed or otherwise maintained upon or within any roadway or sidewalk within the city. All trash, rubbish and construction debris and containers shall be removed from the site before receiving an approved final inspection and a Certificate of Occupancy issued. The onsite or offsite burial of trash, rubbish and construction debris, except at approved landfills, is prohibited and subject to fines or penalties as permitted by law. 
Section 117.3 Site grading. The grading of construction sites shall be in accordance with approved and recorded site plans and meet other requirements as outlined in Section 6-13 of this ordinance. 
Section 117.4 Landscaping and finished grades. Each site shall be graded such that stormwater run-off is directed away from the structure's foundation and to approved swales and drainageways. To prevent the accumulation of water in crawlspaces of elevated structures, the interior grade of all crawlspaces shall be at least equal to or higher in elevation than the finished or anticipated finished exterior grade elevation after all landscaping has been completed. 
Section 117.5 Roads, streets, sidewalks and alleys. All public roads, streets, sidewalks and alleys shall be maintained free of accumulation of dirt, mud, silt and other organic debris throughout construction. Whenever mud from a construction site is being deposited on a public road, street, sidewalk or alley by construction vehicles, through erosion, siltation or other means so as to create hazardous driving conditions, the Director of Building may issue a Stop Work Order or take whatever action deemed appropriate in accordance with Section 6-5 of this ordinance." 
p.  Section 419.1.1, entitled "Limitations," the following paragraphs are added to read: 
1.  The Live/Work unit must meet all zoning requirements of the district in which it is located. 
2.  The use or occupancy of a Live/Work unit as institutional, hazardous, factory-industrial, high hazard storage (S-1) or assembly occupancy with a combined occupant load greater than 50 persons is prohibited in residential subdivisions. 
3.  The work area and other related areas of the work area of a Live/Work unit shall comply with Chapter 11 of this code for accessibility. 
4.  The work area of the Live/Work unit shall comply with Chapter 29 of this code regarding minimum plumbing facilities required based on the use and occupancy of the work area." 
q.  Section 109.1.1 is hereby added and shall read as follows: 
Exemption from fees. All permit fees required by Section 109.1 shall be waived for each properly submitted application requesting a permit for the interior or exterior demolition of any building or structure located within the Downtown Redevelopment District as that area is more specifically set forth and identified within the city Zoning Ordinance. 
r.  Section 107.1, entitled 'General,' is changed to read: 
    Submittal documents consisting of construction documents, statement of special inspections, geotechnical report and other data shall be submitted in four or more sets with each permit application. The construction documents for all work as described in Section 101.2 of this code shall be prepared by an Alabama registered design professional. Where special conditions exist, the building official is authorized to require additional construction documents to be prepared by an Alabama registered design professional. 
    Exception: The building official is authorized to waive the submission of construction documents and other data not required to be prepared by an Alabama registered design professional if it is found that the nature of the work applied for is such that review of construction documents is not necessary to determine compliance with this code. 
(2)  International Residential Code, 2006 Edition. The International Residential Code is hereby amended as follows: 
a.  Section R103, entitled "Department of Building Safety," is changed to read: 
"Section R103 Department of Building". 
b.  Section R103.1, entitled "Creation of Enforcement Agency," is changed to read: 
"The Department of Building is hereby created and the official in charge thereof shall be known as the Director of Building and Chief Building Official of the City. Wherever used in the adopted codes, the titles of Director of Building and Building Official shall have meaning as one and the same person." 
c.  Section R103.2 entitled "Appointment" is deleted. 
d.  Section R103.3, entitled "Deputies," is changed to read: 
"In accordance with the policies and procedures of the city and with the concurrence of the appointing authority, the Director of Building and Chief Building Official shall have the authority to designate specific responsibilities and certain tasks to the Deputy Building Official, Code Enforcement Officers, technical inspectors, building inspectors, plan reviewers and other department employees as deemed necessary and relating to building code administration, permitting, inspections, code enforcement and property maintenance. Such employees shall have powers as delegated by the Director of Building." 
e.  Section R104.12, entitled "Concurrent approvals," is inserted after Section R104.11 to read as follows: 
"Notwithstanding any other provision to the contrary, the Fire Chief or authorized designee shall consult with the Director of Building on all matters of fire and life safety, and shall make the determination with respect to any matter covered by the International Fire Code." 
f.  Section R105.2, entitled "Work exempt from permit" under the subheading entitled "Building," paragraph 1, is changed to read: 
"One-story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the floor area does not exceed 200 square feet." 
g.  "Section R105.2, entitled 'Work exempt from permit,' under the subheading entitled 'Building,' paragraphs 2 and 3 are deleted in their entireties." 
h.  Section R105.2, entitled "Work exempt from permit" under the subheading entitled "Building," the following paragraphs are inserted following paragraph 9 to read: 
1.  The repair, maintenance or replacement of fascia boards, fascia coverings, soffits not exceeding 100 square feet in size, roof gutters, leaders and associated roof drains is exempt from permitting." 
2.  The minor repair or replacement of roof shingles not exceeding 25 square feet in aggregate size and the replacement of exterior siding not exceeding 100 square feet in aggregate size is exempt from permitting." 
i.  Section R105.2, entitled "Work exempt from permit" under the subsections entitled "Electrical" the subsection and paragraph entitled "Repairs and maintenance," is changed to read: 
"Minor electrical repair work including minor replacement of lamps, defective light switches, receptacles, light fixtures and ceiling fan fixtures, or the connection of approved portable electrical equipment to approved permanently installed receptacles where no special knowledge or additional wiring or additional branch circuits are required or installed is exempt from permitting." 
j.  Section R105.2, entitled "Work exempt from permit," the following heading is inserted: 
"Plumbing." 
k.  Section R105.2, entitled "Work exempt from permit" under the new heading entitled "Plumbing," the following paragraphs are revised and numbered to read: 
1.  The stopping of leaks in drains, water, soil, waste or vent pipe; provided however, that if any concealed trap, drainpipe, water, soil, waste or vent pipe becomes defective and it becomes necessary to remove and replace the same with new material, such work shall be considered as new work and a permit shall be obtained and inspection made as provided in this code. 
2.  The clearing of stoppages or the repairing of leaks in pipes, valves or fixtures, and the removal and installation of water closets, provided such repairs do not involve or require the replacement or rearrangement or relocation of pipes." 
l.  Section R105.5, entitled "Expiration," is changed to read: 
"Every permit issued shall become invalid unless the work authorized by such permit is commenced within 180 days after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of 180 days after the work is commenced. Records of inspections maintained within the Building Department documenting the last known inspection of work shall be used to determine suspension or abandonment of permitted work. The Director of Building is authorized to grant, in writing, one or more extensions of time for periods not more than 180 days each. The extension shall be requested in writing by the contractor or property owner who obtained the permit. A Stop Work Order shall be issued whenever a permit has expired and a request for an extension of the permit has not been submitted to the Building Department. No fee shall be charged for the first 180 day extension of an expired permit whereby the work has been suspended or abandoned. However, an administrative permit renewal fee equal to .25 multiplied by the original permit fee will be due and payable to the city for any extensions beyond the first 180 day extension period. No inspections may be scheduled nor performed relating to any expired permit." 
m.  Section R108.1, entitled "Payment of fees," is changed to read: 
"A permit shall not be valid until the fees prescribed by ordinance have been paid as required. Any person, contractor, firm or corporation who commences any work on a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system before obtaining the necessary permits shall be subject to a fee equal to twice the calculated permit fee, such fee to be paid in addition to the required permit fee. Failure to pay required fees shall be deemed a violation of the City Code of Ordinances and subject to penalties and fines as permitted by law." 
n.  Section R110.1, entitled "Use and Occupancy," is changed to read: 
"No person or persons shall occupy or use any building or structure or cause the same to be done, and no change in the existing occupancy classification or use of a building or structure or portion thereof shall be made until the Building Official has issued a Certificate of Occupancy or has approved in writing such change on occupancy or use therefor as provided herein. The unauthorized use or occupancy of a building or structure without first obtaining a Certificate of Occupancy or written approval is deemed a violation of the codes and subject to fines and penalties as prescribed in Section 1-8 of the City Code of Ordinances. The Director of Building is authorized to order disconnection of power and other utilities and cause the same to be done whenever it is determined that an unoccupied building or structure has been sold or conveyed without a Certificate of Occupancy and the building or structure is in the process of being used or occupied (i.e. furnishing being placed in the building). Issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy shall not be construed as an approval of a violation of the provisions of this code or of other ordinances of the jurisdiction. Certificates presuming to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the jurisdiction shall not be valid. 
Exceptions: 
(i)  Certificates of Occupancy are not required for work exempt from permits under Section R105.2 or as determined by the Director of Building. 
(ii)  Accessory buildings or structures which do not contain a dwelling unit or sleeping unit as defined by this code shall be issued a Certificate of Completion. 
(iii)  Permits for minor repairs and alterations to electrical, mechanical, gas and plumbing systems which do not alter the type of use of the building or tenant space." 
o.  Section 325, entitled "Fire protection for Multiple Single Family Dwellings (Townhouses)," is hereby added immediately following Section 324 to read: 
"Notwithstanding any other State or Federal rule, regulation or law to the contrary, attached single-family dwellings (townhouses) shall be required to have an automatic sprinkler system meeting the requirements of the National Fire Protection Association Standard 13D, Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems in One- and Two-Family Dwellings and Manufactured Housing. At the discretion of the Fire Marshal, a single combination water supply shall be permitted."

(4)  International Fire Code, 2009 Edition. The International Fire Code is hereby amended as follows: 
a.  Section 104.2, entitled "Applications and Permits," is hereby amended to read as follows: 
"The fire code official is authorized to receive applications, review documents and issue fire related regulatory and operational permits regulated by this code, inspect the premises for which such permits have been issued and enforce compliance with the provisions of this code." 
b.  Section 105, entitled "Permits," and all subsections thereof, are deleted in their entirety. 
c.  Section 109.3, entitled "Violations," is deleted in its entirety and in lieu and substitution thereof is inserted the following Section 109.3: 
"Section 109.3 Violation Penalties. 
Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment not exceeding six months, or both such fine or imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense." 
d.  Section 403.2.2, entitled "Special Rules for Festival and non-fixed seating in Assembly Occupancies," is inserted in Section 403.2 to read as follows: 
1.  Assembly occupancies over 1,200 square feet using non-fixed seating will submit a plan for seating arrangement to the fire code official for approval. The provisions and limitations for securing seating in assembly occupancies as outlined in Section 1028.12 of the 2009 International Building Code shall apply. 
2.  Festival seating, defined as seating whereby occupants or venue participants provide their own seating, is prohibited in any assembly occupancy not protected by an approved fire sprinkler system. Festival seating in assembly occupancies protected by an approved fire sprinkler system may be approved at the discretion of the fire code official on a case-by-case basis for special events only."

The stopping of leaks in drains, water, soil, waste or vent pipe; provided however, that if any concealed trap, drainpipe, water, soil, waste or vent pipe becomes defective and it becomes necessary to remove and replace the same with new material, such work shall be considered as new work and a permit shall be obtained and inspection made as provided in this code.

"Every permit issued shall become invalid unless the work authorized by such permit is commenced within 180 days after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of 180 days after the work is commenced. Records of inspections documenting the last known inspection of work shall be used to determine suspension or abandonment of permitted work. The extension shall be requested in writing by the contractor or property owner who obtained the permit. j.  Section 108.5, entitled "Stop work orders," is changed to read: 
"Upon notice from the code official, work on any plumbing system that is being done contrary to the provisions of this code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists or where damage to a structure or any building component thereof may be immediately compromised, the code official shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping work. Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to penalties as prescribed in Section 6-5 of this Chapter." 
k.  Appendix C, Section C103.8.1, entitled "Subsurface landscape irrigation site location approval," is added to read: 
"Gray water systems and the discharge of surface water from such systems in areas designated as Well Head Protection Zones shall be approved by the authority having jurisdiction over such areas."

(Ord. No. 2011-60, § 6-16, 4-11-2011; Ord. No. 2011-218, 9-26-2011; Ord. No. 2015-70, §§ 1, 2, 3, 4, 4-13-15) 
Sec. 8-101. - Fees. 
    The following tables of permit fees shall apply to all construction work where, pursuant to the codes adopted herein and where not specifically exempt from permitting, said fees shall be due and payable prior to the commencement of any work: 
TABLE 8-1 
BUILDING PERMIT AND ASSOCIATED PERMIT FEES 
All buildings except one- and two-family dwellings, townhomes, apartments, other residential structures, manufactured homes, modular buildings and temporary structures. One-half percent of the true estimated cost of all labor and materials (a copy of the construction contract for nonresidential structures shall be provided upon request to verify actual costs). One- and two-family dwellings, townhomes, apartments, sunrooms, and detached residential structures except manufactured homes. The sum of: 1. The heated square footage of the structure multiplied by 1.2; plus 2. The unheated square footage of the structure, including covered and uncovered decks, multiplied by 0.3. Manufactured homes. $50.00 (Does not include trade permits such as plumbing, electrical, gas, mechanical, etc., associated with the structure). Modular buildings. $50.00 (Does not include trade permits such as plumbing, electrical, gas, mechanical, etc., associated with the structure). Temporary structures, to include fully enclosed tents, except those temporary structures associated with a city sponsored or co-sponsored events and structures exempt from permits. Permit valid for no more than 180 days. $50.00 (Does not include trade permits such as plumbing, electrical, gas, mechanical, etc., associated with the structure). Demolition of any building or portion thereof to include interior or exterior demolition work. $100.00 All fences four feet or higher in height. $50.00 Roofing, siding, window replacement, signs, open decks and handicap/wheelchair accessible ramps. Total contract price multiplied by 0.01, but not less than $25.00. Residential and commercial swimming pools. $100.00 (Does not include trade permits such as plumbing, electrical, gas, mechanical, etc., directly associated with the pool). Reinspection fee (for rejected work), 1st reinspection $25.00 Reinspection fee (for rejected work), 2nd reinspection $35.00 Reinspection fee (for rejected work), 3rd reinspection $45.00 Reinspection fee (for rejected work), 4th reinspection $55.00 Moving fee for any structure, including new foundation. (Fee does not include trade permits associated with set-up at new site such as plumbing, electrical, gas, mechanical, etc.). $250.00 Retaining walls four feet or higher in height (measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall). $25.00 Minimum permit fee for any work not otherwise provided herein. $25.00
