    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cigarette means a roll of finely-cut tobacco or any substitutes therefor enclosed in paper prepared for smoking by individuals. 
    Container means the individual package in which cigarettes are customarily sold at retail. 
    Dealer means any wholesale or retail dealer as herein defined. 
    Retail dealer means any person who is in the business of selling or delivering cigarettes not for the purpose of sale within the city. The same person may be both a wholesale dealer and a retail dealer. 
    Sale means any transfer of title or possession, or both, exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by any means whatsoever for a consideration or any agreement therefor, including rewards, prizes, or premiums of cigarettes given as a result of operation of punch boards, shooting galleries, or other activities. 
    Stamps means the stamp by the use of which the taxes levied under this article are paid. 
    Tax collector means the tax collector of the city. 
    Wholesale dealer means a person who sells or delivers within the city, thereof at wholesale only, cigarettes to retail dealers for the purpose of retail sale only. A person may be a wholesale dealer within the meaning of this definition even though such person may also be a retail dealer as herein defined and even though such person's only sales or deliveries of cigarettes within the corporate limits are sales or deliveries to such person in such person's capacity as a retail dealer. 
(Code 1992, § 7-121; Ord. No. 95-35, § 1, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-191. - Tax levied. 
    In addition to all other taxes of every kind now imposed by law, every person, firm, corporation, club, or association who sells, stores, or delivers cigarettes in the corporate limits of the city shall pay a privilege or license tax to the city, and a privilege or license tax is hereby fixed and levied, for the sale, storage, or delivery of cigarettes within the corporate limits of the city in the amount of $0.10 for each container of cigarettes so sold, stored, or delivered. 
(Code 1992, § 7-122; Ord. No. 95-35, § 2, 3-28-1995; Ord. No. 2003-232, § 1, 9-29-2003) 
Sec. 10-192. - Payment-Method. 
    The license tax imposed by this article shall be paid by affixing stamps in the manner and at the time herein set forth. 
(Code 1992, § 7-123; Ord. No. 95-35, § 3, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-193. - Same-Time. 
    The license tax imposed by this article shall be paid from time to time as stamps are purchased from the tax collector's office and affixed as provided herein. 
(Code 1992, § 7-124; Ord. No. 95-35, § 4, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-194. - Stamps-Kept by tax collector's office; words inscribed; sale. 
    The tax collector shall keep on hand for sale an adequate quantity of stamps to be affixed to each container of cigarettes in denominations as required under this article. Each stamp shall have inscribed thereon the words "City of Madison Cigarette Tax," but said words need not be arranged in the foregoing order and may be abbreviated. The stamps may be sold to wholesale dealers by the tax collector at a price equal to 90 percent of the full amount thereof, the remaining ten percent of such full amount representing a discount to the wholesale dealer for affixing such stamps to the containers in which cigarettes are packaged. All other persons, except such wholesale dealers, must pay the full face amount of the stamps, but no person shall be entitled to purchase any such number of stamps as shall cause the purchase price to include a fraction of a cent. 
(Code 1992, § 7-125; Ord. No. 95-35, § 5, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-195. - Same-Affixing. 
    Before any cigarettes shall be sold or delivered within the corporate limits by any dealer, such dealer shall affix to each container of cigarettes a stamp or stamps obtained from the tax collector in the amount set out in this article in payment of the license taxes imposed by this article. Every dealer shall, within six hours after receipt of any cigarettes which are to be sold within the corporate limits, unless sooner offered for sale, cause stamps to the requisite amount of the tax to be affixed as herein provided. After such stamping has been begun, it shall be continued with reasonable diligence by such dealer until the unstamped containers shall have been stamped, but no stamp required to be affixed to any container shall, after the same has been affixed as herein provided, be again used in payment of any part of the tax levied under this article. Stamps in denominations equal to the amount of the tax shall be affixed to the container from or in which the cigarettes, with respect to which the stamps are affixed, are normally sold at retail, and shall be so affixed in such manner that their removal will require continued application of water or steam. The stamps shall be affixed to each individual container in such a way that such stamps shall be torn in two or mutilated when such container is opened. 
(Code 1992, § 7-126; Ord. No. 95-35, § 6, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-196. - Records; inspections. 
    Every wholesale dealer shall, at the time of selling or delivering cigarettes into the city, make a true and duplicate invoice of the same which shall show full and complete details of the sale or delivery of such cigarettes and the prices thereof. Every wholesale dealer and every retail dealer shall keep a record of the purchase, sale, exchange, or receipt of cigarettes. All such invoices and cancelled checks and other memoranda pertaining to any such purchase, sale, exchange, or receipt shall be retained for a period of three years and shall be subject to inspection of the tax collector or the tax collector's authorized deputy, who shall have the power and authority to enter upon the premises of any dealer at all reasonable times for the purpose of examining such invoices, records, cancelled checks, and other memoranda. Any person who purchases or receives in any manner whatsoever cigarettes which under the terms of this article are required to have stamps affixed to the container thereof, and which do not have stamps affixed in the manner required by this article, shall, within three days after receipt of such cigarettes, report the receipt or purchase, as the case may be, of such cigarettes to the tax collector, giving the date of purchase or receipt, the name of the person from whom purchased or received, and a list describing the cigarettes so purchased or received and the purchase price thereof. Such report must be made by registered or certified mail or in person. 
(Code 1992, § 7-127; Ord. No. 95-35, § 7, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-197. - Illegal acts. 
    Among others, the following acts and omissions shall be unlawful: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is required by this article to affix stamps to any container of cigarettes to fail to affix such stamps in the manner and within the time required by this article. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, or deliver within the city any cigarettes where stamps have not been affixed as provided in this article. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to have possession or control of any cigarettes with respect to which stamps are, by the terms of this article, required to be affixed and with respect to which stamps have not been affixed in the manner required by this article, for 
more than six hours after receipt of such cigarettes on the premises of such person. The possession of each container of cigarettes not having proper stamps affixed as required by this article shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful to manufacture, buy, sell, offer for sale, or possess, or attempt so to do, any reproduction or counterfeit of the stamps provided for in this article, or to possess tools, implements, instruments, or materials of any kind necessary or appropriate to reproduce or counterfeit such stamps, or to alter or cause to be altered any stamps herein provided for. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful to remove from a container or otherwise prepare any stamps with intent to use or cause the same to be used after they have already been used, or to buy, sell, offer for sale, or give away any washed, removed, altered, or restored stamp to any person, or to have in possession any such washed or removed or restored or altered stamp, or for the purpose of indicating payment of any tax hereunder, to reuse any stamp which has theretofore been used for the payment of any tax provided in this article, or to sell any stamp provided for herein, excepting, however, sales made by the tax collector. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is in this article required to keep records to fail or omit to keep the same in the manner herein provided, or to refuse to permit the tax collector or the tax collector's duly authorized deputy to inspect the same at any reasonable hour, or to interfere with or obstruct the tax collector or duly authorized deputy in the making of any such inspection. 
(7)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is herein required to file statements with the tax collector to fail or omit to make or file any statement herein provided within the time herein specified, or to make any false statement therein, and such offense shall be a continuing offense against the city and each day during which such person shall sell or deliver cigarettes in the city during such default shall constitute a separate offense. 
(8)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is required to pay the license tax herein provided for to fail or omit to pay the same within the time herein specified, and such offense shall be a continuing offense against the city and each day during which said person shall sell or deliver cigarettes in the city during such default shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1992, § 7-128; Ord. No. 95-35, § 8, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-198. - Construction. 
(a)  This article shall not be construed to tax interstate commerce or any business of the United States government or any branch or agency thereof. 
(b)  This article shall not be construed to apply to tobacco products stored for the purpose of resale or reshipment outside the city and which are actually so resold or reshipped. 
(c)  This article shall not be construed to repeal any of the provisions of the general license provisions of the city, but shall be held to be cumulative and in addition to any and all other taxes levied by the city. 
(d)  Whenever the requisite stamps have been affixed to the tobacco products or the container containing the same as required in this article, this article shall not be construed to require additional stamps to be affixed thereto in case of subsequent sales, deliveries, or storage. 
(Code 1992, § 7-129; Ord. No. 95-35, § 9, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-199. - Disposition of proceeds. 
    The proceeds derived from the taxes herein levied shall be placed in the general fund of the city, subject to appropriation by the city council of the city for any lawful purpose of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 7-130; Ord. No. 95-35, § 10, 3-28-1995) 
Sec. 10-200. - Postage and handling charge for the mailing of cigarette stamps. 
    The revenue department of the city is hereby authorized and directed to charge and collect a postage and handling charge for the cost of preparing and mailing cigarette stamps to wholesale cigarette dealers. Such charges shall not apply to purchases of cigarette stamps made in person at city hall. The amount of the postage and handling charge shall be as established by the mayor and council, from time to time. 
(Code 1992, § 7-131; Ord. No. 95-76, § 1, 5-23-1995) 
Secs. 10-201-10-223. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - LODGING TAX[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Regulations regarding hotels, inns and other transient lodging places, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-15-1 et seq.; state license tax on innkeepers and hotels, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-115; state transient occupancy tax, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-26-1 et seq. 

Sec. 10-224. - Levy of lodging tax. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed, in addition to all other taxes of every kind now imposed by law, a privilege or license tax upon every person engaging in: 
(1)  The business of renting or furnishing any room to transients in any hotel, motel, inn, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms or lodgings or regularly furnished to transients for a consideration, such tax being an amount equal to seven percent of the charge for such room or lodging, including the charge for use or rental of personal property and services furnished in such rooms, plus $1.00 per room per night, provided that charges for property sold or services furnished which are required to be included in the computation of the tax levied in Code of Ala. (1975) § 40-23-1, such article being commonly referred to as the state sales tax statutes, shall not be included in computing the tax herein levied; or 
(2)  The business of renting or furnishing space for accommodation of trailers for a consideration, such tax to be in an amount equal to seven percent of the charge for such trailer space, plus $1.00 per space per night, provided, however, that charges made by persons in the business of renting trailer space for use of washing machines, electrical power, garbage collection, water supply, and other such charges shall not be included in the measure of such tax, but only the charge for trailer space proper shall so be included. 
(Code 1992, § 7-140; Ord. No. 2010-329, § 6, 11-22-2010; Ord. No. 2015-144, § 1, 6-22-2015) 
Sec. 10-225. - Taxes due monthly; filing of reports. 
    The taxes levied under this article, except as otherwise provided, shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the 20th day of the month next succeeding the month in which the tax accrues. On or before the 20th day of each month, every person subject to any tax levied by this article shall render to the city on a form prescribed by the city a true and correct statement showing the gross proceeds of the business for the previous month, the amount of the gross proceeds which are not subject to the tax, and shall compute the tax due and shall pay to the city the amount due. 
(Code 1992, § 7-141; Ord. No. 2010-329, § 6, 11-22-2010) 
Sec. 10-226. - Penalty for failure to timely file return. 
    Any person who fails to properly and timely file any return required hereunder on or before the date prescribed therefore shall be assessed a penalty equal to the greater of ten percent of the tax due or $50.00. Such penalty shall be assessed and collected as part of the tax. 
(Code 1992, § 7-142; Ord. No. 2010-329, § 6, 11-22-2010) 
Sec. 10-227. - Penalty for failure to timely pay tax. 
    Any person who fails to fully and timely pay the amount of tax which is due to the city under the provisions of this article shall pay a penalty of ten percent of the unpaid tax amount. Such penalty shall be assessed and collected as part of the tax. 
(Code 1992, § 7-143; Ord. No. 2010-329, § 6, 11-22-2010) 
Sec. 10-228. - Interest on delinquent payments. 
    Interest shall be added and charged as provided by Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-1-44 to any tax or other amount due the city under the provisions of this article which is not paid by the due date. 
(Code 1992, § 7-144; Ord. No. 2010-329, § 6, 11-22-2010) 
Sec. 10-229. - Provisions of state statutes applicable to transient occupancy tax. 
    This article and the taxes levied in this article shall be subject to all definitions, exceptions, exemptions, proceedings, requirements, rules, regulations, provisions, penalties, fines, punishments, and deductions that are applicable to the taxes levied by the state transient occupancy tax statutes, except where inapplicable or where otherwise provided in this article, including all provisions of the state transient occupancy tax statutes for enforcement and collection of taxes. 
(Code 1992, § 7-145; Ord. No. 2010-329, § 6, 11-22-2010) 
Sec. 10-230. - Disposition of proceeds. 
    All taxes received or collected by the city under the provisions of this article shall be deposited in the city's general fund, subject to appropriation by the city council for any lawful purpose of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 7-146; Ord. No. 2010-329, § 6, 11-22-2010) 
Chapter 11 - EMERGENCY ALARM SYSTEMS 
ARTICLE I. - SECURITY ALARM SYSTEMS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2002-140, §§ 1-10, adopted August 12, 2002, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as §§ 11-1-11-9 at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Nuisances, ch. 22. 

Sec. 11-1. - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meaning ascribed to them below: 
    Alarm Technician. Any person who inspects, installs, repairs or performs maintenance on security, fire and/or burglary alarm systems and is licensed by the state or works under a state-licensed alarm contractor. 
    Automatic Telephone Dialing Device or Digital Alarm Communicator System. An alarm system which automatically sends a pre-recorded voice message or coded signal over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm has detected. 
    Cancellation. Responding agency alarm cancellation is the process in which a dispatch is cancelled or officer recalled when the alarm company providing monitoring verifies with the alarm user or responsible party that a false alarm has occurred and that there is not an existing situation at the alarm site requiring law enforcement agency response. 
    Enforcement Officials. The designated representative of the police department appointed by the police chief and the designated representative of the fire department appointed by the fire chief for the purpose of enforcing this chapter. 
    False Security Alarm. The activation of any alarm not caused by fire, forced entry, attempted forced entry, robbery or other crime which results in an official response by the police and/or fire departments and which is caused by the negligent use or misuse of the system by the owner or his employees or servants. A presumption exists that the alarm was false if the police or fire personnel responding to the alarm find no evidence of criminal activity, attempted criminal activity, fire or other emergency at the premises. 
    Fee. The assessment of a monetary charge payable to the city pursuant to this section. 
    Official Response. A response to an alarm activation where any officer or member of the police or fire departments shall be dispatched to the premises where the alarm has been activated or where any on-duty officer of the police or fire departments learns of the activation of the alarm system(s) by any means whatsoever and responds thereto by traveling to the premises. The response ends when the officer or member has completed their investigation of the incident. 
    Premises. Any building, structure or combination of buildings and structures including the curtilage thereof, which is used for residential, commercial or any other purpose. 
    Registration Year. The registration year for security alarm permits begins January 1 and ends December 31. The registration fee for permits issued after January 1 is to be prorated based upon the number of days remaining in the calendar year. 
    Required Operative Alarm System. An alarm system which the owner of premises is required to maintain in an operative condition pursuant to statue, law, ordinance, or rule or regulation of any governmental entity. 
    Responsible Party. Any person or entity that owns or controls the premises in which an alarm system is installed. By way of example and not limitation, the person who controls includes a person or entity that leases, operates or manages the premises. 
    Security Alarm Permit. A permit issued by the city allowing the operation of a security alarm system within the city. 
    Security Alarm System. Any mechanical, electrical or radio-controlled device which is designed to be used for the detection of smoke, fire or any unauthorized entry into a building, structure or facility, which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message to a monitoring company or other outside party when activated. Excluded from the definition of security alarm systems are devices which are audible, visible or perceptible, in or attached to any motor vehicle, or auxiliary devices installed by telephone companies to protect telephone systems from damage or disruption of service. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 1, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 11-2. - Alarm systems operations. 
(a)  The city, its officers, employees and agents, shall not assume any duty or responsibility for the installation, maintenance, operation, repair or effectiveness of any privately-owned alarm system, those duties or responsibilities being solely those of the responsible party as defined in section 11-26. 
(b)  The responsible party shall be required to silence and reset an activated alarm. All security alarm systems shall automatically reset/silence the audible alarm within 15 minutes of activation. 
(c)  All security alarm systems shall have a backup power supply that will automatically become available in the event of power failure or outage without activation of the alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 2, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 11-3. - Alarm registration. 
(a)  The registration of security alarms with the City of Madison shall be voluntary for all alarm users who have not been charged with a false alarm. However, registration is strongly encouraged and will result in a reduced fine when and if any false alarm occurs. 
(b)  Registration will be become mandatory upon the occurrence of the first false alarm. Alarm users who have had a false alarm and do not register will be subject to enhanced fines for subsequent false alarms. 
(c)  Registration forms will be available in the City of Madison Police Department and shall require the following information: 
(1)  The name(s), address, business and home telephone number of the responsible person in charge of the premises wherein the alarm system is installed. 
(2)  The type of premise, whether commercial or residential, the business name, if any, and the exact address. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of at least two authorized representatives who can be notified by the police or fire department in the event of an activation of the alarm system, who shall be capable of responding to the premises within 30 minutes, and who are authorized and able to enter the premises to ascertain the status thereof. 
(4)  The name and; 24 hour telephone number of the installing and/or maintaining alarm service company, or the name and telephone number of the company monitoring the alarm system, if different. 
(5)  Whether the alarm at this location is considered a required operative system. 
(6)  A State of Alabama Electronic Security Board of License permit number. 
(7)  A City of Madison Privilege License number. 
(d)  When any of the information required has been changed, it shall be reported to the enforcement official(s) by the responsible party within ten working days of such change. Failure to notify the enforcement official(s) of any changes to the information on file at the city police department regarding such registration shall invalidate the registration and trigger the enhanced schedule of fines as if the alarm had never been registered. 
(e)  If an alarm user has one or more security alarm systems protecting two or more separate structures having different addresses, a separate registration shall be required for each structure. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 3, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 11-4. - Responsibility for security alarm activation. 
(a)  The responsibility for false alarms shall be borne by the owner or responsible party for the premises at the time of the false alarm. In the absence of the specific assignment of responsibility for the alarm, the person or persons occupying and/or controlling the premises on which the alarm is located will be held liable; however, if the false alarm occurs in an apartment building or other multi-family structure, and the alarm system was installed by and is registered to the owner, the responsibility shall lie with the manager or owner of the premises and not the tenants. If the tenant of an apartment wishes to install an individual security alarm, that alarm must be permitted separately from any alarm system owned by the apartment complex; and, in that case, the tenant will be responsible for false alarms in that tenant's residential unit. 
(b)  When responding to an alarm, false or otherwise, at which there are no persons on the premises, a police department official or fire department official will contact the authorized representative(s) who shall respond to the premises within 30 minutes for the purpose of conducting a security check of the premises and resetting the alarm system. If on three or more occasions within a twelve-month period, the responsible party or authorized representative(s) are not available after notification is attempted, or fail to respond to the premises as required herein, the responsible party shall be assessed a fee of $50.00. 
(c)  Each false alarm more than 24 hours apart for which the police or fire department make a separate response is subject to a separate fee assessment. 
(d)  No person shall be held liable under this chapter for any false alarm transmitted under a reasonable mistake of fact that a fire, robbery, burglary or other felony crime was being or had been committed or for any false alarm caused solely by high wind, rain or other torrential weather. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 4, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 11-5. - Notice/fees. 
(a)  For each alarm that is determined to be false by the enforcement official(s), the responsible party will receive notice, by mail, informing the responsible party of the incident of false alarm and indicating how many false alarms have occurred at the premises during the calendar year. 
(b)  No fee shall be assessed under this section for the first alarm at the premises responded to by the police or fire departments during each registration year. Thereafter, the responsible party shall pay the following fees for each false alarm as set forth below: 
FALSE SECURITY ALARM 
Number of Alarms Registered Non-registered Third Alarm $30.00 $45.00 Fourth through Sixth Alarm $50.00 $75.00 Seventh through Tenth $100.00 $150.00 Eleventh and Above $250.00 $500.00  
(c)  All fees/service charges assessed in the enforcement of this chapter shall be considered a bill owed by the alarm user to the city. Each fee/charge shall be paid to the city within 30 calendar days from the date of the receipt of the written notification of the fee/charge. 
(d)  Failure to pay any fee/charge assessed pursuant to this chapter shall be a violation punishable through our municipal court system by a fine, imprisonment or both. The fee/charge is separate and apart from any fines that may be assessed for a violation of this chapter. 
(e)  Cancelled calls will not be included in the overall count of total false alarms unless the officer has already reached the alarm location. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 5, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 11-6. - Appeals. 
(a)  The responsible party may request a hearing within 15 calendar days of the date of receipt by the responsible party of any notice of false alarm or fee assessment, to contest the validity thereof. The request for a hearing shall be in writing and shall be filed with the enforcement official(s). 
(b)  The police chief, fire chief, or their designee shall hold a hearing within 20 calendar days from the date the responsible party files a request for a hearing with the enforcement official(s). The responsible party or designee shall be given notice of the hearing and shall have the opportunity to present evidence on their behalf, to cross examine any witnesses, and to be represented by counsel. Within ten calendar days of the hearing, the police chief or fire chief or their designee who held the hearing shall issue a written determination affirming or denying the action taken by the enforcement official(s) and advising the responsible party of the action(s) needed. The written determination shall be final and conclusive, subject only to review by the city council whose judgment shall be final as allowed by law. 
(c)  Should the responsible party choose to appeal the determination of the police chief or fire chief or their designee to the city council of the city, a request for such hearing shall be in writing and accompanied by an appeal fee of $25.00. Said request shall be directed to the legal department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 6, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 11-7. - Automatic telephone dialing alarm device. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, operate, or maintain an alarm that includes an automatic dialing system that automatically dials the statewide emergency telephone number (911), or any other telephone number assigned to the city police department or city fire department, except when required by federal or state law or local ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 8, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 11-8. - Penalties. 
    Any person who is found to be in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the fines and other punishment provided in section 11-30 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 9, 8-12-2002) 
Sec. 11-9. - Testing of newly installed alarm systems. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, it shall not be a violation of this chapter to test an alarm system under the following conditions: 
(a)  Where there is no visual, audio, electronic or other indications of the alarm which can be seen, heard or received beyond the boundaries of the property upon which the test is occurring; or 
(b)  Where there is visual, audio, electronic or other indications of the alarm which can be seen, heard or received beyond the boundaries of the property upon which the test is occurring, and one of the following two precautions are observed: 
(1)  Adequate measures are taken to ensure that anyone seeing, hearing or receiving the indication of an alarm will not report it either directly or indirectly to the city as an alarm requiring police or fire assistance; or 
(2)  The police and fire departments are notified, in writing to the enforcement official(s), 24 hours in advance of the test and are instructed not to respond by the owner or responsible party for the property upon which the test is to occur. 
(Ord. No. 2002-140, § 10, 8-12-2002) 
Secs. 11-10-11-25. - Reserved. 
Chapter 12 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to own and regulate cemeteries, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-40 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - CEMETERIES COMMITTEE 

Sec. 12-1. - Madison Municipal Cemeteries Committee. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Madison Municipal Cemeteries Committee (hereinafter "committee"), the purpose of which is to study, make recommendations to the city council regarding, and perform and assist in the performance of maintenance of and improvements to the grounds and structures of all cemeteries operated and maintained by the city, as approved and coordinated by the city as provided herein. 
(b)  The committee shall be composed of nine members as set forth in this subsection, each with full voting rights: 
(1)  Place 1. Member of the Madison Station Historic Preservation Commission, to be selected by the mayor from the current membership of the commission at the time this place becomes open for appointment. 
(2)  Place 2. Member of the city council, to be selected by the council from the current membership of the council at the time this place becomes open for appointment. 
(3)  Place 3. Director of public works or his designee. 
(4)  Place 4. City clerk-treasurer or his designee. 
(5)  Place 5. Mayor or his designee. 
(6)  Place 6. Employee of the public works department, to be selected by the public works director. 
(7)  Place 7. At-large member, to be appointed by the city council. 
(8)  Place 8. At-large member, to be appointed by the city council. 
(9)  Place 9. At-large member, to be appointed by the city council. 
(c)  Places 1 and 2 shall serve as ex officio members, their terms of appointment corresponding to their official tenures on the Madison Station Historic Preservation Commission and city council, respectively. 
(d)  Places 3, 4, and 5 shall serve as ex officio members, their terms of appointment corresponding to their official tenures as director of public works, city clerk-treasurer, and mayor, respectively. 
(e)  Place 6 shall serve at the discretion of the director of public works but in no event shall any public works employee serve in place 6 more than five years in the aggregate. 
(f)  Places 7, 8, and 9 shall serve four year terms and shall be eligible for reappointment. Each at-large member must be a resident of Madison, Alabama. 
(g)  For those serving in places 1, 2, 7, 8, and 9, a member may be removed by a majority vote of the city council for cause, including, without limitation, failure to regularly attend scheduled meetings of the committee. Any designee serving in place 3, 4, 5, or 6 shall be subject to removal by his respective designating authority for good cause shown by the committee, any such removal to be in the designating authority's sole discretion. 
(h)  Vacancies on the committee shall be filled in accordance with the processes set forth above and, where applicable, shall be for the unexpired term of the member replaced. 
(i)  The committee shall elect a chairman and a vice-chairman and such other officers as the members deem necessary. To the extent the same do not conflict with the laws of the city or the state, the committee shall adopt rules of procedure and bylaws to govern its operations and shall therein specify the number of committee members constituting a quorum. 
(j)  The committee shall meet regularly, but not less than semi-annually, at a frequency responsive to the needs and demands of the city and its citizens. Members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for expenses incurred on behalf of the committee in accordance with the rules and regulations for the reimbursement of expenses adopted by the committee and subject to budgetary allocations made by the city council. 
(k)  Meetings of the committee shall be public meetings and shall be conducted in accordance with the Alabama Open Meetings Act, or successive legislation, as the same is most recently amended and codified. 
(l)  Any maintenance or improvement to a cemetery operated by the city which is recommended by the committee must be approved by and coordinated through the director of public works or his designee prior to implementation. Members of the committee shall not individually or collectively endeavor to perform any recommended maintenance or improvements without such approval. 
(Ord. No. 2012-48, § 1, 8-29-2012) 
Secs. 12-2-12-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-347, § 2, adopted January 12, 2015 repealed the former Art. II., §§ 12-21-12-24, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 12-21. - Definitions. 
(a)  Authorized Contractors refers to contractors that are licensed as excavation contractors in the City of Madison. 
(b)  Burial Space refers to a parcel of land for a single grave within a lot. 
(c)  Clerk's Office refers to the city clerk-treasurer's office of the City of Madison, Alabama. 
(d)  Deed refers to an instrument conveying a right of interment in a lot or burial space in Madison Cemetery or Madison Memory Gardens. 
(e)  Fee Schedule refers to a list of charges for city services that the city council establishes in Appendix A of the Code of Ordinances, City of Madison, Alabama. 
(f)  Funeral Home refers to a funeral establishment as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-13-1(a)(18). 
(g)  Grounds Regulations refers to rules established by the city council, and enforced by the public works director, regarding maintenance of cemetery grounds. 
(h)  Interment Order refers to the document provided by the clerk's office for completion by the person(s) requesting interment, the same usually being completed in coordination with the attending funeral home. 
(i)  Lot refers to a parcel of land in any Madison City cemetery which contains four burial spaces. 
(j)  Public Works refers to the public works department of the City of Madison, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 2014-347, § 2, 1-12-2015, Ord. No. 2015-91, § 1, 6-22-2015) 
Sec. 12-22. - Burial space purchases and transfers. 
(a)  The charge for each individual burial space shall be established by the city council from time to time in the fee schedule. 
(b)  Cemetery lots and burial spaces may be purchased at the office of the city clerk-treasurer during normal business hours. The city clerk-treasurer shall collect all fees and issue appropriate receipts at the time of payment. 
(c)  Within 30 days after purchase, the city shall prepare a deed for each lot or burial space purchased and place such deed in the United States mail for delivery by certified letter to the address stated on the application. 
(d)  Transfer of burial spaces: 
(1)  A transferor shall complete and submit to the city clerk-treasurer a request for cemetery burial space transfer using the forms and documentation required by the city. 
(2)  The city clerk-treasurer shall prepare a deed from the transferor to the transferee. 
(3)  At the time that a request for transfer is made, a transfer fee shall be paid according to the Fee Schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2014-347, § 2, 1-12-2015; Ord. No. 2015-91, § 1, 6-22-2015) 
Sec. 12-23. - Funeral services and grave opening and closing; fees established. 
(a)  Funeral scheduling. Funeral homes shall submit an interment order to the city clerk-treasurer to schedule graveside services and grave opening and closing. 
(1)  The City of Madison reserves the right to insist upon at least a 24 hour notice to schedule a funeral on Monday through Friday. Saturday, Sunday, or Monday funerals must be scheduled by Friday no later than 12:00 p.m. 
(2)  Funeral homes must provide notice of a change in the date and time of a graveside service at least 24 hours before said service was initially scheduled. 
(3)  If the graveside service is not held at the scheduled time, a one-hour grace period shall be allowed; however, the funeral home may be subject to a late fee, as established in the Fee Schedule, for each hour following said grace period until the graveside service begins. 
(b)  Grave opening and closing; fees established. 
(1)  Upon receipt of a fully executed interment order, the city will verify ownership of the designated burial space, and thereafter public works will stake the boundaries of the appropriate burial space in advance of the scheduled burial service. When the location of a burial space cannot be precisely determined, or when for any reason it cannot be opened where specified by the interment Order, or when, in the opinion of the director of public works or his designated representative, a burial space has been improperly designated, the director may, in his discretion, direct opening to occur in such location as he deems best and proper. 
(2)  Authorized contractors hired by attending funeral homes will open and close graves, except as otherwise provided by this section. 
(3)  When no authorized contractors are available to open or close a grave, or in other extenuating circumstances as determined by the director of public works, public works employees may open or close a grave. In such cases, the individual requesting interment shall be responsible for the services rendered according to the then-current Fee Schedule. 
(4)  On the next business day after grave closing, public works will inspect the burial space for unreasonable wear and tear to the burial space of interment; any surrounding burial spaces and lot(s); or the common areas within the cemetery. Should the same be discovered, the city will notify the attending funeral home, which shall be responsible for repairing any damage and/or reimbursing the city for the same. 
(5)  Ashes from cremation may be buried in purchased cemetery burial spaces according to the other provisions of this section and in coordination with and under the supervision of a funeral home. 
(6)  A fee for provision of public works services set forth in this section will be as established by the council from time to time and set forth in the Fee Schedule. Such fees shall be due and payable at the time of interment order submission. 
(c)  Exhumation. A person requesting an exhumation must present all forms required by the State of Alabama and Madison County for exhumations. No exhumation will be allowed until all forms are received by the city clerk. At least seven calendar days' notice must be given prior to any exhumation. 
(Ord. No. 2014-347, § 2, 1-12-2015; Ord. No. 2015-91, § 1, 6-22-2015) 
Sec. 12-24. - Cemetery grounds regulations. 
(a)  Provision and acceptance of regulations. Upon submission of an interment order to the city clerk-treasurer, the responsible party, as therein designated, shall be provided a copy of these regulations and then acknowledge his or her receipt and acceptance of the same. 
(b)  Grounds keeping authority. The director of public works or his duly authorized designee (hereinafter "director") has ultimate and final authority to direct or perform any lawful action determined by the Director to be necessary to effectuate the beautification, maintenance, and repair of the city's cemeteries. 
(c)  Monuments and ornamentation. 
(1)  Before a responsible party can install a new monument, replace an existing monument, or affix ornamentation of any kind to an existing monument (the term "monument" to include, but not be limited to, a headstone, ledger stone, cornerstone, or marker) he or she must notify and seek approval from the director. 
(2)  Monuments may be installed only under the supervision of the director, who has final approval over the installation and placement of every monument. 
(3)  Ornamentation of any size on a monument, including, but not limited to, vases, statues, and medallions, must be either original to the monument, having been permanently and physically incorporated into the monument by design and construction, or permanently affixed to the monument in the manner prescribed by the director. 
(4)  Ornamentation prohibited from use or display in all city cemeteries includes, without limitation: 
  Statues and figurines which are not physically incorporated into or permanently affixed to a monument in accordance with these regulations. 
  Benches, except for those which are designed, constructed, and installed as monuments. 
  Balloons, trinkets, pinwheels, etc. 
  Concrete items of any kind or size. 
  Gravel, rocks, stones, wood shavings or pieces, marbles, and similar objects. 
  Funeral home markers for graves that have a monument or headstone. 
  Hanging decorations other than a flower pot installed with a shepherd's hook under subsection (e). 
  Lawn furniture. 
  Solar lights. 
  Vases or urns. 
  Food, beverages, and alcohol, regardless of the container. 
  Curbing, fencing, borders, edging, or materials of any kind which serve to enclose a grave or graves or separate a grave or graves from the remainder of the cemetery. 
(5)  The city reserves the right to remove prohibited items and items which, in the judgment of the director, fall within the general parameters established in subsection (4), and to discard the same without further notice. 
(6)  The city reserves the right to preserve any monument or ornament of historic value, regardless of its compliance with these regulations, subject to the determination by the director of the item's historical significance after consultation with the Alabama Historical Commission. 
(d)  Flags and flag poles. No person can place flags or flag poles in any City of Madison cemetery except as provided below: 
(1)  Subject to the supervision of the director, temporary flags may be placed on graves for two weeks prior to and two weeks after Memorial Day, Independence Day, and Veterans Day. Any flags not picked up will be appropriately discarded by public works without further notice. 
(2)  Any flag pole properly and permanently installed in any Madison cemetery before the date of approval of these regulations shall be allowed to remain in place unless the director determines that the flag pole is damaged, in disrepair, or not being utilized for a continuous period of 30 days. Any flag poles found to be in any one or more of these conditions will be removed by public works without further notice. 
(3)  The city is not responsible for maintaining any flags or flag poles unless they are the city's property. 
(4)  Once flag poles have been removed, whether by the City or an individual, they cannot be replaced. 
(5)  The City of Madison will remove and properly dispose of worn flags without further notice. Notwithstanding the timeline set forth in subsection (2), the City of Madison will not replace any worn flags that it removes. 
(e)  Plants and flowers. 
(1)  Cut or silk flowers and flower arrangements may be temporarily attached to the top of a monument or placed at its base. Except as provided herein, no other flowers or arrangements shall be placed anywhere on any grave. 
(2)  In the event a monument, whether single, double, or family, cannot accommodate a standard flower saddle, up to two shepherd's hooks may be used for the sole purpose of holding and displaying flowers, whether cut or silk. Each hook shall be no more than 48 inches in overall height; made of powder-coated steel with a double-prong forked base; and placed flush with the base of the monument with the hook facing inward toward the center of the monument in a manner that will not interfere with grounds keeping efforts. The city reserves the right to move or adjust any shepherd's hook that poses a hazard or obstacle to grounds keeping efforts and to remove and discard any shepherd's hook that is damaged, abandoned, or in disrepair. 
(3)  Where a grave is marked by a flat or ground-flush monument or by no monument at all, up to two flat-bottom flower pots with a maximum capacity of five gallons each may be placed immediately adjacent to the monument or in the area where a headstone would be placed for the sole purpose of holding and displaying flowers, whether cut or silk. The placement of each flower pot shall be done in a manner that will not interfere with grounds keeping efforts. The city reserves the right to move or adjust any flower pot that is an obstacle to grounds keeping efforts and to remove and discard any flower pot that is damaged, abandoned, or in disrepair. 
(4)  Following a funeral, public works will remove fresh flowers after seven days and artificial flowers after 21 days without further notice. 
(5)  The city reserves the right to remove any flowers when they become faded, dried, worn, or otherwise unpresentable, as determined by the director. 
(6)  No flowers or flower arrangements shall be placed or planted in cemetery walkways or common areas. 
(7)  No flowers, plants, trees, shrubs, or any other vegetation shall be planted in or removed from any location within any cemetery except by the city. 
(8)  The city reserves the right to prune, trim, relocate, or remove any flowers, plants, trees, shrubs, or any other vegetation on any grave or in any common area of any cemetery at any time and without notice. 
a.  Subject to the supervision of the director, temporary wreaths may be placed on graves for one week prior to and one week after any city-recognized holiday. Any wreaths not picked up will be discarded without further notice. 
(f)  Miscellaneous. 
(1)  Parking or driving on graves is prohibited. 
(2)  Scattering cremated remains anywhere within any cemetery is prohibited. 
(3)  Responsibility for compliance with these regulations and for communication of the same shall inure from the original purchaser or owner of the lot to all of those who succeed him or her by assignment, sale, or inheritance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-347, § 2, 1-12-2015; Ord. No. 2015-91, § 1, 6-22-2015; Ord. No. 2016-131, 5-24-2016) 
Secs. 12-25-12-51. - Reserved. 
Chapter 14 - COURT AND CRIMINAL PROCEDURE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-1. - Court established. 
    There is hereby established a municipal court for the city. 
(Code 1979, § 12-1; Code 1992, § 9-1) 
Sec. 14-2. - Jurisdiction of court. 
    The municipal court shall have jurisdiction of all prosecutions for the breach of ordinances of the city within its corporate limits. This jurisdiction shall also extend to all prosecutions for violations of state offenses committed within the corporate limits of the city where such offenses have been made offenses against the city. 
(Code 1979, § 12-2; Code 1992, § 9-2) 
Sec. 14-3. - Time and place of holding court. 
    The municipal court shall be held at such time and place as the city council may determine, with the advice of the municipal judge. 
(Code 1979, § 12-3; Code 1992, § 9-3) 
Sec. 14-4. - Municipal judge-Appointment; term; qualifications; filling vacancy; oath; disqualification. 
(a)  The municipal court shall consist of one or more municipal judges to be appointed by the city council. In the event more than one judge is appointed, one of those appointed shall be designated as a chief judge. Other municipal judges shall serve as associate judges. The chief judge shall have the responsibility and authority to prepare and maintain a schedule for all municipal judges and to designate which judge is to preside at any particular session of court. Each judge shall be appointed for a term of two years and shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of the term. Each judge shall hold office until a successor is appointed and has qualified. 
(b)  Each municipal judge must be licensed to practice law in the state and must be a qualified elector of the state. Each municipal judge shall not be otherwise employed in any capacity by the municipality during such judge's term of office. 
(c)  The office of a municipal judge shall be vacant if such judge dies, resigns or is removed, and vacancies shall be filled by the city council in the same manner as original appointments are made. Any person so appointed shall be eligible to serve two years from the date of appointment. 
(d)  Each municipal judge shall, before assuming office, take and sign the oath provided by the constitution of the state, and a copy thereof shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state, the administrative director of courts and the clerk of the municipal court. 
(e)  Each municipal judge shall be subject to all grounds of disqualification from hearing specific cases as are applicable to circuit court judges. 
(Code 1979, § 12-4; Code 1992, § 9-4; Ord. No. 92-161, § 1, 12-8-1992) 
Sec. 14-5. - Same-Acting. 
    The mayor shall have the authority to designate a person, licensed to practice law in the state and a qualified elector of the state, not otherwise employed in any capacity by the city, to serve as substitute or acting municipal judge with all power and authority of a duly appointed municipal judge to serve in the event of the absence from the city, death, disability or disqualification for any reason of all of the municipal judges appointed by the city council. 
(Code 1979, § 12-11; Code 1992, § 9-5; Ord. No. 92-161, § 1, 12-8-1992) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-34. 
Sec. 14-6. - Same-Compensation. 
    The compensation of each municipal judge of the city shall be as prescribed from time to time by the governing body, and shall be payable monthly. The rate of compensation shall not be diminished during the judge's term of office. Any general increase in the compensation of all or substantially all municipal employees shall be applied proportionately to the compensation of the municipal judge. 
(Code 1979, § 12-10; Code 1992, § 9-6; Ord. No. 92-161, § 1, 12-8-1992) 
State Law reference- Salary, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-33. 
Sec. 14-7. - Municipal court costs; levying and assessing. 
(a)  That, in addition to municipal court costs assessed and collected by the municipal court of the city pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-14, including $17.00 which is remitted to the general fund of the city pursuant to that statute, the city does hereby levy and assess and direct its municipal court to collect the following court costs: 
(1)  For any traffic offense, including driving under the influence, there is hereby assessed an additional $41.50 in court costs, as authorized by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-7.1, which shall be collected by the municipal court of the city and remitted as provided by this section. 
(2)  For any misdemeanor offense, there is hereby assessed an additional $71.00 in court costs, as authorized by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-7.1, which shall be collected by the municipal court of the city and remitted as provided by this section. 
(3)  For violation of any municipal ordinance, the municipal court shall also collect as cost all additional costs and fees imposed by statute of the state for such cases and all such costs and fees shall be remitted as required by said statutes. 
(b)  All costs collected under subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) of this section shall be remitted to a special fund designated as the city's corrections fund, which the city clerk-treasurer has been authorized and directed to establish. Funds deposited into the corrections fund shall be used only for the purposes permitted by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-7.1. 
(Code 1992, § 9-7; Ord. No. 96-166, §§ 1, 2, 11-12-1996; Ord. No. 2004-254, §§ 1, 2, 12-13-2004) 
Sec. 14-8. - Municipal judge-Issuance of warrants. 
    The municipal judge is authorized to issue arrest and search warrants upon affidavit for city ordinance violations returnable to the municipal court and for violations of state law returnable to any state court. 
(Code 1979, § 12-7; Code 1992, § 9-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-32. 
Sec. 14-9. - Same-Reports. 
(a)  The municipal judge shall report on the proceedings of the municipal court as required by law or rule. 
(b)  The judge shall be required to make a report to the council on the operation of the municipal court annually. 
(Code 1979, § 12-9; Code 1992, § 9-9) 
State Law reference- Reports, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-16. 
Sec. 14-10. - Powers of the mayor. 
    The mayor may remit fines and such costs as are payable to the city and commute sentences imposed by the municipal judge to which an appeal was taken for violations of city ordinances, and may grant pardons, after conviction, for violation of such ordinances, and shall report such action to the city council at the first regular meeting thereof in the succeeding month with the reasons therefor in writing. 
(Code 1979, § 12-6; Code 1992, § 9-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-15. 
Sec. 14-11. - Magistrates. 
    The municipal judge shall take steps to have magistrates appointed for the city, pursuant to Rule 18 of the Alabama Rules of Judicial Administration. The powers of the magistrate shall be limited to: 
(1)  Issuance of arrest warrants; 
(2)  Granting of bail in minor offense prosecutions in accordance with the discretionary bail schedule and approving property, cash, and professional surety bonds upon a municipal judge's approval; 
(3)  Receiving of pleas of guilty in misdemeanors where a schedule of fines has been prescribed by law or rule; 
(4)  Accountability to the municipal court for all uniform traffic tickets and complaints issued, including all electronic traffic tickets or e-tickets, as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-4, in instances in which the court has, in its discretion, determined to use e-tickets, and for all, monies received and records of offenses; and 
(5)  Accepting and screening affidavits of substantial hardship upon a municipal judge's approval and, if authorized by court order, assigning attorneys on a rotating basis from a list approved by the court. 
(6)  Conducting arraignments and setting nonguilty pleas for trial, upon a municipal judge's approval. 
(7)  Opening court and calling the docket, upon a municipal judge's approval. 
(8)  Granting continuances in municipal ordinance violation cases, upon a municipal judge's approval. 
(9)  Dismissing no driver's license violations pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-6-9 where the defendant shows proof of a driver's license at the time the citation was written. 
(10)  Dismissing mandatory liability insurance violations pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-7A-20 where the defendant has produced satisfactory evidence that at the time of the citation the motor vehicle was covered by a liability insurance policy in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-7A-4. 
(11)  Dismissing equipment violations where a municipal ordinance allows and where the law enforcement officer signs the uniform traffic ticket and complaint verifying that the equipment has been replaced. 
(12)  Such other authority as may be granted by law. 
(Code 1979, § 12-8; Code 1992, § 9-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-51. 
Sec. 14-12. - Citation-To issue in lieu of custodial arrest in certain cases. 
    When any law enforcement officer or code enforcement officer or other officer authorized to issue citations and to make arrests discovers any violation of any provision of any ordinance, formal written resolution, building regulation, code or subdivision regulation of the city, and the circumstances allowing the officer to make an arrest therefor are of such a nature that a custodial arrest should not be made in the opinion of such officer, such officer may in lieu of taking such offender into custody by formal custodial arrest issue and serve personally upon such person as a potential offender a citation directing such person or potential offender to appear in municipal court at a date or time certain as stated in such citation thereupon to answer to the charges set forth in the citation. 
(Code 1992, § 9-12; Ord. No. 88-52, § 1, 6-21-1988) 
Sec. 14-13. - Same-Separate misdemeanor for failure to appear in response. 
    It shall be unlawful and a separate misdemeanor for any person to fail to appear in the municipal court at the time and place stated in a citation duly issued under section 14-12 and personally served upon and delivered to the person named therein. 
(Code 1992, § 9-13; Ord. No. 88-52, § 2, 6-21-1988) 
Sec. 14-14. - Same-Form. 
    The form of citation to be utilized by law enforcement agents or officers under section 14-12 shall be substantially in the form set out in Exhibit A, attached to and by reference made a part of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(Code 1992, § 9-14; Ord. No. 88-52, § 3, 6-21-1988) 
Sec. 14-15. - Appeals to circuit courts from judgments of municipal court and proceedings thereon. 
    As provided by statute, appeals to the circuit court shall be as follows: 
(1)  All appeals from judgments of the municipal court shall be to the circuit court of this circuit for trial de novo. 
(2)  The municipality may appeal within 60 days, without bond, from a judgment of the municipal court holding an ordinance invalid. 
(3)  A defendant may appeal in any case within 14 days from the entry of judgment by filing notice of appeal and giving bond, with or without surety, approved by the court or the clerk in an amount not more than $500.00 and costs, as fixed by the court, conditioned upon the defendant's appearance before the circuit court. The municipal court may waive appearance bond upon satisfactory showing that the defendant is indigent or otherwise unable to provide a surety bond. If an appeal bond is waived, a defendant sentenced to imprisonment shall not be released from custody, but may obtain release at any time by filing a bond approved by the municipal court. If the defendant is not released, the prosecutor shall notify the circuit court clerk, and the case shall be set for trial at the earliest practicable time. 
(4)  When an appeal has been taken, the municipality shall file the notice and other documents in the court to which the appeal is taken within 15 days, failing which the municipality shall be deemed to have abandoned the prosecution, the defendant shall stand discharged and the bond shall be automatically terminated. 
(5)  Upon trial or plea of guilty in the circuit court on appeal, the court may impose any penalty or sentence which the municipal court could have imposed. 
(6)  Upon failure of an appellant to appear in the circuit court when the case is called for trial, unless good cause for such default is shown, the court shall dismiss the appeal and upon the expiration of 30 days from such date, unless the dismissal is set aside, the circuit court clerk shall return the file, with a copy of the order of dismissal, to the clerk of the court from which the appeal was taken and the judge of such court may enter judgment of default on the appeal bond by utilizing the procedures set forth in the Code of Ala. 1975, § 15-13-81. The circuit court may, on motion of the defendant made within 30 days of the order of dismissal, set aside the dismissal and other orders and reinstate the appeal on such terms as the court may prescribe, for good cause shown by defendant. 
(7)  Upon receipt of notice of dismissal of an appeal, the municipal court may issue a warrant for the arrest of the defendant, who may also be arrested without a warrant as an escapee. Upon arrest, the defendant shall be delivered to the municipal authorities and punished in accordance with the judgment of the municipal court. 
(8)  If a judgment is entered against a defendant on appeal, the circuit court shall remand the defendant to the municipal authorities for punishment in accordance with the judgment of the circuit court, unless, when the judgment is for fine and costs only, the judgment is paid or a judgment is conferred therefor in favor of the municipality with sureties or as otherwise provided for convictions under state law. 
(9)  Upon receipt of payment of fines, forfeitures and costs upon appeals, the clerk of the circuit court shall within 30 days pay 90 percent of such fines and forfeitures and ten percent of the costs to the treasurer of the municipality. The circuit court clerk shall be liable on the bond for such fines and costs plus a penalty of five percent per month for default in such payments. 
(Code 1979, § 12-12; Code 1992, § 9-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-70. 
Sec. 14-16. - Appeals from judgments of circuit courts and proceedings thereon. 
    As provided by statute, in case of appeals from the judgment of the circuit court, the municipality, in a case holding invalid an ordinance, or the defendant in any case, may appeal to the court of criminal appeals in like manner as in cases of appeals for convictions of violation of the criminal laws of the state. If the appeal is taken by the municipality, it shall not be required to give surety for the cost of the appeal. When taken by the defendant, such defendant may give bail with sufficient sureties, conditioned that such defendant will appear and abide by the judgment of the appellate court; and, failing to give bail, must be committed to jail, but may give such bail at any time pending the appeal. When an appeal is taken by the defendant, bail is given pending the appeal and the judgment of conviction is affirmed or the appeal is dismissed, the defendant is bound by the undertaking of bail to surrender such defendant's self to the municipal authorities within 15 days from the date of such affirmance or dismissal; and, if such defendant shall fail to do so, the clerk of the circuit court from which the appeal is taken, upon motion of the municipality, must endorse the bail bond forfeited, and a writ or writs of arrest must be issued by the clerk to the sheriff. Upon arrest the defendant shall be delivered to the municipal authorities, and the sentence must without delay be carried out as if no appeal had been taken. If bail is forfeited as provided in this section, a conditional judgment must be entered by the court in favor of the municipality and the same proceedings had thereon for the municipality as is authorized by law to be had in the name of the state in state cases. 
(Code 1979, § 12-13; Code 1992, § 9-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-71. 
Chapter 16 - FINANCE AND TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Management and control of finances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-56; municipal taxation generally, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-51-1 et seq., 40-1-37; required reports by municipal officers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-84. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Tax year. 
    The tax year for the city shall commence on October 1 of each year and end on September 30 of the next succeeding year. 
(Code 1979, § 8-6; Code 1992, § 10-1) 
State Law reference- Fiscal year defined, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-8-1. 
Sec. 16-2. - Development fees, rates and charges. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided for, all development fees, rates or charges necessary for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter shall be as established and hereafter adopted by motion, resolution or ordinance of the city council, from time to time. 
(b)  Whenever any provision of this chapter provides that a development fee, rate or charge shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and the amount of such fee, rate or charge is not expressed in this chapter in any dollar amount, then the amount of such fee, rate or charge shall be the most recent and latest amount established, set or fixed by the city council by ordinance, resolution or motion. 
(Ord. No. 2012-379, § 1, 10-8-2012) 
Sec. 16-3. - When taxes due and delinquent. 
    Municipal taxes shall be due and delinquent as prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 8-7; Code 1992, § 10-2) 
State Law reference- Dates city taxes are due and delinquent, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-51-2. 
Sec. 16-4. - NSF charge. 
(a)  The city clerk-treasurer is hereby authorized to charge and collect NSF charges of not more than the greater of either $30.00 or an amount equal to the actual charge by the depository institution for return of unpaid or dishonored order of withdrawal or like instrument drawn on a bank or other depository institution given by any person, firm, corporation or association in full or partial payment of any tax, license fee or other fee due the city, or other assessments of the city, if such instrument is dishonored or not paid for any reason by such institution. 
(b)  The NSF check charge shall be a legal charge against the person who tendered dishonored or unpaid instrument and shall not be deemed a finance charge or interest. 
(Code 1992, § 10-3; Ord. No. 91-66, § 2, 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 2006-181, §§ 2, 3, 7-24-2006) 
Secs. 16-5-16-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PURCHASING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Contracts entered into by city, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-5, 11-47-6; competitive bidding on contracts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-50 et seq. 

Sec. 16-25. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed them in this section unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Blind trust means an independently managed trust in which the employee-beneficiary has no management rights and in which the employee-beneficiary is not given notice of alternations in, or other disposition of, the property subject to the trust. 
    Brand name or equal specification means a specification limited to one or more items by manufacturers' names or catalog numbers to describe the standard of quality, performance, and other salient characteristics needed to meet the requirements of the city, and provide for the submission of equivalent products. 
    Brand name specification means a specification limited to one or more items by manufacturers' names or catalog numbers. 
    Business means any corporation, partnership, individual, sole proprietorship, joint stock company, joint venture, or any other private legal entity. 
    Confidential information means any information which is available to an employee only because of the employee's status as an employee of the city and is not a matter of public knowledge or available to the public on request. 
    Contract means all types of city agreement, regardless of what they may be called, for the procurement of supplies or services. 
    Contractor means any person having a contract with the city or using agency thereof. 
    Direct or indirect participation means involvement through decision, approval, disapproval, recommendation, preparation of any part of a purchase request, influencing the content of any specification or procurement standard, rendering of advice, investigation, auditing, or in any other advisory capacity. 
    Employee means an individual drawing a salary or wages from the city, whether elected or not; any noncompensated individual performing personal services for the city or any department, agency, commission, council, board, or any other entity established by the executive or legislative branch of the city. 
    Financial interest means: 
(1)  Ownership of an interest or involvement in any relationship from which, or as a result of which, a person within the past year has received, or is presently or in the future entitled to receive, more than $1,000.00 per year, or its equivalent; 
(2)  Ownership of more than 50 percent of any property or business; or 
(3)  Holding a position in a business such as officer, director, trustee, partner, employee, or the like, or holding any position of management. 
    Gratuity means a payment, loan, subscription, advance deposit of money, service, or anything of more than nominal value, present or promised, unless consideration of substantially equal or greater value is received. 
    Immediate family means a spouse, children, parents, brothers and sisters. 
    Invitation for bids means all documents, whether attached or incorporated by reference, utilized for soliciting sealed bids. 
    Person means any business, individual, union, committee, club, other organization or group of individuals. 
    Procurement means the buying, purchasing, renting, leasing, or otherwise acquiring of any supplies or services. It also includes all functions that pertain to the obtaining of any supply or service, including description of requirements, selection, and solicitation of sources, preparation and award of contract, and all phases of contract administration. 
    Public agency means a public entity subject to or created by the city. 
    Qualified product list means an approved list of supplies or services described by model or catalog numbers, which, prior to competitive solicitation, the city has determined will meet the applicable specification requirements. 
    Responsible bidder means a person who has the capability in all respects to perform fully the contract requirements, and the tenacity, perseverance, experience, integrity, reliability, capacity, facilities, equipment, and credit which will assure good faith performance. 
    Responsive bidder means a person who has submitted a bid, which conforms in all material respects to the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids. 
    Services means labor, time, or effort furnished by a vendor, not involving the delivery of a specific product other than those, which are merely incidental to the required performance. This term shall not include employment agreements except agreements with private temporary service agencies or companies. 
    Specification means any description of the physical or functional characteristics or of the nature of a supply or service. It may include a description of any requirement for inspecting, testing, or preparing a supply or service for delivery. 
    Supplies means property, including, but not limited to, individual items used by a using agency, vehicles, equipment, materials, goods, commodities, and leased property. 
    Using agency means any department, agency, commission, bureau, office, or any other unit in the city government using supplies as provided for in this article. The term shall not include a board, authority or commission authorized to be established as a separate entity by state law or created directly by state law and not under the jurisdiction of the city council. 
    Vendor means any corporation; partnership, individual, sole proprietorship, joint stock company, joint venture, or any other private legal entity. 
(Code 1992, § 10-20; Ord. No. 2008-246, 9-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-26. - Power and duties of purchasing agent. 
(a)  To establish and enforce specifications with respect to supplies, materials, and equipment required by the city government or any using agency thereof. 
(b)  To have charge of such general storerooms and warehouses as the mayor may direct. 
(c)  To transfer to or between offices, departments, or agencies, or sell surplus, obsolete, or unused supplies, material and equipment. 
(d)  To purchase all supplies needed by any using agency in accordance with purchasing procedures as prescribed by this article and such rules and regulations as the agency shall adopt for the internal management and operation of the division of purchasing, and such other rules and regulations as shall be prescribed by the mayor. The authority of the agency to make all purchases for all using agencies shall not be abridged by accepting any particular using agency, except as otherwise provided in this article. Except as herein provided, no city official or officer shall order the purchase of any supplies or make any contract within the purview of this article other than through the purchasing agent. 
(e)  To act to procure for the city the highest quality in supplies at the least expense to the city. 
(f)  To discourage uniform bidding, as possible, and endeavor to obtain as full and open as possible competition on all purchases and sales. 
(g)  To establish and amend, subject to approval by the mayor, all rules and regulations necessary to the operation of the purchasing division. 
(h)  To keep informed of current developments in the field of purchasing, prices, market conditions and new products, and secure for the city the benefit of research done in the field of purchasing by other governmental jurisdictions, national technical systems, trade associations having national recognition, and private businesses and organizations. 
(i)  To prescribe and maintain such forms as such purchasing agent shall find reasonably necessary for the enforcement of this article. 
(j)  To exploit the possibilities of buying in bulk to take full advantage of discounts. 
(k)  To act to procure for the city all federal and other tax exemptions to which the city is entitled. 
(l)  To perform such other duties as imposed upon such purchasing agent by resolution or ordinance, or by direction of the mayor. 
(m)  The purchasing agent may delegate authority to purchase certain supplies or services to other city officials, if such delegation is deemed necessary for the procurement of those items. 
(Code 1992, § 10-21; Ord. No. 2008-246, 9-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-27. - Requisition and estimates. 
(a)  Using agencies to file requirements estimates. All using agencies either by or with the authorization of the head of the department under which the using agency operates, shall file with the agent detailed requisitions or estimates of their requirements in supplies and contractual services in such manner, at such times, and for such future periods as the agent shall prescribe. 
(b)  Revision by agent. The agent shall examine each requisition or estimate and shall have the authority to revise it as to quality, quantity, or estimate cost, but revision as to quality shall be in accordance with the standards and specifications established pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1992, § 10-22; Ord. No. 2008-246, 9-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-28. - Approvals required for purchasing. 
    Except in cases of emergency, as described in section 16-34, neither the purchasing agent nor any other officer or employee of the city shall make purchases in the name of the city on the credit of the city, or create any debt or liability against the city, unless the same has been previously authorized by the city council, or unless the funds for said expenditure have been appropriated by the city council, either specially or in the annual budget of the city. In all cases where a purchase is to be made for which funds have previously been appropriated by the city council involving less than $15,000.00, the purchasing agent or other person authorized to make purchases under these provisions of this article shall purchase such supplies or services at the best available price, using his judgment as to the quantity to be purchased. In all cases involving expenditures of $15,000.00, where competitive bidding is required and where an appropriation has been made by the city council, the purchasing agent shall proceed to issue invitations for bids and to open said bids at the time and place stated in the advertisement for bids. The city council shall act as the awarding authority for all bids. 
(Code 1992, § 10-23; Ord. No. 2008-246, 9-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-29. - Competitive bid procedures. 
    All purchases of and contracts for supplies, including leases thereof, shall, except as specifically provided herein, be based on competitive bids, and awarded to the lowest responsible bidder in accordance with the state law and this article. The following procedures shall apply to all such purchases, not specifically excepted: 
(1)  Invitation for bids. An invitation for bids shall include specifications and all contractual terms and conditions applicable to the procurement. The invitation for bids may be amended by issuance of addenda at any time prior to the date bids are to be opened. 
(2)  Cancellation of invitations for bids or rejection of bids. An invitation for bids or other solicitation may be cancelled or any or all bids may be rejected, in whole or in part, as may be specified in the solicitation, when it is for good cause and in the best interest of the city. The reasons therefore shall be made part of the contract file.
