(Code 1979, §§ 19-14.1(F), 19-19; Code 1992, § 13-5; Ord. No. 85-150, §§ 1, 3, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 85-173, 11-12-1985; Ord. No. 88-4, § 2, 3-1-1988; Ord. No. 88-43, 5-31-1988) 
Secs. 20-5-20-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SYSTEM 

Sec. 20-27. - Application for service required. 
    Each prospective customer desiring water service shall be required to sign the board's standard form of application for service or contract before service is supplied by the board. 
(Code 1979, § 19-3; Code 1992, § 13-20) 
Sec. 20-28. - Connection of property along new public sections. 
    It shall be the duty of property owners, who reside upon streets where no water mains have been laid, to comply with the provisions of this article as soon as such mains are laid along the streets upon which they reside or own property subject to the provisions above prescribed. 
(Code 1979, § 19-4; Code 1992, § 13-21) 
Sec. 20-29. - Water main connection permits. 
(a)  All persons desiring to install water connections to water mains or service lines shall, before commencing such installation, file the right application with the board showing the point at which they wish to form such connection and obtain a written permit from the board for the right or authority to make such connection. 
(b)  No person, except a plumber authorized by the board, shall receive a permit required for connecting to the water main. 
(c)  No person shall make any connection with the water main of the board without first obtaining the permit required in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1979, § 19-5; Code 1992, § 13-22) 
Sec. 20-30. - Using water without approval. 
(a)  No person having charge or control of any hydrant or water pipe connected with the waterworks of the board shall allow or permit any other person to take, draw or use any water from any such hydrant or water pipe without first obtaining the permission of and consent of the board. 
(b)  No person shall take, or cause to be taken, water from any hydrant or fireplug, or carry away or cause to be carried away water for any purpose or use whatsoever without first obtaining the consent and permission of the board. 
(c)  If the water has been cut off from any premises for any reason whatever, no person shall allow, cause or suffer such premises to be supplied with board water without the authority and permission of the board. 
(Code 1979, § 19-6; Code 1992, § 13-23) 
Sec. 20-31. - Destruction of property. 
    No person shall mar, deface, break or otherwise damage any of the buildings, machinery, pipes, hydrants, valves, meters or fixtures or any other property of the waterworks of the board. 
(Code 1979, § 19-7; Code 1992, § 13-24) 
Sec. 20-32. - Water meters. 
(a)  Required for furnishing water service. The board shall not furnish water service to any establishment unless there is installed, with respect to such establishment, a separate meter or other measuring device capable of measuring accurately the amount of water furnished to such establishment. 
(b)  Installation; necessary to regulate water consumption. The board shall see that water meters of a uniform type are installed throughout the city on the connections of all water consumers for the purpose of regulating and measuring the amount of water that may be used by all consumers from the waterworks of the board. 
(c)  Type; placement. All meters shall be of a kind approved by the board and must be placed to the satisfaction of the board or its authorized agent in charge of the waterworks. 
(d)  Title. All meters shall be and remain the property of the board and shall be kept accessible at all times for meter reading, maintenance and repairs. 
(e)  Access; maintenance. No one, other than the board or its authorized agents, shall have access to any water meter or shall tamper therewith or undertake any repairs thereto. The board shall, at its expense, provide the ordinary and routine maintenance of each water meter, but in the event of any damage to any meter resulting from hot water backflow or any other cause attributable to the customer's use of the water system or of property under such customer's control, the cost of repairing or replacing such meter shall be paid by the customer. 
(Code 1979, § 19-8; Code 1992, § 13-25) 
Sec. 20-33. - Control and maintenance of system and of fire hydrants. 
(a)  All water mains now established or that may hereafter be established in or under the streets, avenues, easements or public ways of the city are now declared to be under the exclusive control of the board (and, as to fire hydrants, the city fire department), and to be maintained and kept in repair by the board, without interference by any person. The fire department will report any known problems or defects to the board for repair. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person except authorized personnel of the board (and of the city fire department as to fire hydrants) to undertake to exercise control over such water mains or fire hydrants without first obtaining a written permit from the board. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the water service lines now established or that may be hereafter established and connected with such water mains. Such service lines are to be maintained and kept in repair by the person owning or controlling the property serviced by such service lines. 
(Code 1992, § 13-26) 
Sec. 20-34. - Maintenance of consumer's piping, etc.; authority to cut off supply. 
(a)  Persons taking water from the water system shall keep their own water pipes and all fixtures connected therewith in good repair and protected from frost. Each consumer of water from the board water system shall keep all pipes, valves and other appurtenances connected to the water system in such condition so as not to cause any damage to the meter or to any other part of the water system. 
(b)  The board shall have the right, power and authority to cut off the water from any establishment with the underground service pipe or service line or any part thereof leading from the water meter to the establishment which become defective or out of repair so as to cause a leakage or wastage of water. 
(c)  It shall not be the duty of the board to keep in repair any underground pipe or service line or any part thereof, except the main pipe generally known as the board water main; nor shall it be the duty of the board to furnish water to any consumer whose service pipe is not in a fit condition to receive the water and prevent its waste. 
(d)  When the consumer owns or uses any service line or underground pipe and becomes a consumer of water from the board through such pipe or service line, it shall be the duty of such consumer or owner of the house, building or property to keep such pipe or service line in fit condition to receive the water, and if such consumer or owner of the house, building or property fails to do so, the city and the board shall not be liable for cutting off the water upon such premises because of such failure of the consumer or owner to keep such pipeline or service line in fit condition; provided, that if the consumer owns or uses any such underground pipe or service line jointly with any other consumer who may have separately contracted with the board to furnish water through such common line into the respective branches thereof, the board shall have the right to cut off the water from such common line when the pipes of either or any of the service lines, or any branch thereof, have been permitted to get out of repair or in condition unfit to receive water and the board shall not be liable for so cutting off the water because of the getting out of repair or unfitness of any common line, pipe, service or branch line. 
(e)  The city and the board expressly and without notice reserve the right to cut off the water from any of its water mains for the purpose of making repairs or extensions. 
(Code 1979, § 19-10; Code 1992, § 13-27) 
Sec. 20-35. - Authority to enter property. 
(a)  Where a cutoff or water meter is located on private property and is connected with the water system for service the city and the board shall each, at all times, have the right and authority by and through its agents, servants, officers or employees to go upon and enter such premises for the purpose of reading the water meter or to cut off or on the water when making any such repair to the water meter or to inspect its meters or connections as it deems necessary. 
(b)  Where any property owner or tenant refuses to allow the city, the board or the properly authorized agent, officer or employee of either, to enter such premises for the purposes set out above, the city or the board shall have the right and authority to cut off the water from such premises at any convenient place, and the services shall not be reinstated until the property owner or tenant shall have caused such cutoff or water meter to be removed and placed ready for service at whatever place the city shall designate. Neither the city nor the board shall be liable for cutting off the water upon such premises. 
(Code 1979, § 19-11; Code 1992, § 13-28) 
Sec. 20-36. - Plans for water lines. 
    No person shall construct or lay water lines in any subdivision of the city or in any easements or public rights-of-way of the city where public water lines are not existing or located, without first presenting plans and specifications for the laying of such water lines to the board or its agent and obtaining its consent for the laying of such water lines. 
(Code 1992, § 13-29) 
Sec. 20-37. - Connection permits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to connect with or maintain a connection with any water main of the board without first having secured a permit for such connection from the board. 
(Code 1992, § 13-30) 
Secs. 20-38-20-62. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to construct and maintain sewer systems, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-50. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-63. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, wherever used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section unless the context plainly indicates otherwise or that a more restricted or extended meaning is intended: 
    Appurtenances shall mean the various accessories essential to efficient operation of the wastewater system including but not limited to man holes, lift stations, etc. 
    Board shall mean the water & wastewater board of the City of Madison, doing business as Madison Utilities. 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) shall mean the amount of dissolved oxygen needed by aerobic biological organisms in a body of water to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period. 
    BOD s shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees centigrade, expressed in parts per million by weight. BOD shall be determined by standard methods as defined in this article. 
    Batch process shall mean a treatment process in which a tank or reactor is filled, the wastewater treated, and the tank emptied. Such processes are also used to clean, stabilize, or condition chemical solutions. 
    Building (house) sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the sewer lateral at the property line or other lawful place of disposal. 
    City shall mean the City of Madison, Alabama. 
    COD (denoting chemical oxygen demand) shall mean the quantity of dissolved oxygen required for the chemical oxidation of decomposable matter under aerobic conditions. 
    Composite sample shall mean a sample collected using automatic sampling equipment during a 24-hour period in which portions of the sample are taken at even intervals and combined to form a representative sample. 
    Constituents shall mean the combination of particles, chemicals, or conditions which exist in the industrial wastes. 
    Control manhole shall mean an appropriately located manhole from which a given owner's undiluted effluent can be effectively sampled by the board. 
    Effluent shall mean the discharge of flow from a sewer, treatment facility, process, reservoir, or basin. 
    Fats, oils, and greases (FOG) shall mean organic polar compounds derived from animal and/or plant sources that contain multiple carbon chain triglyceride molecules, detectable and measurable using analytical test procedures established in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 136 as same may be amended from time to time. 
    Flammable shall be as defined by existing fire regulations covering the City of Madison, Alabama. 
    Food service establishments shall mean those establishments primarily engaged in activities of preparing, serving, or otherwise making available for consumption foodstuffs and that use one or more of the following preparation activities: Cooking by frying (all methods), baking (all methods), grilling, sautéing, rotisserie cooking, broiling (all methods), boiling, blanching, roasting, toasting, or poaching, and infrared heating, searing, barbecuing, and any other food preparation or serving activity that produces a consumable food product in or on a receptacle requiring washing to be reused. 
    Grab sample shall mean a sample taken on a one-time basis which is not a function of flow or time. 
    Grease trap shall mean a fixture through which all of the discharge of a connection flows and which provides a minimum detention period of ten minutes between influent and effluent baffles with 20 percent of the total volume as allowance for a sludge pocket. 
    Grit chamber shall mean a device to remove sand and gritty material from wastewater. 
    Illicit discharge shall mean any discharge to the municipal separate storm sewer that is not composed entirely of stormwater, except discharges pursuant to a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit (other than the NPDES permit for discharges from the municipal separate sewer) and discharges resulting from firefighting activities. 
    Industrial plant shall mean any plant producing liquid waste, with or without suspended solids, required to be discharged either with or without pretreatment, into the POTW. 
    Industrial plant site shall mean a parcel of land occupied by a facility which discharges industrial wastes. Each separate industrial plant connected to the POTW will be considered and assessed for each connection individually even though an owner may operate one or more industrial plants on the same site. A single-building or multi-building industrial plant with more than one connection located on a single site shall not arbitrarily combine waste qualities by computations for the purpose of obtaining dilution benefits. 
    Industrial user or contributor shall mean an industry which discharges wastewaters having the characteristics of industrial wastes, as distinct from commercial wastes or domestic wastes, and having a BOD of 250 ppm or greater and/or total suspended solids of 250 ppm or greater, or other chemical constituents above or different from normal domestic and/or commercial waste. 
    Industrial waste surcharge shall mean the additional service charge assessed against industries in the city sewer service area whose waste characteristics exceed those of normal wastewater. 
    Influent shall mean the wastewaters arriving at the wastewater treatment plant for treatment and those structures associated with its initial treatment. 
    Metered water shall mean the amount of water consumed by the sewer customer, as measured by the city water meter. 
    Mg/l (milligrams per liter) shall mean ratio by weight, to volume, interchanged with ppm. 
    Municipal separate sewer shall mean a conveyance or system of conveyances (including roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels, or storm drains): 
(1)  Owned by the city having jurisdiction over disposal of sewage, industrial wastes, stormwater, or other wastes; 
(2)  Designed or used for collecting or conveying stormwater; 
(3)  Which is not a combined sewer; 
(4)  And, which is not part of the POTW of the Board. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    Normal shall mean those values taken as standards in the measurement of this article; these limits are defined in context. 
    Owner shall mean any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation, or group. 
    pH shall mean the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution; pH shall be determined by standard methods as hereinafter defined. 
    Ppm (parts per million) shall mean ratio by weight. 
    Person shall mean any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation, or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner of a premise or as the owner's agent. 
    Potable water shall mean water reserved or suitable for drinking. 
    Pretreatment shall mean that biological, physical, or chemical treatment given to a waste stream or those processes utilized for this purpose before discharge into the POTW. 
    Public sewer shall mean a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have certain rights and shall include all fixtures and appurtenances connected and used in the POTW, and which is controlled by the board. 
    Publicly owned treatment works (POTW). A sewage or wastewater treatment works owned and operated by the board for the use and benefit of its customers, including but not limited to any devices or systems used by the board in the collection, storage, treatment, recycling, and reclamation of municipal sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature and any conveyances which convey wastewater to a treatment plant. See 33 U.S.C. §1292, et seq. 
    Receiving waters shall mean those waters into which a waste stream is discharged. 
    Residential or domestic user shall mean a premises or person that discharges wastewater to the POTW which closely match normal residential wastewater as to their volume and strength, and further, for billing purposes, is defined as a dwelling place or place of residence. 
    Sanitary sewer shall mean a sewer which carries wastewater and to which storm, surface, and groundwater are excluded. 
    Septic tank waste shall mean that waste which results from the emptying of domestic septic tanks. 
    Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit for carrying wastewater. 
    Standard methods shall mean those procedures or methods established by the latest edition of the "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Sewage", as prepared, approved, and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    Standard strength shall mean wastes of any origin having a content of 250 mg/l or less of five-day, 20 degrees centigrade BOD and/or containing 200 mg/l or less of suspended solids, and having no prohibited qualities for admission to the POTW. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain shall mean a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes wastewater and polluted industrial wastes. 
    Stormwater shall mean stormwater runoff, snow melt runoff, and surface runoff and drainage. 
    Suspended solids shall mean solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, wastewater, or liquid and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Total solids shall mean total weight of ppm of all solids: dissolved, undissolved, organic, or inorganic. 
    Toxic shall mean constituents of wastes which adversely affect the organism involved in wastewater treatment or aquatic life in receiving facilities or waters. 
    Wastewater or wastes shall mean a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments; treatable wastes. 
    Wastewater treatment plant shall mean any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating wastewater as part of the POTW. 
    Watercourse shall mean a definite channel with bed and banks within which concentrated water flows, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1992, § 13-40; Ord. No. 93-59, § 1, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 2009-145, § 1, 7-27-2009; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-64. - Application of article. 
    The rules and regulations incorporated in this article shall govern the installation, alteration, and maintenance of all sanitary drainage within the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-41; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-65. - Purpose and policy. 
    This article sets uniform requirements for discharges into the POTW and enables the board to comply with all applicable State and Federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 United States Code [U.S.C.] section 1251 et seq.) and the General Pretreatment Regulations (Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations [CFR] Part 403), the water quality requirements set by the POTW and the applicable effluent limitations, national standards of performance, toxic and pretreatment effluent standards, and any other discharge criteria which are required or authorized by state or federal law, and to derive the maximum public benefit by regulations the quality and quantity of wastewater discharged into the POTW. This article provides a means for determining wastewater volumes, constituents and characteristics, the setting of charges and fees, and the issuance of permits to certain customers. 
(Code 1992, § 13-42; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-66. - Compliance with article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do or cause to be done any of the acts prohibited by this article or to fail, refuse, or neglect to do any of the acts required to be done or performed by this article. 
(a)  When the board finds that an owner has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this article, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the board may serve upon that owner a written notice of violation. Within five days of the receipt of such notice, an explanation of the violation and a plan for the satisfactory correction and prevention thereof, to include specific required actions, shall be submitted by the owner to the board. Submission of such a plan in no way relieves the owner of liability for any violations occurring before or after receipt of the notice of violation. Nothing in this section shall limit the authority of the board to take any action, including emergency actions or any other enforcement action, without first issuing a notice of violation. 
(b)  If the owner does not respond to the notice of violation in a satisfactory manner, water and sewer service may be discontinued unless adequate treatment facilities, devices, or other related appurtenances are installed and properly operated within a time specified in the notice of violation. Other conditions necessary to address the noncompliance may also be required, including additional self-monitoring and management practices designed to minimize the amount of pollutants discharged to the POTW. 
(Code 1992, § 13-43; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-67. - Control and maintenance of system. 
(a)  All sewer mains now established or that may hereafter be established in or under the streets, avenues, easements, or public ways of the city are now declared to be under the exclusive control of the board, to be maintained and kept in repair by the board, without interference by any person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to undertake to exercise control over such sewer mains, or to aid in or grant the right to make connections therewith without obtaining a permit from the board. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sewer service lines now established or that may be hereafter established and connected with such sewer mains. Such service lines are to be maintained and kept in repair by the person owning or controlling the property serviced by such service lines. 
(Code 1979, § 19-16; Code 1992, § 13-44; ; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-68. - Right of entry of inspectors. 
(a)  The duly authorized employees of the city and the board are hereby authorized to receive and investigate complaints of violations of this article, including, but not limited to, investigation of possible illicit discharges to the municipal separate storm sewer system and possible violations of the city's national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) permit. 
(b)  Duly authorized employees of the board bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in connection with enforcement of the provisions of this article. Such duly authorized representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment, or the municipal separate storm sewer system. 
(Code 1992, § 13-45; Ord. No. 93-59, § 2, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-69. - Indemnification. 
    In all instances where the board has reasonable cause to believe that any of the rules, regulations, or provisions set forth in this article or that have otherwise been duly adopted by the board have been, may be, or are being violated by any person discharging waste into the POTW, the Board may require such person to give bond or enter into an indemnity agreement in a form acceptable to the board with sufficient surety to be approved by the approving board to protect, indemnify, and hold harmless the board and the city from any loss, damage, or expense that it may suffer or that may incur as a result of such noncompliance or violation by such person; and, in the event of the failure to do so after ten days' notice by certified U.S. mail that the same will be required, the use of the POTW by such person shall be denied or discontinued. 
(Code 1992, § 13-46; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-70. - Special agreements. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the board and any industrial concern by the board for treatment, subject to payment therefor, by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1992, § 13-47; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-71. - Appeals procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved by a decision of any representative of the board regarding a determination made under this article or other rules and regulations of the board, relating to use of or access to the POTW, shall have the right to appeal to the governing body of the board or to a committee which may be established by the board for the purpose of hearing such appeals. The appellant must file with the general manager of the board a request in writing for such a hearing. The appeal must include the date and description of the decision or determination made by the representative of the board and the manner in which the appellant asserts that the appellant is aggrieved by the decision. The appeal must also include a citation to the specific section or sections of this article or other rules and regulations of the board by which the person is aggrieved pursuant to the determination made by the representative of the board. To be considered, any appeal must be signed, include the information required by this section and be filed no more than ten days after notice of the decision or determination made by the representative of the board. Upon receipt of a timely and complete notice of appeal properly filed hereunder at least five days prior to the board's next regularly scheduled meeting, it shall be the duty of the general manager of the board to present the appeal to the board at that meeting. The board may elect to issue notice to the appellant of a date and time at which it will hear the appeal or may refer it to a committee established by the board. If deferred to a committee of the board, the committee will issue notice of a date and time for hearing of the appeal within ten days from the date the committee is informed of the referral. The appellant will be given the time, date, and place of the hearing and will be afforded an opportunity to present evidence and argument in opposition to the decision or determination of the representative of the board at that hearing. 
(Code 1992, § 13-48; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-72. - Discontinuance of connections discharging injurious substances into sewers. 
    The board shall have power to prevent or discontinue any connection with the POTW which discharges any substance liable to damage the POTW or obstruct the flow of wastewater. 
(Code 1992, § 13-49; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-73. - Plans for sewer lines. 
    No person shall install or modify existing sewer lines or appurtenances in any subdivision, in any easements or public rights-of-way within the city without first presenting plans and specifications for the installing or modifying of such sewer lines or appurtenances to the board or its designated agent and obtaining its consent for the installing or modifying of such sewer lines or appurtenances. 
(Code 1979, § 19-17; Code 1992, § 13-50; ; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-74. - Connection permits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to connect with or maintain a connection with the POTW without first having lawfully connected to the board's water system or other board authorized water systems and having secured a permit for such sewer connection from the board. 
(Code 1979, § 19-18; Code 1992, § 13-51; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-75. - Connection of property along new public sewer sections. 
    It shall be the duty of property owners who reside upon streets where no public sewers have been laid to comply with the provisions of this article as soon as such sewers are laid along the streets upon which they reside or own property subject to the provisions above prescribed. 
(Code 1979, § 19-21; Code 1992, § 13-53; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-76. - Introducing substances into the POTW. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to introduce any substance into the POTW of the board by means of any manhole, cleanout plug, or any other means; provided, however, this section shall not apply to an establishment or residence lawfully connected in the regular course of daily activity. 
(Code 1979, § 19-21.1; Code 1992, § 13-54; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-77. - Damage to the POTW. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment that is a part of the POTW, or cause or permit any prohibited discharge therein. 
(Code 1992, § 13-55; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
State Law reference- Criminal damage to property, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-7-20 et seq. 
Secs. 20-78-20-97. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS 

Sec. 20-98. - Requirements of sewer use. 
    The owners of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the service area where there is located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the board, are hereby required, at such owners' expense, to install suitable toilet facilities therein, to pay all fees and charges assessed by the board, and to connect such facilities directly with the POTW in accordance with the provisions of this article within 180 days after the date of official notice from the board to do so; provided that such public sewer is within 200 feet of the property line of the property receiving the notice. This section shall not apply to unimproved or vacant lots. 
(Code 1992, § 13-60; Ord. No. 93-119, 8-24-1993; Ord. No. 97-35, § 1, 3-24-1997; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require premises to be connected to sewer system, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-50-53, 11-50-54; regulation of septic tanks, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-55. 
Sec. 20-99. - Violation. 
    Any person who knowingly or intentionally violates any provision of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject, upon conviction, to punishment by a fine up to but not exceeding $500.00. Each day a violation of this division continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1992, § 13-61; Ord. No. 97-35, § 1, 3-24-1997; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-100. - Commencement of action. 
    An action may be initiated for violation of article 3, division 2 by filing a complaint with the Madison Municipal Court by appropriate representatives of the board. 
(Code 1992, § 13-62; Ord. No. 97-35, § 1, 3-24-1997; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-101. - Service of notice required by section 20-98. 
    The notice required by section 20-98, where the property owner is a resident of the city, shall be given on behalf of the board either by personal delivery to such owner or by mail addressed to such owner with postage fully prepaid. Where such property owner is a nonresident of the city, such notice may be given to such owner's agent, if any, in the city who has charge of such property or its rental. If the owner has no resident agent, such notice must be given by advertisement once a week for three successive weeks in some newspaper published in the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-63; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-56. 
Sec. 20-102. - Discharge to municipal separate storm sewer system or natural outlet. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, discharge, or caused to be placed or discharged, any illicit discharge into the separate municipal storm sewer system or any natural outlet, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with provisions of this chapter and other state and federal laws. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any sanitary sewage or wastewater into the separate municipal storm sewer system or any natural outlet. 
(c)  Violations of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. Each day any violation of this section shall continue, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1992, § 13-64; Ord. No. 93-59, § 3, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-103. - Unsanitary methods of discharge. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the service area, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage, trash, or other pollutants or toxic waste. 
(Code 1992, § 13-65; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-104. - Reporting of illicit discharge. 
(a)  Any person who places, discharges, or causes to be placed or discharged, any illicit discharge of sanitary sewer into the separate municipal storm sewer system or any lake, stream, or other body of water located within the corporate limits of the city shall report all information relevant to the discharge, including, but not limited to, the date, location, nature, and volume or quantity discharged (if known) to the engineering department of the City of Madison within 24 hours of such discharge. 
(b)  Failure to report an illicit discharge as provided in this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. Each day any violation of this section shall continue, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1992, § 13-66; Ord. No. 93-59, § 4, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Secs. 20-105-20-121. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 20-122. - Septic tanks. 
    Septic tanks will be prohibited except as provided in regulations of the board. 
(Code 1992, § 13-70; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-123. - Duties of owner generally as to connections. 
(a)  All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the board from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(b)  All industries, commercial organizations, or other producers of liquid waste of any form, including domestic waste at, without limitation, apartments, hotels, motels, hospitals, universities, schools, or homes served by the POTW, must obtain a permit for such connection from the board. 
(Code 1992, § 13-71; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-124. - Prohibited connections. 
    No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to the POTW. 
(Code 1992, § 13-72; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-125. - Public hazard. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-73; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-126. - Cross-connections. 
    Any cross-connection between potable water supply and sanitary sewer shall be prohibited, except as specified by the adopted building and plumbing codes of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 13-74; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Secs. 20-127-20-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PERMITS 

Sec. 20-151. - Industrial permits. 
    Any person owning or operating an industrial plant producing a liquid industrial waste of any quantity of strength or other qualities requiring special consideration, as relevant conditions are defined herein, or who hereafter desires to make connection for the industrial waste-producing facilities of any such establishment, to the POTW, shall make application to the board on the supplied industrial wastewater discharge permit application form for a permit authorizing such connection. Owners desiring to discharge wastes requiring pretreatment (as determined by the requirements of this article) shall complete the appropriate sections of the form. Holders or applicants of an SID permit shall provide a copy of such to the board. 
(Code 1992, § 13-91; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-152. - Certification. 
    The following certification statement is required to be signed and submitted as part of the permit application: 
Certification: I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervision in accordance with a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the person or persons who manage the system, or those persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is, to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate, and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for knowing violations. 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-153. - Permit modifications. 
    For any owner holding a valid pretreatment permit, any change in the pretreatment process operated by the owner which causes a measurable change in the composition or a ten percent increase in the volumetric discharge of the wastewater shall notify the general manager of the board and be subject to a re-application. 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-154. - Permit applicability 
    A permit issued by the board pursuant to this division authorizes only the discharge of wastewater listed in the permit application and none other. 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-155. - Monitoring and sampling. 
    Unless an appropriate control manhole can be identified, the owner shall provide and operate appropriate monitoring facilities to allow inspection, sampling, and observation of the waste stream as it leaves its facility and prior to entering the POTW. Such facilities shall be maintained at all times in safe and proper operating condition and accessible by board personnel. Sampling requirements and frequency of reporting shall be as determined by the board. 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Secs. 20-156-20-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - INDUSTRIAL SURCHARGES 

Sec. 20-171. - High concentrations of pollutants. 
    The board is authorized, in its discretion, to establish, on a case-by-case basis, a surcharge based upon the increased cost of handling and treatment of discharges containing concentrations of specific pollutants higher than the limits established herein. The board reserves the right to define and determine pollutants for which such surcharges may be established. 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Secs. 20-172-20-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PROHIBITED DISCHARGES 

Sec. 20-196. - General types of prohibited discharges. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters into the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-197. - Substances prohibited in public sewers. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged, any of the following described waters or wastes into the POTW: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature which will inhibit biological activity in the board's wastewater treatment plant, but in no case higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes which may contain more than 100 parts per million, by weight, of fats, oil, or grease, or any water or waste containing oil, grease, or other substance that will solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 and 90 degrees Fahrenheit. See also section 20-205. 
(3)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, mineral spirits, commercial solvent, motor oil, any flammable or explosive liquid that may create a fire or explosive hazard in the POTW, or any other petroleum derivative. 
(4)  Any waters or wastes that contain more than ten parts per million by weight of hydrogen sulfide, sulfur dioxide, or nitrous oxide. 
(5)  Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, offal, plastics, wood, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, lime residues, beer or distillery slops, chemical residues, fiberglass, paint or ink residues, cannery waste, bulk solids, or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the POTW without proper pretreatment and written approval of the board. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than six or higher than nine at any time, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, or personnel of the wastewater works, or the treatment process. 
(7)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous substances in such concentration as to constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or to interfere with any wastewater treatment process, or to create any hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant without proper pretreatment and written approval of the board. The limits fixed herein may be used as a guide in design and plant control, but may be altered by the board as required or authorized by state or federal law in the event of a cumulative overload on a particular drainage basin or wastewater treatment plant. 
(8)  Any waters containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual provision, attention, or expense is required to handle such materials at the wastewater treatment plant. 
(9)  Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance, capable of creating a public nuisance or hazard to life or preventing entry into the POTW for their maintenance, inspection, and repair. 
(10)  Any waters containing quantities of radium, naturally occurring, or artificially produced radioisotopes in excess of presently existing or subsequently accepted limits for drinking water as established by the national committee on radiation protection and measuring. 
(11)  Any concentrated dye wastes, spent tanning solutions, or other wastes which are highly colored, or wastes which are of unusual volume, concentration of solids, or composition that may create obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation and treatment of influent of the POTW without proper pretreatment and written approval of the board. 
(12)  Waters or wastes containing substances, which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment processes, employed, or are amenable to treatment to only such degree that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(13)  Any waters or wastes containing more than 2,000 parts per million total solids. 
(14)  Wastes at a flow rate and/or pollutant discharge rate that is excessive over short periods of time so that there is a treatment process overload and subsequent loss of treatment efficiency. 
(15)  Any wastewater containing phenols or other taste-producing substances in such concentrations as to produce odor in the effluent as to affect the taste or odor of the receiving water. Quantities of such substances will be determined by the board on a case-by-case basis. 
(Code 1992, § 13-121; Ord. No. 2009-145, § 2, 7-27-2009; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-198. - Fixed upper limits for constituents (ppm, by weight). 
    Discharges into the POTW shall be in compliance with the "Fixed Upper Limits for Constituents Discharged into Madison Utilities POTW," as adopted by the board, and as 13 th day of February, 2017, revised and adjusted from time to time. 
(Code 1992, § 13-122; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-199. - Dilution. 
    The admission into the POTW of any waters or wastes in volumes, or with constituents, such that existing dilution conditions in the sewers or at the treatment plant would be affected to the detriment of the city or the board, shall be subject to review and approval of the board. Where necessary, in the opinion of the representative of the board, pretreatment or equalizing units may be required to bring constituents or volume of flow within the limits previously prescribed or to an otherwise acceptable level, and to hold or equalize flows such that no peak flow conditions may hamper the operation of any unit of the POTW. Such equalization or holding unit shall have a capacity suitable to serve its intended purpose, and be equipped with acceptable outlet control facilities to provide flexibility in operation and accommodate changing conditions in the waste flow. 
(Code 1992, § 13-123; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-200. - Suspended solids. 
    The admission into the POTW of any waters or wastes having a suspended solids (TSS) content in excess of 500 ppm, by weight, on a 24-hour composite basis or having a suspended solids content for any grab sample greater than five times the average influent value recorded at the affected wastewater treatment plant during the previous calendar year, or 750 ppm, whichever is greater, will be subject to review by the board. Where deemed necessary in the opinion a representative of the board, pretreatment may be required as stated herein above. 
(Code 1992, § 13-124; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-201. - Chemical oxygen demand (COD). 
    The admission into the POTW of any water or waste having a chemical oxygen demand (COD) in excess of 850 ppm, by weight, on a 24-hour composite basis or for any grab sample having a chemical oxygen demand in excess of five times the average influent value for the affected wastewater treatment plant during the previous calendar year or 1,275 ppm, whichever is greater, will be subject to review by the board. Where required by the board, pretreatment may be required as stated heretofore. 
(Code 1992, § 13-125; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-202. - Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD ) limit. 
    The admission into the POTW of any waters or wastes having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand (BOD s ) in excess of 500 ppm, by weight, on a 24-hour composite basis, or for any grab sample having a BOD s in excess of five times the average influent value for the affected wastewater treatment plant during the previous calendar year or 750 ppm, whichever is greater, will be subject to review by the board. Where required by the board, the owner shall provide and operate, at such owner's own expense, such pretreatment as may be required to reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to meet the above requirements. 
(Code 1992, § 13-126; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-203. - Deleterious discharges; authority of board generally. 
(a)  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the POTW, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in this division, and which, in the judgment of the board, and/or the state and federal agencies having jurisdiction, may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the board may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes, 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the POTW, 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge, and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. 
(b)  The owner shall provide protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or substances. Facilities to prevent such accidental discharges shall be provided and maintained at the owner's expense. In addition, the owner shall post, in conspicuous locations throughout his facility, emergency contact information to be used in the event of an accidental discharge. 
(Code 1992, § 13-127; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-204. - Discharge to storm sewers. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged as approved by the local, state, and federal agencies having jurisdiction. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the local, state, and federal agencies having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1992, § 13-128; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-205. - Fat, oil, and grease control (FOG). 
    The board is authorized to prevent and/or minimize the introduction and accumulation of fats, oils, and greases into the POTW. Sanitary sewer blockages and obstructions may be caused or contributed to by fats, oil, and greases (FOG). The requirements of this section shall be applicable to all food service establishments and other industrial or commercial businesses or establishments which sanitary sewage containing FOG. Users of the POTW may be required by the board to install, implement, and maintain, grease traps, interceptors, or other board-approved strategies to avoid introduction of FOG into the POTW in accordance with the provisions hereof. 
(1)  Grease traps, interceptors, or other board-approved devices shall be installed at the customer's expense when required by the board at food service establishments or other such industrial or commercial establishments as may be identified by the board as posing a risk of introducing FOG into the board's POTW. These devices must meet the board's engineering standards and provide a minimum retention time of ten minutes between influent and effluent baffles with 20 percent of the total volume as allowance for a sludge pocket. 
(2)  Upon written notification to a food service establishment or other industrial or commercial establishment that the board will require a grease trap device for an existing location currently served by the board, the customer must bring its establishment into compliance within 90 days. Compliance will not occur until the required devices are operational and approved by the board. Grease trap devices shall be available for inspection by the board or its staff at all reasonable times. 
(3)  All grease traps, interceptors, or other board-approved devices shall be serviced and emptied of accumulated waste content as required in order to maintain minimum design capability or effective volume of the device but not less often than every 60 days or as otherwise permitted by the board. This servicing will be at the expense of the customer. 
(4)  The customer shall maintain written records of maintenance for a period of three years from the date the maintenance is performed. All such records shall be available for inspection by the board at all times. These records shall include the following: 
(a)  Customer name and physical location. 
(b)  Date and time of grease device service. 
(c)  Name of grease device servicing company. 
(d)  Name and signature of grease interceptor servicing company agent performing said service. 
(e)  Type of service provided (full pump out, partial pump out, etc.). 
(f)  Approximated amount of grease and solids removed from device. 
(g)  Total volume of waste removed. 
(h)  Destination of removed wastes, food solids, and wastewater disposal. 
(i)  Signature and date of customer personnel confirming service completion. 
(j)  Such other information as required by board. 
(5)  Requests for modifications to or variances from the requirements of this article shall be made in writing to the board. Variances from the pumping frequency requirement will be considered only after one year of data has been documented for the site in question. Any such variance will be considered only if the board is satisfied that reduced pumping frequency will not compromise the operation of the surrounding system. Any modification or variance to maintenance and service schedules and procedures shall be subject to annual renewal by the board. 
(6)  Failure to comply with the requirements of this section 20-205 will constitute a violation of this article punishable as provided under section 20-99 of this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 13-129; Ord. No. 2009-145, § 3, 7-27-2009; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-206. - Pretreatment facilities. 
    Owners shall provide the necessary wastewater treatment as required to comply with the provisions of this article. Any facilities required for pretreatment shall be acceptable to the board and shall be provided, operated, and maintained at the expense of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Secs. 20-207-20-233. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY DETERMINATIONS 

Sec. 20-234. - Standard of quality-Rate of delivery of effluent and waste. 
    The delivery of all effluent and waste from a producer to the POTW shall be at a reasonable uniform rate, as produced without storage by the producer, except that storage which is necessary in the pretreatment process of the producer. 
(Code 1992, § 13-140; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-235. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person who is engaged in the process of collecting, storing, or holding wastewaters, oils, grease, portable toilet waste, grease trap contents, or sand trap contents shall deposit any of these wastes, oils, or greases into the POTW. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or place any semiliquid waste material including, but not limited to, waste cleaned from septic tanks and portable sources into the POTW except through a duly authorized permanent connection thereto, or if dumped from a portable source then in conformity with the following: 
(1)  No such material will be placed or dumped into the POTW except under the immediate supervision of employees designated for that purpose on duty at the public sewer treatment plant. 
(2)  Each person dumping or placing waste in the POTW from portable sources shall pay to the board a service fee as prescribed by the board per month for each month during which any of such material is dumped or placed, plus an additional amount as so prescribed per each 1,000 gallons of waste dumped into the POTW. 
(Code 1992, § 13-141; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 20-236. - Quantity determination. 
(a)  The quantity of waste delivered to the POTW will be calculated as the amount of water delivered to the owner by the board's water system, unless a separate, owner-provided wastewater meter acceptable to the board is available. If well water is used, it shall be metered and the monthly quantity used reported to the board. All metering devices shall be subject to the approval of the board, and the owner shall provide access and pay for all costs incurred for meter reading and billing. Meters shall be maintained, calibrated, and serviced on a regular basis, and documentation of all maintenance, calibration, and service shall be provided to the board. 
(b)  If the amount of water delivered to a customer of the board is used for the basis of quantity of waste determination, and if the customer's consumption of water does not result in delivery of water consumed to the POTW, it shall be the obligation of the customer to install, calibrate, maintain, and service meters acceptable to the board to measure this consumption so that the board may consider, upon request, an appropriate adjustment to the measurement of the quantity of waste delivered to the POTW for billing purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Secs. 20-237-20-263. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PRIVATE WATER WELLS 

Sec. 20-264. - Purpose and scope. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect the water resources of the city (both present and potential) to control the drilling, construction and reconstruction of private wells through a system of permits and to secure to all persons within the city an equal distribution of municipal water. 
(Code 1979, § 19-14.1(A); Code 1992, § 13-170; Ord. No. 88-43, 5-31-1988) 
Sec. 20-265. - Permit. 
    No person shall construct, reconstruct or drill a private well within the corporate limits of the city unless such person first obtains a private well permit from the water and wastewater board in the manner set forth by the board. 
(Code 1979, § 19-14.1(B); Code 1992, § 13-171; Ord. No. 88-43, 5-31-1988) 
Sec. 20-266. - Connection to board water system prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, tenant or one having in charge property upon which a private water well is located to make or cause to be made or permit to continue to exist any physical connection between a private water well and its pumping system and the public water distribution system of the board and the city. Check valves, either manual or automatic, placed between the private supply and the public distribution system of the board and the city shall not constitute satisfactory compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1979, § 19-14.1(G); Code 1992, § 13-172; Ord. No. 88-43, 5-31-1988) 
Sec. 20-267. - Private water well used as discharging point. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and dangerous to the public health for any private water well within the corporate limits of the city to be employed as a discharging point for any waters or wastes of any kind, liquid, inorganic, or organic. 
(Code 1979, § 19-14.1(H); Code 1992, § 13-173; Ord. No. 88-43, 5-31-1988) 
Sec. 20-268. - Authorization for removal from city distribution system. 
    In the event that any private water well or its pumping system fails to comply with any of the provisions of section 20-266, the board is hereby empowered and directed to disconnect and remove in an appropriate manner the property served by such private well system from the city distribution system. 
(Code 1979, § 19-14.1(I); Code 1992, § 13-174; Ord. No. 88-43, 5-31-1988) 
Secs. 20-269-20-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WATER CONSERVATION 

Sec. 20-300. - Scope. 
    There is hereby established a city water conservation plan. 
(Code 1992, § 14-111; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 1, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-301. - Declaration of policy. 
    It is hereby declared that, because of water conditions prevailing and which may prevail in the city, the general welfare requires that the water resources available to the city be put to the maximum beneficial use of the public and the customers of the water and wastewater board of the city (hereinafter referred to as the "board") and that the waste or unreasonable use, or unreasonable methods of use of water be prevented and the conservation of such water is to be extended with a view to the reasonable and beneficial use thereof in the interests of the people of the city, other customers of the board and for the public health and welfare. 
(Code 1992, § 14-112; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 2, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-302. - Authorization. 
    The board, through its management and through the enforcement powers of the city, is hereby authorized and directed to implement the applicable provisions of this article based upon a determination that such implementation is necessary to protect the public health and welfare and safety. 
(Code 1992, § 14-113; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 3, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-303. - Application. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all persons, customers and property utilizing water from the board wherever situated. 
(Code 1992, § 14-114; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 4, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-304. - Water conservation stages. 
(a)  Water use prohibited when contrary to guidelines. It shall be a violation of this article for any person who uses water from the board knowingly to make, cause, use or permit the use of water received from the board for residential, commercial, industrial, agricultural, governmental, or any other purpose in a manner contrary to any provision of this article, or in an amount in excess of that use permitted by the water conservation stage in effect under this article. The board is hereby authorized and directed to promulgate guidelines which shall set forth the criteria for determining when a particular water conservation stage is to be implemented and terminated. Such guidelines will be updated when, in the determination of the board, the conditions of the water production and distribution system have changed so as to necessitate such an update. 
(b)  Conservation stages adopted. The following progressive water conservation stages are adopted for implementation by the board as deemed necessary under its guidelines: 
(1)  Stage I-Voluntary conservation. Customers of or persons who use the water utility of the board are requested to voluntarily limit the amount of water to the amount absolutely necessary for health, business and outdoor use. 
(2)  Stage II-Water alert (mandatory compliance). Under stage II-water alert, the following restrictions on the use of water shall apply to all customers of or persons who use the water utility of the board. Use of water supplied by the board in violation of these restrictions after implementation and publication of stage II water conservation measures is prohibited and is a violation of this article. 
a.  Upon implementation and publication of stage II water conservation measures by the board, use of water for the following purposes is prohibited except as provided in subsection (b)(2)b of this section: irrigation utilizing individual sprinklers from hoses, or buried sprinkler systems for the purpose of watering lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs and other plants and filling, re-filling or replenishing ponds, lakes or other natural or manmade private reservoirs. 
b.  Notwithstanding, the prohibition on water usage for the purposes stated in subsection (b)(2)a of this section, water provided by the board may be used under stage II water conservation measures within the following restrictions: 
1.  Irrigation of lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs or other plants is permissible at odd numbered street addresses on odd days of the month and even numbered street addresses on even days of the month. 
2.  Commercial nurseries are exempt from these restrictions but shall restrict water use to the minimum amount absolutely necessary for survival of their inventory of plants, shrubs, sod, etc. 
3.  There is further exempt from the restriction use of any hand-held garden hoses or small hand-held watering containers which may be used on any day to water small areas that might need more frequent watering. 
(3)  Stage III-Water warning (mandatory compliance). Under a stage III-water warning, the following restrictions on the use of water shall apply to all customers of, or persons who use water supplied by the board. Use of water supplied by the board in violation of these restrictions after implementation and publication of stage III water conservation measures is prohibited and is a violation of this article. 
a.  Upon implementation and publication of stage III water conservation measures by the board, use of water for the following purposes is prohibited except as provided in subsection (b)(3)b of this section: irrigation of lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs, crops or other plants, washing of private vehicles, filling, re-filling or replenishing swimming pools, washing of sidewalks, streets, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios, or other paved areas, or filling, re-filling or replenishing ponds, lakes or other natural or manmade private reservoirs. 
b.  Notwithstanding, the prohibition on water usage for the purposes stated in subsection (b)(3)a of this section, water provided by the board may be used under stage III water conservation measures within the following restrictions: 
1.  Irrigation of lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs or other plants, washing private vehicles and filling, re-filling or replenishing swimming pools is permissible two days each week on the following basis: user of water at odd-numbered street addresses may use water for these purposes on either Saturday or Sunday and Wednesday or Thursday, except between the hours 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m., of when such day is an odd numbered day of the month. Users of water at even numbered street addresses may use water for these purposes for either Saturday or Sunday and Wednesday or Thursday, except between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m., when such day is on an even numbered day of the month. The intent of this provision is to authorize two days each week for each customer or user when water may be used for the stated purposes, except between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
2.  Commercial nurseries are exempt from these restrictions but shall restrict water use to the minimum amount absolutely necessary for survival of their inventory of plants, shrubs, sod, etc. 
3.  Commercial car washes and service stations are exempt from the restrictions applicable to washing private vehicles but shall exercise all reasonably available means of minimizing water usage. 
4.  Sidewalks, streets, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios or other paved areas may be washed only by the city public works department or fire department when necessary for public health or safety reasons. 
5.  Otherwise lawful use of water from a fire hydrant is prohibited without a permit from the board's management for an express purpose, amount and written date on which the fire hydrant may be used. Utility crews, the public works department and fire department are exempt from this provision in order that they may properly maintain utility systems and provide for public health and safety. 
c.  Placing or setting individual sprinklers from hoses or settings for underground sprinkler systems so as to allow a significant amount of water to be sprayed into the street or on driveways is prohibited. 
(4)  Stage IV-Water emergency. Under a stage IV-water emergency, the following restrictions on the use of water shall apply to all customers or persons who use water provided by the board. Use of water supplied by the board in violation of these restrictions after implementation and publication of stage IV water conservation measures is prohibited and is a violation of this article. 
a.  Upon implementation and publication of stage IV water conservation measures by the board, use of water for the following purposes is prohibited except as provided in subsection (b)(4)b of this section: Irrigation of lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs, crops or other plants, washing or private vehicles, filling, re-filling or replenishing swimming pools, washing of sidewalks, streets, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios or other paved areas, or filling, re-filling or replenishing ponds, lakes or other natural or manmade private reservoirs. 
b.  Notwithstanding the prohibition on water usage for the purposes stated in subsection (b)(4)a of this section, water provided by the board may be used under stage IV water conservation measures within the following restrictions: 
1.  Commercial nurseries are exempt from these restrictions but shall restrict water use to the minimum amount absolutely necessary for survival of their inventory of plants, shrubs, sod, etc. 
2.  Commercial car washes and service stations are exempt from the restrictions applicable to washing private vehicles but shall exercise all reasonably available means of minimizing water usage. 
3.  Water from fire hydrants may only be used by utility crews, the department of public works and the fire department. 
4.  Sidewalks, streets, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios or other paved areas may be washed only by the city public works department or fire department when necessary for public health or safety reasons. 
(Code 1992, § 14-115; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 5, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-305. - Compliance for golf courses and tennis courses. 
(a)  Any golf course or driving range, either public or private, that uses water provided by the board for watering greens and fairways must comply with the watering restrictions imposed by water alert (stage II) or water warning (stage III) and water emergency (stage IV) restrictions in this article. 
(b)  Tennis courts (public or private) utilizing rubico surfaces are exempt from the restrictions of stage II and stage III, but shall exercise all reasonably available means of minimizing water usage. 
(Code 1992, § 14-116; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 6, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-306. - Mandatory conservation stage implementation. 
(a)  Based on criteria established by the board, management of the board may order the appropriate stage of water conservation to be implemented or terminated in accordance with the applicable provision of this article. 
(b)  Management of the board shall monitor its pumping capacity and supply available from other systems as well as demand for water by its customers on a daily basis during periods of hot and/or dry weather or other water supply emergency conditions. Because certain of the board's back-up water supply is available from Huntsville's Utilities system, the board shall also monitor potential mandatory conservation stage implementation by Huntsville. 
(c)  At any time during which the board is drawing water from its connection to Huntsville Utilities' system, the water conservation stage ordered by the board shall be at least as high as the stage implemented by Huntsville Utilities at the same time, until conditions are such that the board no longer needs to draw water from its back-up connection to Huntsville Utilities' system to meet customer demand. 
(d)  Any order of board management of a water conservation stage under this article shall be made by public announcement and shall be published in a daily newspaper in general circulation in the city. The implementation of water conservation measures shall be effective immediately upon such publication. Publication shall continue on a daily basis until such time as all restrictions are removed, which fact shall also be published daily for three days upon removal of restrictions. 
(Code 1992, § 14-117; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 7, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-307. - Area implementation. 
    Due to the varied elevations, service areas with varied pumping and storage capacities, certain areas of the city or service areas of the board outside of the city that utilize the water provided by the board may be designated to be in different stages of conservation at various times. 
(Code 1992, § 14-118; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 8, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-308. - Presumption. 
    Any person, firm or corporation in whose name water service is currently registered by the board and who or which has received water for the board for residential, commercial, industrial, agricultural, governmental, or any other purpose in a manner contrary to any provision of this article, or in an amount in excess of the use permitted by the conservation stage then in effect, is presumed to have knowingly made, caused, used or permitted said water to be used in violation of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 14-119; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 9, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-309. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or association violating any provision of this article who or which may be found within the corporate limits of the city shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of an offense and shall be punished as provided in section 1-9(c). The violation of each provision and each separate violation thereof shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be punished accordingly. 
(Code 1992, § 14-120; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 10, 6-26-2000) 
Sec. 20-310. - Other means of securing compliance. 
    The board is expressly granted authority to secure compliance with this article by seeking injunctive relief against any person, firm or corporation in violation of provision of this article or by discontinuing water service to any person, firm or corporation who or which is a customer of the board or user of water supplied by the board and is found to have used water in a manner or an amount contrary to any provision of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 14-121; Ord. No. 2000-98, § 11, 6-26-2000) 
Secs. 20-311-20-338. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GARBAGE AND TRASH[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Solid Waste Disposal Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-1 et seq.; local solid waste management programs, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-47. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 20-339-20-364. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRASH COLLECTION FEE 

Sec. 20-365. - Charge. 
    There is hereby established and assessed a mandatory monthly trash collection charge of per single-family residential unit fronting on a publicly dedicated street in the city, except as otherwise provided herein, which fee shall be due and payable monthly. The amount of the charge shall be as established by the mayor and council, from time to time. 
(Code 1992, § 13-201; Ord. No. 92-40, § 1, 4-14-1992; Ord. No. 2004-285, § 1, 12-21-2004; Ord. No. 2006-242, § 1, 10-9-2006; Ord. No. 2014-193, § 1, 9-22-2014) 
Sec. 20-366. - Billing. 
    Charges assessed by this article shall be billed to residential electric customers of Athens Utilities and Huntsville Utilities residing within the corporate limits of the city and receiving regular monthly water bills. 
(Code 1992, § 13-202; Ord. No. 92-40, § 2, 4-14-1992; Ord. No. 2004-285, § 12-21-2004; Ord. No. 2006-242, § 2, 10-9-2006; Ord. No. 2012-408, § 1, 11-26-2012) 
Sec. 20-367. - Trash collected. 
    The city will collect trash, yard waste or metal or "white goods" generated at or by all residential dwelling units fronting, or in a development or complex fronting, a publicly dedicated street in the city. The term "white goods" for purposes of this article includes large household appliances such as refrigerators, washers, dryers, water heaters, etc. 
(Code 1992, § 13-203; Ord. No. 92-40, § 3, 4-14-1992; Ord. No. 2004-285, § 3, 12-21-2004; Ord. No. 2006-242, § 3, 10-9-2006) 
Sec. 20-368. - Material not collected. 
    The city will not collect, haul or dispose of the following material under this article: 
(1)  Household garbage. 
(2)  Hazardous waste as defined by the state department of environmental management, including, but not limited to, gasoline, oil, paint, other petroleum-based products, or similar liquid toxic wastes, and containers containing residue of any such liquid wastes, pathological or medical waste or refuse, batteries, dead animals or animal waste, or other waste deemed hazardous by the collector. 
(3)  Trash or yard waste generated by a commercial landscaper. 
(4)  Materials or debris generated from construction work that requires a city permit issued by the building department. 
(5)  Tree limbs or trimmings resulting from land clearing or cuttings by tree service contractors or commercial workmen. 
(6)  Rocks, dirt or other debris resulting from landscaping or construction. 
(7)  Yard waste, trash, white or metal goods, etc. exceeding five cubic yards, except as provided in section 20-369. 
(8)  Trash, yard waste, white or metal goods or any other class of garbage or refuse generated by any business or by any residential unit in a private residential complex or development not fronting on a publicly dedicated street. 
(Code 1992, § 13-204; Ord. No. 92-40, § 4, 4-14-1992; Ord. No. 2004-285, § 4, 12-21-2004; Ord. No. 2006-242, § 4, 10-9-2006; Ord. No. 2017-78, § 1, 5-8-2017) 
Sec. 20-369. - Material collected. 
    Yard waste, trash, white or metal goods, etc. which exceeds five cubic yards may be collected pursuant to prior arrangement with the department of public works for a charge per five cubic yards beyond the first five cubic yards, provided, however, that the charge shall not exceed $150.00 per trailer load (20 cubic yards). The amount of the charge shall be as established by the mayor and council, from time to time. 
(Code 1992, § 13-205; Ord. No. 92-40, § 5, 4-14-1992; Ord. No. 2004-285, § 5, 12-21-2004; Ord. No. 2006-242, § 5, 10-9-2006) 
Sec. 20-370. - Promulgation of rules. 
    The director of the department of public works is hereby authorized and directed to promulgate such reasonable rules, regulations and guidelines, not inconsistent with this article, as deemed necessary to effectuate the efficient and timely collection of trash, yard waste, white or metal goods, etc. under this article, and to publish said rules, regulations, or guidelines to residences subject to the charges authorized by this article.
