(b)  For the purposes of this article and the enforcement thereof, the definitions contained in section 24-99 shall be applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 2, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 24-143. - Application. 
(a)  Any person seeking issuance of a parade/race permit shall file an application with the police chief not less than 60 days before the date on which the applicant proposes to conduct the parade or race. 
(b)  The police chief, in his sole discretion and where good cause is shown therefor, may consider any application filed less than 60 days before the date such parade or race is proposed to be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 2, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 24-144. - Contents of application. 
    An application for a parade/race permit shall set forth: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade or race. 
(2)  If the parade or race is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the local authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade or race chairperson and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(4)  The date when the parade or race is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point, and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade or race; the type of animals expected to be involved; and a description of the vehicles to be used. 
(7)  The hours when such parade or race will start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade or race will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade or race. 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade or race will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas. 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade or race. 
(12)  If the parade or race is designed to be held by, on behalf of, or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the police chief a written request from the person proposing to hold the parade or race authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(13)  Any additional information which the police chief shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 2, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 24-145. - Standards for issuance. 
(a)  The police chief shall issue a permit as provided for herein when, from a consideration of the application and from such other reasonable information as may be otherwise obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade or race will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade or race will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The conduct of such parade or race will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of travel and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade or race will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of such parade or race will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The conduct of the parade or race is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct, or to create a disturbance. 
(7)  The parade or race is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(8)  The parade or race is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(b)  The content or viewpoint of any message of the parade or race shall not be considered by the police chief in determining whether to issue the permit nor shall any person, group or organization be unlawfully discriminated against in the grant or denial of a permit. 
(c)  Any parade/race permit which will require the temporary closing of a public street shall be granted subject to approval by the director of the public works department. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 2, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 24-146. - Appeal procedure. 
    The appeal procedure found in section 24-108 shall govern any appeal of the denial of a parade/race permit. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 2, 5-14-2012) 
Secs. 24-147-24-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FUNERAL PROCESSIONS 

Sec. 24-176. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article and the enforcement thereof, the definitions contained in section 24-99 shall be applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 3, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 24-177. - Notice to police department. 
    In order for the police department to provide escorts and traffic control for a funeral procession, the attending funeral director must provide the police chief notice of the need for the same at least 24 hours prior to the beginning of the funeral service. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 3, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 24-178. - Driving through funeral processions or other convoys. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral procession or other authorized convoy unless directed to do so by a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 3, 5-14-2012) 
Sec. 24-179. - Drivers in a convoy or funeral procession. 
(a)  No funeral procession or driver of any vehicle in a funeral procession may be granted any special right-of-way nor permitted to violate any provision of law or ordinance governing the movement of vehicles unless such funeral procession is escorted by police officers pursuant to procedures established by the police chief. If such police escort is provided, the drivers in a funeral procession shall be subject to the direction of the police officers providing the escort and it shall be unlawful for such a driver to fail to comply with any order or direction of a police officer or to violate any provision of law unless directed to do so by a police officer. 
(b)  Each driver in a funeral procession or other authorized convoy shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practicable subject to the direction of a police officer and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as practicable and safe. 
(c)  Vehicles in funeral processions or other authorized convoys shall operate their headlamps and emergency flashers while traveling upon the streets of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 3, 5-14-2012) 
Chapter 26 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Personnel system-Purpose; enforcement. 
(a)  There is hereby established a personnel system for the city based on the following principles: 
(1)  That the recruiting, selection and advancement of employees for the city should be on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge and skill and that open competition of qualified applicants for initial employment by the city should be encouraged whenever practical; 
(2)  That a city employee should be retained or separated on the basis of the city's needs, the adequacy of the employee's performance, efforts made to correct inadequate performance and compliance of the employee with clearly established rules governing conduct; 
(3)  That training for employees should be provided where possible to assure high quality performance; and 
(4)  That employees and applicants for city positions should be assured fair and equitable treatment in all aspects of personnel administration without regard to political affiliation, sex, race, color, religion or national origin. 
(b)  The mayor shall be responsible for ensuring that the personnel system created herein and the personnel policies and procedures adopted pursuant to this chapter are properly enforced within the city. 
(Code 1992, § 15-1; Ord. No. 90-95, §§ 1, 7, 2-26-1991) 
Sec. 26-2. - Same-Coverage. 
(a)  The city personnel system shall cover all employees including those full-time, part-time and temporary employees currently employed by the city, but shall not include or cover the following: 
(1)  Members of the municipal governing body and other elected officials; 
(2)  Members of appointed boards and commissions, municipal judges and municipal attorneys; 
(3)  Volunteer personnel who receive no regular compensation from the city; 
(4)  Persons performing work under contract for the city who are not carried on the payroll as employees; 
(5)  Other persons as may be designated by the city council. 
(b)  The city personnel system shall also include employees who serve as department heads or officers designated by the city council pursuant to the state law (i.e., the fire chief, police chief, city clerk and city treasurer). Such individuals will serve at the pleasure of the mayor and/or city council in accordance with state law and city-adopted policies and procedures. 
(Code 1992, § 15-2; Ord. No. 90-95, § 2, 2-26-1991) 
Sec. 26-3. - Same-Adoption of personnel policies and procedures. 
    To serve as guidelines for the implementation of the intent of this chapter, the city council hereby adopts by reference and incorporates herein as if fully set out the "Personnel Policies and Procedures of the City of Madison, AL," as approved by the mayor and city council on Feb. 26, 1991, and as later amended. Such policies and procedures, to include rules, regulations and plans for the implementation of the personnel system established by this chapter, shall become effective upon passage by majority vote of the city council. The policies and procedures shall provide for: 
(1)  Classification of employees; 
(2)  Staffing procedures; 
(3)  Promotion procedures; 
(4)  Development of a performance appraisal system; 
(5)  Demotion or separation of employees; 
(6)  Disciplinary procedures; 
(7)  Employee grievance and appeal procedures; 
(8)  Establishment of hours of work, holidays, vacations, leaves with pay and procedures relating to leave without pay; 
(9)  Such other matters as may be necessary to carry out the intent and purpose of this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 15-3; Ord. No. 90-95, § 3, 2-26-1991) 
Sec. 26-4. - Approval of job descriptions. 
    Approval of job descriptions for each department head position and for each assistant or deputy department head position, as defined by the city council on the most recent class plan, shall be the responsibility of the city council. 
    Approval of all other job descriptions for positions within the city service shall be the responsibility of the city council's human resources committee. 
(Code 1992, § 15-4; Ord. No. 90-95, § 4, 2-26-1991; Ord. No. 2014-344, § 1, 12-22-2014) 
Sec. 26-5. - Policies and procedures for the use of municipal credit cards. 
(a)  Policies. 
(1)  A municipal credit card holder statement of responsibility form shall be signed by each officer or employee assigned or allowed to use a municipal credit card. The signed forms will be kept on file in the treasurer's office. 
(2)  Each credit card holder shall be responsible for limiting the credit card charges to the budgeted amount for which charges are incurred. 
(3)  Each credit card holder shall be personally responsible for all purchases charged on his assigned municipal credit card which are not approved for payment in accordance with the procedures set forth below and in accordance with sections 10-83 and 10-84. 
(4)  In accordance with sections 10-83 and 10-84, an officer or employee may be required to reimburse the city for any charges the city council deems not necessary to official municipal business or where an officer or employee has no receipt to support the charge on the municipal credit card bill. 
(5)  Any credit card holder who fails to timely file requests for payment in time to avoid the imposition of finance charges shall be personally liable for the payment of finance charges assessed. 
(b)  Procedures. 
(1)  Each officer or employee making charges against a municipal credit card, and within five days after returning from out-of-town travel during which such charges were made, shall provide to the finance department a request for payment form with receipts of all expenses charged to the municipal credit card during the travel out of town. 
(2)  The request for payment form with the receipts shall be checked against the credit card statement, and if all receipts are noted on the statement, payment shall be made in accordance with sections 10-83 and 10-84. 
(Code 1992, § 15-5; Res. No. 93-152-R, 11-9-1993) 
Secs. 26-6-26-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOCIAL SECURITY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Social security for city employees, Code of Ala. 1975, § 36-28-1 et seq. 

Sec. 26-29. - General policy and purpose. 
    It is declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective as of January 1, 1956, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law or by this article and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of old age and survivor's insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734 of the 81st Congress. In pursuance of such policy and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 16-6; Code 1992, § 15-20) 
Sec. 26-30. - Adoption of terms, conditions, etc. 
    The city adopts the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges and other conditions thereunto appertaining of Title II of the Social Security Act as amended by Public Law No. 734, of the 81st Congress, for and on behalf of all the officials and employees thereof, except any official or employee who occupies any position, office or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and further excluding elected officials and emergency employees. 
(Code 1979, § 16-7; Code 1992, § 15-21) 
Sec. 26-31. - Execution of necessary agreements and amendments. 
    The mayor is authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state agency authorized to act to secure coverage of employees and officials as provided in this article. 
(Code 1979, § 16-8; Code 1992, § 15-22) 
Sec. 26-32. - Withholdings from salaries and wages. 
    Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided in this article are authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations and shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1979, § 16-9; Code 1992, § 15-23) 
Sec. 26-33. - Employer's contributions. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions which shall be paid over to the state agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such funds. 
(Code 1979, § 16-10; Code 1992, § 15-24) 
Sec. 26-34. - Records and reports. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 16-11; Code 1992, § 15-25) 
Secs. 26-35-26-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to create the office of and prescribe duties for police chief, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-5; municipal authority to establish a police force, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-55. 

Sec. 26-57. - Chief of police-Appointment; term; qualifications; removal. 
    The police chief shall be appointed by the city council for a term coextensive with that of the mayor, conditioned upon good conduct and efficiency. The chief shall meet qualifications in training and experience set by the council and shall have the ability to command persons and hold their respect and confidence. The chief may be removed before the end of the term only for just cause and after a hearing before the city council. 
(Code 1992, § 15-29) 
Sec. 26-58. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    In addition to the powers conferred and duties imposed upon the chief of police by the laws of the state and other ordinances of the city, the chief shall have the following powers and perform the following duties: 
(1)  Attendance at council meetings. For preservation of good order at all city council meetings, the chief or the chief's designee shall be in attendance. 
(2)  Attending courts. The chief or the chief's designee shall attend all the sessions of court held by the municipal judge, and preserve good order during the sitting of the court. 
(3)  Police department supervision; requiring police department personnel to discharge duties. The chief shall be the supervisor of the whole police department of the city and as such it shall be the chief's positive duty, without fear or favor, to require and see that every member of the police department shall discharge such member's whole duty. 
(4)  Guardianship of peace, safety and good order of the city. The chief shall have and exercise a general and particular care and guardianship over the peace, safety and good order of the city. 
(5)  Enforcement of laws, etc. It shall be the duty of the chief to enforce, and to see that all police department personnel shall enforce, all the laws within the city. 
(6)  Arrest of offenders. The city shall have the power and it is made such officer's duty to arrest all persons who violate the penal laws of the state in the city and who violate any provision of a city ordinance, and all such arrests shall be made as provided by state laws and city ordinances. 
(7)  Duty upon arrest. When a person is arrested, the chief of police or any officer of the police department under the chief's command shall bring such person before the municipal judge or magistrate for examination and commitment for the violation of a state law or for trial for the violation of a city ordinance. 
(8)  Execution of writs, warrants, summonses, etc. The chief shall, without delay, execute all writs; writs of arrest; warrants; summonses; executions; rules; attachments; notices; and all other processes, original, mesne and final, which may be issued by the municipal judge, and sell property in the city under execution and make title to real property so sold by such officer. 
(9)  Authority as sheriffs, etc. In the discharge of the duties above imposed, the chief shall have all the rights and powers that sheriffs and other peace officers of the state have and be entitled to all protection, privileges and immunities to which they are entitled. 
(10)  Administration of police department personnel. The chief of police shall have the power to administer personnel of the police department in accordance with the personnel policies and procedures of the city, and state law. 
(11)  Requiring police officers to make daily reports. The chief shall require each supervisor, i.e., captain, sergeant and detective, to make to such chief a daily report of all violations of law which have come to such supervisor's knowledge or about which such supervisor has information. Detectives are to give status reports on all cases active at the time of reporting. 
(12)  Appointment of community mental health officers. The chief shall have the authority to designate on behalf of the city one or more community mental health officers to act as liaisons to the general public within the jurisdiction of City of Madison. The chief shall have the authority to appoint employees as community mental health officers if they possess a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university in social work or a related field, or if they possess an equivalent combination of education and experience according to findings of the judge of probate. In addition, community mental health officers must possess the following: at least one year of experience in social work; knowledge of the principals, practices, and techniques of social work as they apply to crisis intervention; knowledge of the theory, principles, and practices of psychiatric social work; knowledge of federal, state, and municipal laws regarding the aiding of mental patients; and knowledge of the functions and resources of public and private social agencies in the community. 
(13)  Execution of judgments and orders of municipal judge. The chief shall have power to execute all the judgments and orders of the municipal judge condemning a person to imprisonment, to work on the streets or any other work for the city. 
(14)  Monthly report to mayor. The chief shall make a report, once in each month, to the mayor of all that has been done since the last report. 
(15)  Moneys to be paid over daily to the city treasurer; monthly report to the mayor. All the money belonging to the city which the chief may collect or receive, the chief shall pay over daily to the city treasurer and take the treasurer's receipt therefor, showing from whom such chief received the money and on what account; and the chief shall make a separate report of this to the mayor once each month, and more often if required. 
(16)  Report of occurrences requiring immediate action of mayor. If at any time anything should occur requiring the immediate action of the mayor, the chief of police shall report it forthwith. 
(17)  Arrest of drunk and disorderly persons. If any person shall be found drunk on the streets and disturbing in any way whatsoever the quiet of the city or the comfort or convenience of any other person, it shall be the duty of the chief or any officer of the police department under the chiefs' command to arrest such person and carry such person before the municipal judge. 
(18)  Enforcement of laws relative to bootlegging and gambling. It is the duty of the chief to use all lawful means to break up all bootlegging and gambling houses, gambling saloons or gaming tables of all kinds and descriptions. 
(19)  Duty upon alarm of fire. On the alarm of fire, it shall be the duty of the chief to report at once to the fire, and when there it shall be the special duty of the chief to protect and guard the fire department from all interruption or interference, which the chief shall accomplish either personally or by assigning police officers to such duty. 
(20)  Summon persons to aid in guarding property. It shall be the duty of the chief to guard and protect all property and for that purpose such officer shall have power to summon any citizen between the ages of 21 and 60 years to aid in guarding and taking care of property removed from any houses; and any person refusing, when summoned to render such aid, shall be reported to the mayor, and shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1979, § 17-1; Code 1992, § 15-30; Ord. No. 2016-258, § 1, 10-11-2016) 
Sec. 26-59. - Powers and duties of police officers. 
    The police officers of the city shall have the following powers and perform the following duties: 
(1)  Obedience to the mayor and chief of police. They shall, in all things pertaining to their office, obey the orders and directions of the mayor and chief of police. 
(2)  Devotion of whole time on duty to discharge of duty. They shall, giving up all other things, devote their whole time while on duty to the discharge of their duty. 
(3)  Preservation of order, peace and quiet. They shall, at all times, in all places and under all circumstances, preserve order, peace and quiet in the city. 
(4)  Powers conferred by state law and Code on chief of police. Each of the police officers of the city shall have all powers that are conferred on the chief of police by the laws of the state and the provisions of this section and other city ordinances, subject to the direction and control of the mayor or chief of police in the exercise of their power. 
(5)  Duties required by chief of police. All police department personnel shall perform all of the duties required of the chief of police by the laws of the state and the provisions of this section and all other ordinances of the city, subject to the direction and control of the chief of police. 
(6)  Ex officio animal control officers. Each police officer shall be an ex officio animal control officer, and as such control officer it shall be such officer's duty to see that all provisions of the animal control ordinances are complied with to the fullest extent. 
(Code 1979, § 17-3; Code 1992, § 15-32) 
Secs. 26-60-26-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to maintain and operate a fire department, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-140. 

Sec. 26-77. - Appointment, term, qualifications, and removal of chief. 
    The fire chief shall be appointed by the city council for a term coextensive with that of the mayor, conditioned upon good conduct and efficiency. The fire chief shall be technically qualified by training and experience and shall have the ability to command persons and hold their respect and confidence. During the term of office of the chief, the chief shall be removed only for just cause and after a hearing before the city council. 
(Code 1979, § 9-26; Code 1992, § 15-40) 
Sec. 26-78. - Formulation of rules and regulations; responsibility for efficiency, etc. 
    The fire chief shall formulate a set of rules and regulations to govern the fire department, provided such rules and regulations are not inconsistent with the rules and regulations adopted for the city as a whole and shall be responsible to the city council for the personnel, morals and general efficiency of the fire department. 
(Code 1979, § 9-27; Code 1992, § 15-41) 
Sec. 26-79. - Suppression of arson. 
    The fire chief shall assist the proper authorities in suppressing the crime of arson by investigating or causing to be investigated the cause, origin and circumstances of all fires. 
(Code 1979, § 9-30; Code 1992, § 15-42) 
Sec. 26-80. - Right of entry. 
    The fire chief shall have authority to enter any building and premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of making inspections and to serve written notice upon the owner or occupant to abate, within a specified time, any fire hazard that may be found. 
(Code 1979, § 9-31; Code 1992, § 15-43) 
Sec. 26-81. - Records. 
    The fire chief shall see that complete records are kept of all fires, inspections, apparatus and minor equipment, personnel and other information about the work of the fire department. 
(Code 1979, § 9-32; Code 1992, § 15-44) 
Sec. 26-82. - Reports-Monthly report. 
    The fire chief shall report monthly to the mayor the conditions of the apparatus and equipment, the number of fires during the month, their location and cause, the date of such fires and the loss occasioned thereby, the number and purpose of all other runs made, the number of members responding to each fire or other run and any changes in membership. 
(Code 1979, § 9-33; Code 1992, § 15-45) 
Sec. 26-83. - Same-Annual report. 
    The fire chief shall make a complete annual report to the city council within one month after the close of the fiscal year, such report to include the information specified in section 26-82, together with comparative data for previous years and recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the fire department. 
(Code 1979, § 9-34; Code 1992, § 15-46) 
Sec. 26-84. - Officer accountability. 
    The fire chief shall be held accountable to the mayor only and shall make written and verbal reports as the mayor may require. All other fire department and company officers shall be accountable to the fire chief only. 
(Code 1979, § 9-20; Code 1992, § 15-48) 
Sec. 26-85. - Equipment required. 
    The fire department shall be equipped with such apparatus and other equipment as may be required from time to time to maintain its efficiency and properly protect life and property from fire. 
(Code 1979, § 9-13; Code 1992, § 15-49) 
Sec. 26-86. - Wrongful use of equipment. 
    No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private purpose, nor shall any person willfully and without proper authority take away or conceal any article used in any way by the fire department. 
(Code 1979, § 9-17; Code 1992, § 15-50) 
Sec. 26-87. - Handling, etc., of equipment by unauthorized persons. 
    No person shall enter any place where fire apparatus is housed or handle any apparatus or equipment belonging to the fire department unless accompanied by or having the special permission of an officer or authorized member of the department. 
(Code 1979, § 9-18; Code 1992, § 15-51) 
Secs. 26-88-26-117. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESERVE POLICE FORCE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Reserve law enforcement officers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-210. 

Sec. 26-118. - Establishment. 
    As provided by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-210, a police reserve force, (hereinafter referred to as "auxiliary"), is hereby established within the police department of the city. 
(Code 1992, § 15-66; Ord. No. 93-6, § 1, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-119. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the auxiliary shall be to provide a limited number of supplemental reserve auxiliary officers to assist certified law enforcement officers of the city, as needed, with routine patrol, traffic direction and control and crowd control. For purposes of this article, the term "certified law enforcement officer" means a municipal police officer who has completed the training requirements of the Alabama Peace Officers Standards and Training Commission as set out in article 3, chapter 21, title 36 of the Code of Alabama 1975. 
(Code 1992, § 15-67; Ord. No. 93-6, § 2, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-120. - Qualifications. 
    Any person desiring appointment to the auxiliary must submit a written application to the chief of police of the city, certifying that he is a resident of the city, is at least 19 years of age, of good moral character and reputation, and has never been convicted of a felony or of a misdemeanor involving force, violence or moral turpitude. Applicants must consent in writing to a fingerprint and background search. 
(Code 1992, § 15-68; Ord. No. 93-6, § 3, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-121. - Appointment. 
    Appointments to the auxiliary shall be made by the chief of police. Members of the auxiliary shall serve at the pleasure of the chief of police, and may be removed with or without cause and without hearing by the chief of police. 
(Code 1992, § 15-69; Ord. No. 93-6, § 4, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-122. - Supervision. 
    The auxiliary shall function under the immediate direction of the chief of police, who shall provide for its organization and training. The chief of police is hereby authorized and directed to establish such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the efficient operation of the auxiliary. 
(Code 1992, § 15-70; Ord. No. 93-6, § 5, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-123. - Equipment. 
    Each member of the auxiliary shall be issued an identification card signed by the chief of police. Members of the auxiliary shall carry this identification card with them at all times. Whenever a member of the auxiliary shall be called to active duty, he shall be issued a badge and cap which shall be worn at all times while on active duty in the manner prescribed by the chief of police. 
(Code 1992, § 15-71; Ord. No. 93-6, § 6, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-124. - Duties. 
(a)  Generally. The duties of auxiliary officers are confined to the following: 
(1)  Patrol operation. Patrol operation performed for the purpose of detection, prevention and suppression of crime or enforcement of the traffic or highway laws of the state, provided the auxiliary law enforcement officer acts at all times under the direct control and supervision of a certified law enforcement officer. 
(2)  Traffic direction and control. Traffic direction and control may be performed without direct supervision, provided, however, that supervisory control is exercised by a certified law enforcement officer whose total span of control would be considered within reasonable limits. 
(3)  Crowd control. Auxiliary officers may render crowd control assistance at public gatherings or municipal functions as directed by the municipality, provided supervisory control will be exercised by a certified law enforcement officer whose span of control would be considered within reasonable limits. 
(b)  Auxiliary officers; compliance with laws and other regulations. In the performance of these duties, auxiliary officers are required to become familiar with and to comply with all laws of the state and all ordinances, regulations and policies of the city and its police department. 
(Code 1992, § 15-72; Ord. No. 93-6, § 7, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-125. - Arrest powers. 
    No member of the auxiliary shall have any authority to exercise any power of arrest unless he has completed the training requirements of the Alabama Peace Officers Standards and Training Commission as set out in article 3, chapter 21, title 36 of the Code of Alabama 1975. 
(Code 1992, § 15-73; Ord. No. 93-6, § 8, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-126. - Weapons. 
    No member of the auxiliary shall carry a weapon while on active duty unless the following requirements have been fulfilled: 
(1)  Completion of a designated 40-hour basic firearms course; 
(2)  Completion of a class in the use of force; 
(3)  Obtained the age of 21 years; 
(4)  Obtained a licensed pistol permit; 
(5)  Inspection and approval of the weapon by the department for use on active duty; 
(6)  Approval of the chief of police for the auxiliary member to carry the weapon. 
(Code 1992, § 15-74; Ord. No. 93-6, § 9, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-127. - Compensation. 
    No member of the auxiliary shall receive compensation for service in the auxiliary. Auxiliary members are not employees of the city and shall be entitled to no rights or benefits associated with city employment. Members of the auxiliary may be compensated for any reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of official duties while on active duty on prior approval of an expense voucher by the chief of police. 
(Code 1992, § 15-75; Ord. No. 93-6, § 10, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-128. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person not a member of the auxiliary to wear, carry, or display an auxiliary identification card, badge or cap, or in any way represent himself to be connected with the auxiliary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any member of the auxiliary to loan, sell, lease or otherwise permit any person not a member of the auxiliary to wear, carry or display an auxiliary identification card, badge or cap. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any member of the auxiliary to assist any person not a member of the auxiliary to represent himself as connected with the auxiliary. 
(Code 1992, § 15-76; Ord. No. 93-6, § 11, 2-23-1993) 
Sec. 26-129. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of section 26-128 shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine in an amount not exceeding $500.00, a sentence of imprisonment not exceeding six months, or both, at the discretion of the court trying the cause. 
(b)  Additionally, any member of the auxiliary charged with violating section 26-128(b), (c) shall be suspended from the auxiliary pending a determination of guilt. Suspended auxiliary members must surrender their identification card, badge and cap to the chief of police. 
(c)  Auxiliary members who are convicted of violating section 26-128(b), (c) shall be immediately removed from the auxiliary force and shall not be eligible for reappointment to the auxiliary. 
(Code 1992, § 15-77; Ord. No. 93-6, § 12, 2-23-1993) 
Chapter 28 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Moving or removal of survey pins, monuments or other reference points. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority granted to municipalities by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-1, and to promote and to protect the safety, health, welfare and property interests of the citizens of Madison, the council finds it necessary to regulate the removal and/or movement of survey pins, monument, or other reference points, which define property lines within the city limits of the city. 
(b)  Survey pins, monuments, or other reference points which are placed by licensed professional land surveyors to define property lines shall not be moved or removed, except by surveyors who are licensed and registered pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-11-1 et seq. 
(c)  Penalty. A violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(d)  Offenses. Each violation of this section shall be a separate violation and each day of the violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1992, § 16-1; Ord. No. 2001-48, §§ 1-4, 3-26-2001) 
Secs. 28-2-28-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Creation, composition, and powers of municipal planning commission, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-2 et seq. 

Sec. 28-47. - Established; composition; name. 
    Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-2, a planning commission is hereby created for the city, to consist of nine members, to be known and designated as the city planning commission. 
(Code 1979, § 2-14; Code 1992, § 16-20) 
Sec. 28-48. - Members-Designated; selection. 
    The members constituting the planning commission shall consist of the mayor, or the mayor's designee, one of the administrative officials of the municipality selected by the mayor, a member of the city council to be selected by it as a member ex officio and six persons who shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15; Code 1992, § 16-21; Ord. No. 89-60, § I, 11-28-1989) 
Sec. 28-49. - Same-Compensation; holding other offices; terms. 
(a)  All members of the planning commission shall serve as such without compensation, and the appointed members shall hold no other municipal office; except that one of such appointed members may be a member of the zoning board of adjustment. 
(b)  The terms of ex officio members shall correspond to their respective official tenures; except, that the term of the administrative official selected by the mayor or any designee of the mayor shall terminate with the term of the mayor selecting such member. The term of each appointed member shall be six years or until a successor shall take office; except, that the respective terms of five of the members first appointed shall be one, two, three, four and five years. 
(Code 1979, § 2-16; Code 1992, § 16-22) 
Sec. 28-50. - Same-Removal. 
    Members of the planning commission other than the member selected by the city council may, after a public hearing, be removed by the mayor for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. The city council for like cause may remove the member selected by it. The mayor or city council, such as the case may be, shall file a written statement of the reasons for such removal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-17; Code 1992, § 16-23) 
Sec. 28-51. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring on the planning commission, otherwise than through the expiration of term, shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor in the case of members selected or appointed by the mayor, and by the city council in the case of the members selected or appointed by it. 
(Code 1979, § 2-18; Code 1992, § 16-24) 
Sec. 28-52. - Procedural rules; record. 
    The planning commission is hereby authorized to adopt rules for the transaction of business, and it shall keep a record of all its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record. 
(Code 1979, § 2-19; Code 1992, § 16-25) 
Sec. 28-53. - Chairperson; officers. 
    The planning commission shall elect its chairperson from the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of the chairperson shall be one year, with eligibility for reelection. 
(Code 1979, § 2-20; Code 1992, § 16-26) 
Sec. 28-54. - Regular meetings. 
    The planning commission shall hold at least one regular meeting each month. 
(Code 1979, § 2-21; Code 1992, § 16-27) 
Sec. 28-55. - Employees and consultants. 
    The planning commission may appoint such employees as may be necessary for its work and may contract with city planners, engineers, architects and other consultants for such services as may be required to accomplish the purpose for which the planning commission is created. 
(Code 1979, § 2-22; Code 1992, § 16-28) 
Sec. 28-56. - Powers; jurisdiction. 
    The planning commission shall possess all the powers and jurisdiction granted to municipal planning commissions by the laws of the state applicable to municipal planning commissions. 
(Code 1979, § 2-23; Code 1992, § 16-29) 
State Law reference- Powers of municipal planning commission, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-7. 
Secs. 28-57-28-128. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MADISON STATION HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 28-129. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the establishment of a historic preservation commission to promote the educational, cultural, economic and general welfare of the residents of the city through the preservation and protection of buildings, sites, structures, areas and districts of historic significance and interest; through the preservation and enhancement of the national, state and local historic, architectural, archaeological and aesthetic heritage found in the city; and through the promotion and enhancement of Madison's historic and aesthetic attraction to tourists and visitors. 
(Code 1992, § 16-60; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-60), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-130. - Establishment of historic preservation commission. 
    There is hereby established the Madison Station Historic Preservation Commission (the "commission") to provide for the creation, protection and enhancement of historic properties or historic districts, structures, and places in the city. 
(Code 1992, § 16-61; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-61), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-131. - Composition of commission; nomination of members; terms of office; removal; vacancies; officers; rules; reimbursement of expenses; personnel; annual report; meetings. 
(a)  The commission shall be composed of seven members, who shall have demonstrated training or experience in the fields of history, architecture, architectural history, urban planning, archaeology or law, or who shall be residents of an historic district designated pursuant to that ordinance. Members of the commission shall be bona fide residents of the city. Not more than one of the members of the commission shall be a public official. 
(b)  Members of the commission shall be nominated by the mayor and appointed by the city council. Nomination and appointment of members of the commission shall be made so as to ensure that the commission will be composed of persons with as much of the training and experience specified in subsection (a) of this section as is possible. 
(c)  Except for the original members of the commission, members of the commission shall serve three-year terms and shall be appointed in such a manner so as to serve overlapping terms. Two of the original members of the commission shall be appointed to serve one-year terms, two of the original members of the commission shall be appointed to serve two-year terms, and the remainder of the original members of the commission shall be appointed to serve three-year terms. Members of the commission may be reappointed. 
(d)  Members of the commission may be removed for cause by the city council. 
(e)  Vacancies on the commission shall be filled by persons nominated by the mayor and appointed by the city council. Such appointments shall be for the unexpired term of the member replaced. 
(f)  Members of the commission shall elect a chairperson and a vice-chairperson and such other officers as the members deem necessary. The commission shall adopt rules of procedure and bylaws to govern its operations and shall communicate those rules of procedure and bylaws to the mayor and city council. The rules of procedure and bylaws of the commission shall specify what number of members of the commission constitutes a quorum. 
(g)  Members of the commission shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for expenses incurred on behalf of the commission in accordance with the rules and regulations for the reimbursement of expenses adopted by the commission, subject to budgetary allocations made by the city council. 
(h)  The commission may employ such professional, technical, office and other personnel as may be necessary to carry out the purposes and responsibilities of the ordinance enacted pursuant to this article subject to budgetary allocations made by the city council. Staff in the department of planning and building shall perform the commission's administrative duties, such as the taking of meeting minutes and the maintenance of the commission's records. 
(i)  The commission shall prepare and file with the city council, and with the state historical commission, an annual report of its activities as required by the city council and the state historical commission. 
(j)  Meetings of the commission shall be public meetings and shall be held at times and places and pursuant to such notices specified in this article and the Alabama Open Meetings Law (Code of Alabama 1975, § 36-25A). 
(Code 1992, § 16-62; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-62), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-132. - Status of commission as nonprofit agency exempt from taxation. 
    The commission shall constitute a nonprofit governmental agency whose funds shall be used exclusively for public purposes. Such commission shall have tax exempt status, and the properties of the commission and the income therefrom, together with all leases, agreements and contracts made by it, shall be forever exempt from any and all taxation by the state and any political subdivision thereof, including, but not limited to, income, admission, amusement, excise and ad valorem taxes, as specified in Alabama Act 89-536. 
(Code 1992, § 16-63; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-63), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-133. - Powers and duties of commission. 
    The commission shall be authorized to: 
(1)  Preserve and protect buildings, structures and sites of historic and architectural value in the historic districts designated pursuant to this article; 
(2)  Prepare a survey of all property within the city; 
(3)  Recommend to the city council structures, sites and districts for designation as historic properties or districts; 
(4)  Restore and preserve any historic properties acquired by the city; 
(5)  Promote acquisition of facade and conservation easements by the city; 
(6)  Develop and conduct educational programs on historic projects and districts designated pursuant to this article and on historic preservation subjects; 
(7)  Make such investigations and studies of matters relating to historic preservation as the city council or the commission deems necessary and appropriate for the purposes of this article; 
(8)  Apply for funds to carry out the purposes and responsibilities of the commission from municipal, county, state, federal and private agencies and sources; 
(9)  Purchase, sell, contract to purchase, contract to sell, own, encumber, lease, mortgage and ensure real and personal property in carrying out the purposes and responsibilities of the commission, subject to approval of the city council; 
(10)  Investigate, survey and process nominations of properties to the National Register of Historic Places; 
(11)  Investigate, survey and process applications for certification of historic properties for tax credits for preservation expenditures; 
(12)  Contract with other municipal, county, state, federal and private agencies and organizations to perform historic preservation related functions; 
(13)  Exercise such further powers as the commission may deem reasonably necessary and proper to carry out the purposes, responsibilities and powers of the commission. 
(Code 1992, § 16-64; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-64), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-134. - Designation of historic properties and historic districts by municipality on recommendation of commission; criteria. 
(a)  On recommendation of the historic preservation commission, the city council may designate historic properties and historic districts within the territorial jurisdiction of the municipality. 
(b)  The commission shall not recommend designation of an historic property or historic district unless such recommendation is based on a finding of a survey of such property or district conducted by or for the commission in accordance with the rules and regulations of the state historical commission. 
(c)  The commission shall not recommend designation of an historic property or historic district unless it finds that the building, structure, site or district is identified with or represents a significant aspect of the cultural, political, economic, military or social history of the locality, region, state or nation or has had a significant relationship with the life of a historic person or event, representing a major aspect of the history of the locality, region, state or nation, or if a part of the historic, architectural, archaeological or aesthetic heritage of the locality, region, state, or nation. In the case of an individual building or structure, the commission may recommend designation as an historic property if the commission finds that the building or structure is an example of an architectural style, or combination of architectural styles, which is representative of the city or which is unique to that municipality. In the case of a district, the commission may recommend designation as an historic district if the commission finds that the district contains vernacular structures which contribute to an overall character and sense of place which is representative of the municipality creating the commission. 
(Code 1992, § 16-65; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-65), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-135. - Public hearing on proposed recommendation; notification of property owners. 
(a)  Before the commission shall recommend the designation of an historic property or historic district, it shall hold a public hearing on the proposed recommendation of historic designation to be held at a time and place, and pursuant to such notices specified in the ordinance creating the commission. 
(b)  In addition to the notice of the public hearing required pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, all owners of property to be included in the proposed historic designation, as such owners are identified in the relevant property tax rolls, if such owners can be found on reasonable inquiry, shall be notified by mail of the public hearing to be held by the commission on the proposed recommendation of historic designation. 
(Code 1992, § 16-66; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-66), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-136. - Written notice of designation of historic property or district. 
    Upon the designation of any historic property or historic district by the city, pursuant to this article, the historic preservation commission shall give notice in writing of that designation to all agencies of the municipality, and to all owners of property included in the historic designation. 
(Code 1992, § 16-67; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-67), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-137. - Certificate of appropriateness prerequisite to changes in historic property or district; submission and consideration of application for certificate; rules, regulations and standards; expedited procedure; records. 
(a)  No change in the exterior appearance of an historic property or any building, structure or site within an historic district may be made, and no historic property may be demolished, and no building or structure in an historic district may be erected or demolished unless and until a certificate of appropriateness for such change, erection or demolition is approved by the historic preservation commission. Signs shall be considered as structures and no sign on an historic property or in an historic district shall be changed, erected or demolished unless and until a certificate of appropriateness is approved by the commission. The requirement of a certificate of appropriateness shall apply to public property which has been designated as an historic property or which is contained in an historic district, and shall apply to all actions by public authorities which involve historic properties and properties within historic districts. Demolition by neglect and the failure to maintain an historic property or a structure in an historic district shall constitute a change for which a certificate of appropriateness is necessary. The painting of originally unpainted surfaces shall require a certificate of appropriateness, as shall the repaint of painted surfaces that alters the character of the surface. 
(b)  The commission shall adopt rules and regulations setting forth the procedure for submission and consideration of applications for certificates of appropriateness, and no certificate of appropriateness shall be approved unless an application for a certificate of appropriateness is submitted to the commission accompanied by such drawings, photographs and plans, as may be required by the commission. 
(c)  The commission shall adopt general design standards which shall apply in considering the granting and denial of certificates of appropriateness. 
(d)  Applications for certificates of appropriateness shall be considered by the commission at public meetings, held at least monthly in Madison City Hall, on dates and at times provided in the commission's bylaws. The city clerk or commission secretary shall post notice of such meetings at least one week in advance thereof in a manner consistent with the provisions of the Alabama Open Meetings Law (Code of Ala. 1975, § 36-25A). 
(e)  The commission may adopt an expedited procedure for approval of routine maintenance to historic properties, or to buildings or structures in historic districts. Such expedited procedure may waive the requirements for submission of an application for a certificate of appropriateness and for consideration at a public meeting. 
(f)  The commission shall keep a record of all applications for certificates of appropriateness and requests for approval of routine maintenance and of all of its proceedings. 
(Code 1992, § 16-68; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-68), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-138. - Appeal of denial to circuit court. 
    Any person having a request for a certificate of appropriateness denied by the historic preservation commission, or architectural board as hereinafter provided, may appeal such denial to the circuit court of the county in which the commission exists. 
(Code 1992, § 16-69; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-69), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-139. - Issuance of certificate; factors considered; reasons for rejection; application for reconsideration; effect of rejection on issuance of building permit. 
(a)  The historic preservation commission shall approve an application and issue a certificate of appropriateness if it finds that the proposed change, erection or demolition conforms to the general design standards established by the commission, is compatible with the character of the historic property or historic district and does not detract from the value of the historic property or historic district. In making this determination, the commission shall consider, in addition to any other pertinent factors, the historic and architectural features involved and the proposed change thereto, and the relationship thereof, to the exterior architectural style, and pertinent features of other structures in the immediate neighborhood. 
(b)  In its review of applications for certificate of appropriateness, the commission shall not consider interior changes or use having no effect on the exterior of a building or structure. 
(c)  In the event the commission rejects an application, it shall state its reasons for doing so and shall transmit a record of such action and reasons therefor, in writing, to the applicant. The applicant may make modifications to its plans and resubmit the application for reconsideration at any time after doing so. 
(d)  In cases where the application is for a change in the exterior of the building or structure which would require the issuance of a building permit, the rejection of an application for a certificate of appropriateness by the commission shall be binding upon the department of planning and building. 
(Code 1992, § 12-70; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-70), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-140. - Institution of court proceedings to prevent violations and recover damages. 
    The historic preservation commission, or the city, shall be authorized to institute any appropriate action or proceeding in a court of competent jurisdiction to prevent any change in the exterior of a building or structure which is either an historic property or which is contained in an historic district, except in compliance with the provisions of this article or rules and regulations adopted pursuant to it, or to prevent any illegal act or conduct with respect to such historic property, or historic district, and to recover any damages which may have been caused by the violation of that ordinance. 
(Code 1992, § 16-71; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-71), 10-27-2008) 
Sec. 28-141. - Applicability of article to highways, bridges, etc.; applicability of federal provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to a highway, road, street, bridge, or utility structure or facility, nor to any highway, road, street, bridge or utility structure or facility to be constructed or improved, including any property, building or other structure or facility to be changed, moved, demolished, acquired or utilized in connection therewith, lying or running within any municipality or county, or within an historic district or an area designated as historic properties under this article, nor to actions taken in connection therewith by public authorities or utilities charged with responsibility of constructing, maintaining, repairing or improving any such highway, road, street, bridge or utility structure or facility, including any property, building or other structure or facility to be changed, moved, demolished, acquired or utilized in connection therewith; provided further, however, that where property lying within an area designated as historic properties or as an historic district, pursuant to the provisions of this article is sought to be utilized or acquired by any such public authority for the purpose of construction or improvement of a highway, road, bridge, utility structure or facility or street, and the provisions and requirements of Section 106 et seq., of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (16 USCA 470), are applicable to the property acquisition or utilization, the public authority or utility may utilize or acquire any such property, building or other structure or parts thereof, and change, move or demolish any building or other structure in accordance with the applicable provisions, requirements and procedure provided for under such act, including the requirements and procedure as applicable of the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, Section 36, Code of Federal Regulations 800 (16 USCA 470i), and in accordance with the provisions, requirements and procedure as applicable under Section 4(f) of the U.S. Department of Transportation Act of 1966, as amended, 49 USCA 1653(f), and under 23 USCA 138. 
(Code 1992, § 16-72; Ord. No. 2008-269, § 1(12-72), 10-27-2008) 
Secs. 28-142-28-191. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TECHNICAL REVIEW COMMITTEE 

Sec. 28-192. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a technical review committee for the city (the "committee"). 
(Code 1992, § 16-100; Ord. No. 96-164, § 1, 12-17-1996) 
Sec. 28-193. - Membership; terms of service. 
    The committee shall be a staff committee consisting of the heads of the planning development, public works, fire, police, recreation, and of such other municipal departments, or their duly appointed designees, as shall be designated by the mayor. Members appointed to the committee shall serve as long as they continue as city employees, unless released by the mayor. 
(Code 1992, § 16-101; Ord. No. 96-164, § 1, 12-17-1996) 
Sec. 28-194. - Responsibilities and duties. 
    The committee shall make recommendations to land development applicants as to how to correct errors in proposed development plans, improve the design of proposed developments, and ensure that all requirements of the city's applicable laws and regulations are applied to all proposed land developments for which the planning commission is the permitting authority. The committee shall also make a report to the planning commission with respect to the vacation or abandonment of real property rights owned by the city, the changing of any street name, annexations, any proposed rezoning or comprehensive land use plan designation change, or any other matter properly coming before the planning commission. The committee shall also have the authority and responsibility to perform studies at the request of the city council. The committee will furnish a written report on any land development proposal properly coming before the planning commission or the city council to the appropriate body, prior to their action on any proposed land development application, as coordinated by the planning department. 
(Code 1992, § 16-102; Ord. No. 96-164, § 1, 12-17-1996) 
Sec. 28-195. - Officers; administration; meetings. 
    The committee will be co-chaired by the city engineer and director of community development, and the administration thereof shall be the responsibility of the chief of growth management, who shall also serve as committee secretary. The committee will meet at the call of the director of the planning department, or at a regularly scheduled place and time designated by him. 
(Code 1992, § 16-103; Ord. No. 96-164, § 1, 12-17-1996) 
Sec. 28-196. - Advisory role. 
    The committee shall serve in an advisory role to the director of the planning department, who shall make the final determination with respect to any and all recommendations made pursuant to section 28-194; provided, however, that upon the call of any member of the committee, a vote on the matter before it will be taken, and the result of that vote reported to the planning commission or city council, as appropriate. 
(Code 1992, § 16-104; Ord. No. 96-164, § 1, 12-17-1996) 
Sec. 28-197. - Fees. 
    The planning department shall collect the fees prior to consideration of any of the following classes of land development applications. All fees are in addition to fees enumerated in the zoning and subdivision regulations of the city, or elsewhere in the city Code. The amounts of the fees shall be as established by the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1992, § 16-105; Ord. No. 96-164, § 1, 12-17-1996) 
Secs. 28-198-28-217. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DEDICATION OF PROPERTY 

Sec. 28-218. - Scope. 
    The evaluation procedure adopted by this article shall not apply to, or be required for, the dedication of property for streets, sidewalks, drainage and water, sewer, or other utilities required to be constructed and dedicated in accordance with standards established by the zoning and subdivision regulations or the comprehensive plan of the city. With respect to all other dedications of property required as a condition for the approval of a final plat or for issuance of a building permit, the evaluation procedure provided herein shall be followed prior to plat approval or issuance of a building permit, unless waived as provided below. 
(Code 1992, § 16-120; Ord. No. 94-110, § 1, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 28-219. - Recommendation. 
    When any proposed subdivision or site plan is submitted to the planning commission for preliminary plat or site plan approval, the staff of the planning commission may recommend to the planning commission the dedication of property, in fee or by easement, as a condition of the requested approval. 
(Code 1992, § 16-121; Ord. No. 94-110, § 2, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 28-220. - Evaluation required. 
    If the staff of the planning commission determines that a dedication of property should be recommended to the planning commission, the staff shall so inform the applicant and initiate and complete an evaluation of the proposed subdivision. 
(Code 1992, § 16-122; Ord. No. 94-110, § 3, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 28-221. - Waiver. 
    If the applicant does not object to the recommended dedication, the applicant may waive the evaluation in writing. If the developer elects to waive the evaluation, the plat approval process shall proceed as it would if no dedication were involved. 
(Code 1992, § 16-123; Ord. No. 94-110, § 4, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 28-222. - Evaluation procedure. 
    The evaluation shall: 
(1)  Identify the governmental interest creating the need for the recommended dedication; 
(2)  Determine whether a nexus exists between the governmental interest identified and the recommended dedication (that is, determine whether the recommended dedication serves the interest identified); and 
(3)  Make an assessment as to whether there exists a rough proportionality between the projected impact of the proposed subdivision and the recommended dedication (that is, that the recommended dedication is related both in nature and extent to the projected impact of the proposed subdivision). 
(Code 1992, § 16-124; Ord. No. 94-110, § 5, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 28-223. - Factors. 
    In performing the evaluation, the staff of the planning commission will consider any impact on the public health, safety, or welfare, which may include, but shall not be limited to, impact on water sources, supply, or distribution, population density, traffic and roadways, drainage, sanitary sewer, environmental concerns (such as open space, well head, and wetland protection), and recreation. The evaluation will also consider the existence, adequacy, and suitability of any existing facilities. 
(Code 1992, § 16-125; Ord. No. 94-110, § 6, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 28-224. - Schedule. 
    The staff of the planning commission shall complete the evaluation within 90 days of the receipt of the application for subdivision or approval of a proposed site plan. 
(Code 1992, § 16-126; Ord. No. 94-110, § 7, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 28-225. - Report. 
    The staff of the planning commission shall submit to the planning commission a written report of its findings and conclusions. Such report shall summarize the staff's findings for each step of the evaluation as described in section 28-122. The report shall also state any specific interests or concerns identified by the staff that may be impacted by the proposed subdivision (as described in section 28-223), as well as any existing facilities considered in the staff evaluation. 
(Code 1992, § 16-127; Ord. No. 94-110, § 8, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 28-226. - Discretion. 
    The planning commission may, in its discretion, accept or reject any recommendation of the planning commission staff, in whole or in part. 
(Code 1992, § 16-128; Ord. No. 94-110, § 9, 9-13-1994) 
Chapter 30 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate streets and sidewalks, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-1 et seq. 

Sec. 30-1. - Accommodation of utilities. 
    The city hereby adopts the "State of Alabama Highway Department Standards for Accommodating Utilities on Highway Rights-of-Way" as standards, as written and including future amendments thereto, for use by the city for accommodating utilities on roads and streets under the jurisdiction of the city which have or will involve the expenditure of state or federal highway funds. 
(Code 1979, § 18-1; Code 1992, § 17-1) 
Sec. 30-2. - Obstructing streets and sidewalks with goods, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to encumber a street or sidewalk with goods or merchandise, lumber, fuel or any article or obstruction whatever; except, that any merchant may display goods, wares or merchandise immediately in front of such merchant's store or building, but such goods, wares or merchandise shall not extend more than 30 inches from the base of the store or building. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to block or obstruct the sidewalk with goods or merchandise or any article, except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, but in any event the balance of the sidewalk space shall be left unencumbered for pedestrians to walk. 
(Code 1979, § 18-2; Code 1992, § 17-2) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to maintain free and ample passage on sidewalks, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-2. 
Sec. 30-3. - Obstructing ditches, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any ditch, storm drainage pipe, or waterway within any public right-of-way, public drainage easement, or natural stream so as to impede the flow of water in such ditch, storm drainage pipe, or waterway. 
(Code 1979, § 18-3; Code 1992, § 17-3; Ord. No. 2014-106, § 1, 7-15-2014) 
Sec. 30-4. - Standards for municipal consent to street closings and right-of-way vacations. 
(a)  Substantive standards for closure or vacation. The city council shall give its consent to the permanent closing of a publicly dedicated street and/or vacation of a publicly dedicated right-of-way pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 23-4-2 or 23-4-20, only if it finds that: 
(1)  The measured average daily traffic count at the location proposed for closure and/or vacation is less than 100 trips per day; 
(2)  The requested street closure and/or right-of-way vacation shall not deprive any landowner of safe, reasonable and convenient access to, ingress to, or egress from his property; 
(3)  The requested street closure and/or right-of-way vacation shall not cause any delay in emergency response times for ambulance, police, EMT or fire vehicles; 
(4)  The requested street closure and/or right-of-way vacation shall not impair access to overhead or underground utilities; 
(5)  The requested street closure and/or right-of-way vacation shall not create a traffic or pedestrian safety hazard; 
(6)  All applicable substantive and procedural standards of Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 23, ch. 4, have been met by the petition. 
(b)  Procedural standards. 
(1)  The petitioner for road closure and/or right-of-way vacation shall prepare a report on the factors enumerated in subsection (a)(1)-(6) of this section and submit it to the director of the planning department. 
(2)  The petition and study shall undergo review by the EMA director, fire chief, police chief, city engineer, and city planner, who shall report their findings within ten days to the technical review committee (TRC) as constituted pursuant to article III of the city's subdivision regulations. 
(3)  The TRC will receive the petition, study, and analyses of the EMA director, fire chief, police chief, city engineer, and city planner at its next regularly scheduled meeting and make a study thereof. The TRC's findings will be summarized by the planning department and forwarded to the planning commission. 
(4)  The matter will be placed on the following month's planning commission agenda for public comment, and the subject of the petition, along with the date, time and location of said meeting will be advertised in the newspaper with which the city has a contract for such publication or, if none, any newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(5)  At the scheduled date and time, the planning commission will consider the petition, the petitioner's report, and the report of the technical review committee, and make a recommendation on the petition to the city council. 
(6)  The city council will act on the petition at its next regularly scheduled meeting in accord with the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 23, ch. 4. 
(c)  Burden of demonstrating compliance. The burden of demonstrating compliance with the standards enumerated in subsection (a) of this section shall fall to the petitioner. In case the petition is initiated by the city pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 23-4-2, the city shall have the burden of demonstrating compliance with all factors enumerated in subsection (a) of this section, and the council's resolution vacating the specified right-of-way required by Code of Ala. 1975, § 23-4-2, shall specifically state the findings required in subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  Designation of all existing and future public "stub streets". In order to avoid confusion about the future extension of existing and future public "stub streets" pursuant to section 5-4-2015 of the city's subdivision regulations, the planning commission is hereby authorized and directed to designate the status of all existing and future public "stub streets" as "permanently closed" or "future street extension." The planning commission is further authorized and directed to erect signs at the end of each such "stub street," at city expense, advising the public of its status. Such signs shall be erected at the end of each such stub street existing on the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives, no later than July 1, 2001. Thereafter, each newly created "stub street" shall be designated "permanently closed" or "future street extension" within 30 days after acceptance into the city's maintenance program. 
(Code 1992, § 17-4; Ord. No. 2001-76, §§ 1-4, 5-14-2001) 
Sec. 30-5. - Continuation of stub streets. 
(a)  Application. This section shall apply to all developments, including land subdivisions, site plans (except site plan amendments where a principal building already exists) and all other land developments authorized by the city planning commission, by city staff, or by operation of law or ordinance. Neither the planning commission nor city staff shall approve any land development application that does not comply with this section. 
(b)  Continuation of street system. Streets that are stubbed to the property line of a new or proposed development, or within 50 feet of said property line, shall be continued into the internal road system, parking area, or internal drives, as appropriate, of the new property at the time of development of said property. 
(c)  Design criteria. The method, geometry, traffic control, and all regulatory and design elements relating to the required continuation of stub streets into the new development shall be subject to approval by the city engineer based on adopted regulations and good engineering practice. 
(d)  Other regulations. Nothing in these regulations shall act to negate or relieve the developer or property owner whose property is subject to this section from any other regulation, law, or ordinance of the city or state. 
(e)  Administrative exemptions. No administrative waivers, variances, or exemptions from this section are permitted, nor are the city planning commission or zoning board of adjustment authorized to grant waivers, variances, or exemptions from the provisions of this section. 
(f)  Exemptions by the city council. The city council, upon application from the landowner or developer, and upon showing of good cause, may by resolution grant an exemption from the provisions of this article subject to the following process: 
(1)  The landowner or developer shall file a letter of intent with the planning department, including the following items: 
a.  A clear statement of the applicant's request; 
b.  The reason for the exemption; 
c.  A traffic plan for the new development; 
d.  A statement, sealed by a professional engineer licensed in the state, that making the required connection is unsafe or is for some other reason not good engineering practice; 
e.  A fee in an amount as established by the council, from time to time, to defray the expense of administering the application; and 
f.  A list of any local or state laws, ordinances, or regulations which effectively prevent making the required connection safely (if any); 
(2)  The city engineer shall study the application and make a recommendation on its disposition to the city council within ten days after the receipt thereof. In the analysis, the city engineer shall be guided by the presumption that all developments subject to the provisions of this section shall comply therewith unless the applicant can demonstrate good cause for exemption. 
(3)  Within ten days after the receipt thereof, the city engineer shall forward the application, all supporting documents, and his recommendation to the city clerk for inclusion on the agenda of the next regular council meeting. 
(4)  The city council shall, by resolution at a regular council meeting, approve, deny, or approve with conditions the application. 
(5)  If the resolution is approved, the city clerk shall provide a certified copy of the resolution to the applicant. If denied, the city clerk shall notify the applicant in writing of the denial. 
(Code 1992, § 17-5; Ord. No. 2006-359, § 1, 1-8-2007) 
Sec. 30-6. - Installation of street lights, payment. 
(a)  Street lights installed by private developers in rights-of-way, to be accepted by the council into city maintenance, must be paid for by the private developer as a cost of the development and must be installed prior to acceptance into maintenance. 
(b)  Street lights installed by the city, in existing streets, will be paid for at the time the request for installation is made. The respective utility will provide an aid-to construction cost for the light installation and a request for funding will be presented to council for approval. 
(c)  Street light installation for both new construction and request for installation on existing streets shall comply with the city street light policy. 
(Code 1992, § 17-6; Ord. No. 2010-268, §§ 1-3, 10-11-2010) 
Chapter 32 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate motor vehicles and traffic, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-49-4, 11-49-5; motor vehicles and traffic generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-1 et seq.; powers of local authorities generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-1; Alabama Rules of the Road Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-1 et seq.; appearance upon arrest for misdemeanor generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-4; depositing driver's license in lieu of bail, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 32-1-5, 32-1-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Incorporation of state motor vehicle and traffic laws and rules and regulations of the state department of public safety.
